story:
Introducing Fred...

(He's the one on the left in the stripey shirt)

Fred is a friend and the librarian at the Ugandan Arts Trust (where I work). He's an extraordinary man. 

Fred was born in a small village in Uganda, with polio. No one was aware of how to treat Fred's illness and one day Fred woke up and couldn't walk.  His legs had wasted away.  

This never stopped Fred from growing: mentally, physically and artistically. 

Despite the odds of poverty and disability, Fred travelled to Kampala, Uganda's capital, and worked his way up through the education chain to complete a Degree in Fine Art at East Africa's most prestigious establishment, Makerere University.

I don't know either how he managed it, but he did.

How I met Fred...

Upon graduating and on hearing about our organisation Fred organised himself a funded internship with us.  

The day he walked through my office was pretty blooming magical. Armed with two supporters from "Handicap International" Fred said:

"I'm going to work for you for the next three months and prove to you that you need me!"

How could we refuse.

Then Fred wanted more...

Now Fred works for us full time, earning enough money to support himself and a bit for his family back in the village.

But Fred wants (and deserves) more.

He wants to share his skills and motivation with others by running a Saturday art class teaching other disabled people art and craft skills so they can:

  • Make a living
  • Meet other pals
  • Get off the streets
  • Be proud of themselves and each other

Watch out...

If you give to this campaign, this is what you'll do:

  • Provide all the materials needed for Fred's Saturday Art Class for 6 months.
  • Provide transport costs for the participants.
  • Give disabled people a way to get off the streets and into work.
  • Give hope, enjoyment and empowerment to some incredible individuals.
  • Earn me as your biggest fan forever.

If you can't contribute, don't worry too much but please SHARE this campaign so we reach our goal and get Fred's art class rocking.

Thank you from the bottom of my arty heart.

Rocca xx

story:
As some of you may know we ran this campaign earlier this year. We raised $1760 of our goal of $3500. It was enough to get us started and now it's time to finish.

The 7 Deadly Sins series consists of seven models each representing one of the 7 Deadly Sins: wrath, greed, sloth, pride, lust, envy, and gluttony.  We are fortunate to work with 6 amazing body painters throughout the series. 

The photo shoot will entail of the model climbing in the coffin and being shot from above. These photos will be done individually as well as composited into one larger photo with each coffin side by side.


We began our journey on July 27, 2013 with Gluttony. We had so much fun covering the model in paint, candy and pouring chocolate down her. On September 22, 2013 we painted Envy. Even a few snakes slithered their way on set. Next in the series is Lust on November 24, 2013. 

After we complete Lust we will need your help to complete the series. 

Greed-January 26, 2014

Wrath- March 15, 2014

Pride- March 15, 2014

Sloth-TBA

We will also be documenting this process and creating a Behind the Scenes video to hopefully be completed May 2014.

Funds will be used to pay body painters, models, make-up/hair artist, purchase supplies for painting, make-up, set design, food for crew and any unexpected materials to complete project.

story:
Projet d’installation et d’interventions urbaines à Charlottetown, par le biais de la Confederation Art Gallery, Île du Prince Édouard, Canada, en août 2014.

Art Exhibition (installation and performance outside), at the Confederation Art Gallery, Charlottetown, PEI, Canada, in august 2014.

Conception de quatre sculptures mobiles. The creation of a serie of four mobile homes (small wagons) with their creatures.*english version will follow.

Je suis artiste visuelle et ma pratique artistique s'inscrit dans l'art contextuel, l'installation performée et la sculpture vêtement.

Mes dernières expériences en résidences artistiques à l'étranger et au Québec m’ont amenée à réfléchir sur les notions de nomadisme. Je m’interroge sur les concepts de mobilité et d’interrelation entre les formes et les êtres.  La notion de sculptures habitats et plus précisément de maisons artistiques mobiles s’est avérée pertinente dans mon parcours de déracinée. Je conçois des vêtements relationnels qui servent à la réalisation de performances collectives dans lesquelles les gens sont invités à participer. Je m’intéresse donc aux différents tissus, différentes couleurs et systèmes de confection pour créer des vêtements interconnectables.

J’en suis maintenant à fabriquer des architectures portables à roulettes. Tels des habitacles qu’on porte sur son dos, un « vêtement-maison » ambulant et amovible. Je propose ainsi, aux différentes structures d’accueil, ce concept d’haltes nomades. À cet effet, la Confederation Art Gallery, à Charlottetown, m'a invité à présenter un projet d'installation extérieur, en août 2014. Pour ce faire j'ai besoin de financement pour les coûts de matériel,  d'un atelier de menuiserie et des services d'un technicien. 

Le corpus d’œuvres que je veux créer s’inscrit dans l’optique de l’exil, une création de maisons mobiles, des architectures portables. Il s’agit d’une série de petites caravanes-wagons avec lesquelles les participants se déplaceront dans la ville, habillés d’une combinaison créée à cet effet, tels des étrangers suivant un trajet tracé d’avance, des créatures nomades exploratrices. Ils pourront ainsi déambuler à leur guise dans la ville.  Lorsque les caravanes-wagons seront installées, inhabitées, elles deviendront un petit village de maisons mobiles abandonnées par leurs propriétaires. Une trace de leur passage, de leur mobilité.

Techniquement, les caravanes-wagons seront construites en bois pour la structure et en tissu imperméable qui recouvrera les toits et les sièges. Elles seront munies d’un système de roues et d’attelage à l’avant et à l’arrière pour qu’elles puissent s’emboîter et ainsi former un train.

La caravane, tout comme la tente, symbolise beaucoup dans nos sociétés actuelles : de l’objet récréatif à la situation précaire de réfugiés (catastrophe naturelle, déportation ou guerre). Elle représente d’une part, l’idée de la maison mobile, du voyage, des vacances, de la liberté tout en étant souvent symbole de résistance, de contestation, d’oppression, de pertes de territoire et d’identités. 


J'alimenterai régulièrement ma campagne de financement en postant des esquisses et des images liées au processus de création.


Budget

Frais de matériaux (approximatif): 1500 $ CAD

Frais d'utilisation de l'atelier de menuiserie (au Centre Clark): 3 jours semaine x 25$ x 6 : 450$ CAD

Frais de service d'un technicien: au centre Clark  (35$/h)  35$ x 10h : 350$ CAD

TOTAL: 2300$ CAD*

*Même si je n'atteins pas l'objectif total, l'argent contribuera à faire avancer mon projet, m'aidera à l'achat de matériaux et à payer autres frais liés au projet.

Ainsi, en août 2014, le projet Vagabond Blues sera présenté à la Confederation Art Gallery, à Charlottetown, à l'île du Prince-Édouard. Et vous aurez contribué à la mise en lumière de ce projet.

Pour plus d'informations mes projets antérieurs vous pouvez visiter mon site web:
www.christinecomeau.com


Je vous remercie à l'avance de l'intérêt que vous porterez à la réalisation de Vagabond Blues.


* I am a visual artist, I dedicate my life in making sculptural textile art work and installation. The topics of her work are about nomadism, exil, identities and networks between human being and their environment. So I am interested in different issues, different colors and pack systems which can be slotted and intertwined to create clothing. I am now making portable architectures onwheels such as cockpits that carry a "garment-home". My art work has been presented in several individual and collective events and exhibitions in Canada, Brasil, United States, Sweden, Portugal and Germany.  I took part of several artistic residencies around the world in the past 8 years. Artistic residencies combine art, travels and passages. They form an integral part of my artistic practice. I propose to the art organisations this concept of nomadic stopping place. The confederation Art Gallery invited me to present a new art project in august 2014.  I need financial aid to be able to realize this outside installation and performance. 

The project Vagabond Blues will consist in an outdoor installation of a serie of small caravans (with more outfits about 4) as a nomadic stop of these outsiders. There will be performances (parades) organized during the exhibition. Similarly the participants will move into the city, dressed in blue overalls, (following a random walk or path ahead) coming across as strange nomadic creatures.

When they will be stable, without any inhabitants, the cavarans will look as a small village of mobile homes abandoned by their owners, a trace of their passage.

The caravan, as the tent symbolizes many in today's society: the object recreational to the precarious situation of refugees (natural disaster, war or deportation). It represents the one hand, the idea of the mobile home, travel, holidays, freedom while often a symbol of protest, oppression, loss of territory and identity.

Technically, caravan-wagons  will be constructed in timber for structure and waterproof fabric to recover the  roof.  They will be designed for walking. A system of attelage wil be fixed behind and in the front of each caravan to create a small train.  The participants are found among volunteers, friends and fellow artists.

During the campaign, I will post some images to show the process of the project.

Your financial aid will help me to buy art supplies and to rent a wood studio and to pay a technician.

Budget: Art supplies: 1500$ CAD, Wood studio rental (centre Clark): 450$ CAD, Technician service: 350$ CAD*

*Even if I dont get the total goal the money will help me to afford material and services.


I invite you to visit my website to get more informations about my last projects:
www.christinecomeau.com

Thank you in advance for your interest in Vagabond Blues.

story:
Basically, we are going to be attend the upcoming Scottish Brony convention, BronyScot, which is being held in Edinburgh, Scotland in the Autumn.

We wish to have our own stall to sell various merchandise and prints. However, we lack any sort of funding - so we're asking from help from the community. 

Any donation, however small, would be very much appreciated!
story_txt: Basically, we are going to be attend the upcoming Scottish Brony convention, BronyScot, which is being held in Edinburgh, Scotland in the Autumn.We wish to have our own stall to sell various merchandise and prints. However, we lack any sort of funding - so we're asking from help from the community. Any donation, however small, would be very much appreciated!

story:
Hi. We're grunt gallery. Maybe you have heard of us, we are a Canadian artist-run centre established 1984, with a long history of working with many artists communities in Vancouver and across the world from our facility in the east side of Vancouver. We produce exhibitions, performances and projects in contemporary art as well as websites. Check our site at grunt.ca.

Our next project is the group exhibition BLIZZARD: Emerging Northern Artists curated by Beat Nation curator Tania Willard, and featuring 5 artists from the North opening July 5, 2012 . This exhibition was inspired by the impact of the artworks included and the way in which these works reinterpret and translate ideas and culture from the South, making us the outsiders. Dismantling the paternalistic nature of the South's relationship with the North, Our North, BLIZZARD attempts to create space to view new works that reflect the intimacy of connection to land and culture, but also use humour, shock, and critique to re-frame that understanding of land and culture. Just as Beat Nation has changed the way people look at the artworks by young aboriginal artists, Blizzard will show us what a new generation of indigenous artists in the North are accomplishing. But we need your help.

Artists:

Jamasie Pitseolak

Nicholas Galanin

Tanya Lukin-Linklater

Geronimo Inutiq

And in the Media Lab

Northern Haze: Living the Dream (2011, Director: Derek Aqqiaruq)


We need to raise $2500 to help cover the printing cost of our publication. We already have some support but need your help to produce an exciting catalogue to document this important work. So we're turning to our supporters to ask for contributions. As recognition of your support, we're offering first editions of the catalogue, invitations to the artists' reception and other perks from our products and publications. Your contribution will help us cover printing costs for the publication, and further, it will help give us a deeper understanding of artmaking in the North. Thanks!

story:
ARTENERGYFUTURE

Creating a sustainable future from the inside out. 

May 24 to July 1, 2012

Regional Museum of Natural Science of Turin, Italy


33 Contemporary Gallery in Chicago is pleased to announce a unique opportunity to exhibit the work of its gallery artists at the prestigious Regional Museum of Natural Science in Turin, Italy.  Through ART-ENERGY-FUTURE, our gallery will be supporting the International Year of Sustainable Energy. This exhibition is curated by Sergio Gomez. 

We are asking for your support in funding this international exhibition project.  



Who We Are


33 Contemporary Gallery is a Chicago-based fine arts gallery with over seven years of continuous exhibitions. Our purpose is to represent, promote and facilitate collaborations through the gallery, online presence, mobile media and to provide our clientele (experienced and novice) with a fine selection of art works. We represent local, national and international emerging and established artists working in various media. We provide diverse opportunities for self-exploration, enrichment and professional growth via collaborations with local and international artists, as well as other galleries and art institutions.


The Impact

This exhibition is also part of an international exchange program between 33 Contemporary Gallery and ArteItalia Magazine. Our long-term commitment is to ensure that this program continues to evolve. 

Participating Artists:

Terry Adams

Mary Bookwalter

Carla Carr

Jennifer Cartolano-Moore

Dena Cavazos

Javier Chavira

Sijia Chen

Maribeth Coffey-Sears & Mark Hereld

Cesar Conde

Jennifer Cronin 

Nicholas DePeder 

Tanya Gadbaw

Sergio Gomez

Mario Gonzalez Jr.

Petronilla Hohenwarter

Timothy Hurley

Cheng-Yung Kuo

Alice McMahon

Janice F. Meister

Eddwin Meyers

Joe B. Milosevich

Injung Oh Zhoushi

Pedro Palacios

Alberto Paniaya 

Brigitta Rossetti

Michael Ruback

Steve Sherrell

Lou Shields

Christine Simpson Forni

Harry Sudman

Michael Wasniowski

Carol Weber

Mark Zlotkowski



What We Need & What You Get

In order to cover all exhibition expenses, we need to raise $3,000 US dollars. This amount will cover for shipping to Italy and back to Chicago, exhibition catalogs and postcards. Please see the list on the right to find out what you get for helping us reach our goal.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please helps us get the word out and to raise the funds we need to fulfill this exhibition project. Please use the SHARE tools in this website.


Our Partners

33 Contemporary Gallery has partnered with ItaliaArte Magazine in the organization of this exhibition.


VISIT US AT: www.33contemporary.com

story:
In 2013 and 2014 a very exciting exhibition, titled "GLASSS", will be showing glass from a selection of the best of Danish glass artists at Holsterbro Kunstmuseum and Sophienholm, both in Denmark. It is the third and last of its kind, the first in 2004 and the second in 2007 both showing glass in an unprecedentedly grand format in Denmark. For the exhibition in 2007 I showed 10 large cast glass sculptures.

 

Together with curator ATILA we have planned that I will make and show a large installation of 300+ small individually unique bowls, all made by a technique I have developed over some years. They all have a common shape, but in the creation process  I have left room for uncontrolled "happy accidents" where the properties of the materials involved take over - meaning each one is a unique expression.

 

The concept

A lot of contrasting concepts meet in this project, the fragile edges against a solid heavy bottom, the transparent grey glass mixing non-homogeneously with opaque black glass, from very detailed texture zoomed out to an overview in large numbers and as with most of my glass, the often clean idea of glass is met with a rougher more raw approach to it.

The shape from above is a very rounded rectangle approx. 13 cm across and the bowl is 9 cm tall.

 

 By either pre-purchasing one of these bowls, buying one of the print perks or in any other way contributing to this project by spreading the word, you will make a concrete difference in meeting the goal of 300+, allowing me to fund the raw materials, energy and workshop space.  I will ship to anywhere in the world, they travel well in a protected box. If you like the sound of the project or think others might have an interest, please share this with your network and help spread the word.

 

About me

I have worked with glass for over 10 years and graduated from The Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts, School of Designin 2005. After graduation I lived in New Zealand and worked in my own studio for almost 6 years, before returning to Denmark in 2011 to join Luftkraft Glasstudio.

 

The Exhibition

The artists included in the coming exhibition are Lene Bødker, Tobias Møhl, Stig Persson,Pernille Braun, Tillie Burden, Jeannet Iskandar, Susanne Jøker Johnsen, Micha Maria Karlslund, Maria Koshenkova, Karen Lise Krabbe, Pipaluke Lake, Marie Retpen and myself.

It will open in Holstebro Kunstmuseum, Denmark 25th May till 8th September 2013 and at Sophienholm, Lyngby, Denmark 12th April till 22nd may 2014

 

Return to this site to follow progress, for updates and to get insight of the making process.

story:
First of all welcome! And thank you for taking the time to check out Wondrous: Tales When Wishing Still Helped, a series of illustrations based on captivating and imaginative folk and faerie tales from around the world.

I believe that these tales are just as important today as they’ve ever been; for they connect us with our past, ground us in the present and lift us to our future.

Great faerie tales always have beautiful illustrations to go along with them, ones that we stare at for hours and that have inspired the imagination of generations to dream of worlds with wicked trolls, brave princess, greedy dragons and clever tailors.

My goal is to create a series of 10 illustrations of folk and faerie tales that capture a bit of that wonder I had when reading them for the first time, and hopefully introduce them to a new audience.

 

My name is Anthony Wallace; I’m an illustrator living in beautiful Canada. In 2012 I won third place in the Jim Henson Fraggle Rock 30th Anniversary Illustration Contest.

I fell in love with these tales when I was given my very own book of Irish Fairy tales, I spent hours reading these stories and staring at the illustrations, looking at all the little details and secrets that the artist had put into it. I want to pass on my passion of these tales; I love great stories that steal your imagination and the great people who tell them.

 

Albert Einstein said, “If you want your children to be intelligent, read them fairy tales. If you want them to be more intelligent, read them more fairy tales.”

We all have a connection to these stories, whether it was being read them at bedtime, maybe a grandparent sat you on their knee and told you a tale or two, or you discovered them on your own one day in a quiet library.

These stories are an ancient tradition that is part of who we are, and bring us together as humans. There are around 35 different versions of Little Red Riding Hood found from all over the word, which to me says we all have the same dreams, same fears and the same past.

 

If I lived in a faerie tale, I would be working away at my art in an enchanted forest and learning all the troll secrets, with no cares in the world; but sadly I don’t.

I want to give the time and care to this project that it deserves, to create 10 quality illustrations and an accompanying pdf book of the series. All this takes money: for new paints, brushes and paper, and most importantly to support me so I can focus on this project.

 

Well I’m hoping it will be done by the end August 2013. I’ve already completed two out of the proposed ten, and I am currently working on the third, so I feel I’m in good shape.

 

 

The hi-res image from the series can be your choice. There are two all ready for download! Or you can choose to wait for a later illustration.

 

The Pdf book will collect all the illustrations and show additional drawings and excerpts from their accompanying stories, as well as showing the process I take to create them. It will be available as a digital download.

 

All the illustrations will be 13"x17" gallery quality Giclée prints on natural white, matte, ultra smooth, 100% cotton rag, acid and lignin free archival paper using Epson UltraChrome™ K3 archival inks and trimmed by hand.

 

The original 8"x10" drawing will be on Strathmore smooth bristol, 100lb acid free paper. Each drawing will be unique (I won’t be drawing the same thing over and over), they'll be somewhere between a sketch and a finished drawing, and they’ll go hand in hand with the themes of the project. So you can expect lots of sprites, trolls and dragons for sure.

 

The original 5"x7" watercolour painting will be on Strathmore acid -free, 140 lb coldpress watercolour paper

 

Just because you can’t contribute doesn’t mean you can’t help, and a helping hand is worth a lot.

Share this campaign with all your friends and family on Facebook, or twitter or any other ways you can think of, to anyone you think might find this project wondrous!

The Indiegogo share tools on this site are a great place to start getting the word out!

 

Thank you for taking the time to read this, and in the end that’s all I ask for. So feel free ask any questions, and hopefully I'll have the answers.

Thank you!

 

- Anthony

story:
About "Pink Ribbon Calendar"

‘One in 9 women will be diagnosed with breast cancer in their lifetime – that’s 7 women a day" 

"Pink Ribbon Calendar" involves the encounter of a photographer's team and a group of women affected by breast cancer and turning the resulting artwork into a high quality, glossy 2014 calendar.

Our goal is to sell the calendar to increase awareness about breast cancer in Quebec and to raise funds for the Quebec Breast Cancer Foundation. In order, to get this project of the ground, we need $7,000 to cover the production costs.

What's so special about this calendar?

The "Pink Ribbon Calendar" ranges from age 18 to 70 years old and includes a variety of professional women. ALL of these women have been affected by breast cancer. 

The calendar images are a collaborative effort between the model, make-up artist, photographer and graphic designer: 

Each women chose to highlight their own strengths, passions and purposes in life. A team of artists then worked to capture this essence and transfer it onto the model’s pose. Finally, the photographer and graphic designer created the setting for each photo and ensured there was a flow from month to month. 

The calendar is designed as a beautiful piece of art, each month presents a different message of hope. These messages are one of strength, determination, family, courage and more, while also being a constant reminder to women to get regular breast examinations. 

The calendar will be launched at an exclusive event in Montreal in the first week of October. (Breast Cancer Awareness Month)

 

Who's behind the "Pink Ribbon Calendar" projet?

 
This project was started by Stephane Morin, a professional photographer living in Quebec. We hope that this project will not only raise funds for the QBCF, but also increase awareness about breast cancer in this country. Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women and it is a detectable disease. Regular examinations & mammograms can save lives.
 
Please note:  All of the wonderful people involved in this project have volunteered their time and expertise.  Therefore, all the money raised will go towards the Quebec Breast Cancer Foundation.
 

 

A propos du "Calendrier Ruban Rose"

«Une femme sur 9 sera diagnostiquée avec le cancer du sein dans leur vie - c'est 7 femmes par jour"

Le "Calendrier Ruban Rose" mettra en scène un groupe de femmes touchées par le cancer du sein, un photographe professionnel et son équipe. Le projet vise à produire une oeuvre de qualité artistique supérieure, en un calendrier "Ruban Rose" 2014.

La vente du calendrier visera à accroître la sensibilisation au cancer du sein au Québec et d'amasser des fonds pour la Fondation Québécoise du Cancer du Sein. Cependant, pour en couvrir les coûts de production et permettre la réalisation de ce projet, nous avons besoin d'amasser 7000$.

Quelle est la particularité de ce Calendrier?

Le "Calendrier Ruban Rose" mettra en scène des femmes professionnelles de différentes régions du Québec âgées entre 18 et 70 ans. TOUTES ces femmes sont des survivantes ou des combattantes du cancer du sein.

Les images du calendrier résulteront d'un effort collectif entre ces femmes, une équipe artistique, le photographe et un infographiste, afin de rendre hommage à leur courage et transmettre un message d'espoir.

Chacune des femmes prendra la pose de façon à mettre en évidence sa personnalité, ses forces et passions. Pour ce faire, elles seront assistées d'une équipe artistique travaillant en étroite collaboration afin d'en saisir l'essence lors de la mise en scène. Enfin, le photographe et son infographiste travailleront aux réglages finaux de chacune des images et en assureront la mise en page de mois en mois.

Alors que le calendrier sera conçu comme une oeuvre d'art, chaque mois sera porteur d'un message d'espoir. Les thèmes seront ceux de la force, la détermination, la famille, et le courage, tout en étant également un rappel constant pour les femmes à se soumettre à des contrôles réguliers des seins.

Le calendrier sera lancé lors d'un événement exclusif qui aura lieu à Montréal dans la première semaine d'octobre (mois de sensibilisation au cancer du sein).

 

Qui est à l'origine du projet "Calendrier Ruban Rose"? 

Ce projet a été initié par Stéphane Morin, un photographe professionnel vivant au Québec. Nous espérons que ce projet permettra non seulement de recueillir des fonds pour la Fondation du cancer du sein du Québec, mais aussi d'en accroître la sensibilisation. Le cancer du sein est le cancer le plus fréquent chez les femmes et c'est une maladie détectable. Des contrôles réguliers et des mammographies sauvent des vies.
 
Notez que toutes les merveilleuses personnes impliquées dans ce projet le font totalement gratuitement, permettant ainsi à ce que tous les fonds recueillis soient remis à la Fondation du cancer du sein du Québec

story:
Who I Am and What We are Building

My name is Bob Marzewski, but everyone knows me as wizzard.  I have been taking art to Burning Man for the past 14 years.  I have built pieces large and small, by myself and with crews.  This is going to be my most challenging piece yet. 

For 2012, my project is the Mayan TRIcycle.  It is a human powered tread-wheel, which will advance the days on three Mayan Calendars – the Haab, the Tzolkin and the Long Count.  My ultimate goal is to help others understand how the Mayan Calendar works and to help alleviate the fears that many have that the world as we know it is going to end on December 21st when the calendar 'ends'.  I believe that the cycle is just turning over, much like the odometer in your car does. To visually show this, I am building the Mayan TRIcycle. The 260-day Tzolkin Calendar will be a 13’ tall wheel, driven/rotated by humans running inside the wheel. The 365-day Haab Calendar will be a 24’ tall wheel that the Tzolkin calendar wheel is cradled in. Together the two wheels will rotate and will advance the Long Count “Odometer”. 

Why We Are on Indiegogo

We are on Indiegogo to raise awareness of the Mayan TRIcycle and to have people, like you, donate to the project to help us purchase supplies and get the TRIke to Black Rock City.  We have already raised an initial $4,000. But, it is going to take another $3,000 to make it happen.  The wood alone is costing us more than $5,000 (and we have been getting it at a discounted rate!!). 

This is by far the most complicated and expensive art piece that I have attempted thus far.  But, I think it is going to be awesome visually, as well as fun and educational.  In order to build it, I am going to use over 100 sheets of plywood – 3/8” for the skin, 3/4” for the gears/teeth and 1 1/8” for the sides/rings; 100 - 2 x 4s; 4 – 24' beams; 40 casters; 4 deep cell batteries; night lighting; plus wind generators, paint, nuts, bolts, screws, nails, etc, etc, etc. The list goes on and on.  

The Mayan TRIcycle is a kenetic, interactive art piece.  Everyone in Black Rock City will have an opportunity to take a spin on the TRIke.  When you donate, you can brag to everyone that you helped build it.  And they WILL be impressed! 

What's In It For You?

We have some great gifts for you if you donate to our project.  All our gifts have images that are essential to the project. For all the items with the stela on them, the stela depicts the day the Man burns (which is also the day the TRIke burns!! How about that!!!).  If you are getting one of the pendants, the glyph is one of the glyphs from the stela.  These are LIMITED edition pendants and are not being mass produced.  If you are getting the set of 5 glyph pendants, they are the five glyphs that make up the Long-Count Calendar for the day the Man burns. 

What Happens If We Don't Reach Our Goal

We are hopeful that we will get all the funding we need.  If we don't get it all here, we will just have to find it elsewhere.  But, we would prefer to have this be our last fund-raising effort.  We really need to shift our focus to building the piece and getting it ready to take to the desert.  With your help, this will be the last of our fundraising efforts.  

The Impact

The Mayan TRIcycle is going to be an imposing structure that should leave an impression on those who have a chance to see it and I hope a significant fraction of them also take the time to learn a bit about the Mayan culture and complexity of their way of thinking.

It is also valuable at Burning Man in that it is an art piece that will be set on fire and burned it to the ground on Saturday morning (look for it to burn at 2:00 am.).  Few thing burners value more than a big wood fire.

We will have a crew at the site to clean it all up and leave the playa as clean as it was before we started to build – LNT. 

As I stated above, this will be my 14th year to take art to Burning Man.  My past projects include:

  • A Place to Stand (2003)
  • Pagoda of Infinite Reflection (2004)
  • Project X (2005)
  • Intelligent Design (2006/2009)
  • THE END (2008)
  • Valley of Heart's Delight (crew member of South Bay CORE project 2011). 

In 2003, I was asked to be in the documentary Burning Man: Beyond Black  Rock (now available on NetFlix if you want to watch it).  I was one of three artists who was featured in the film. I am the guy who had the house fire. 

In 2000, a photo of my art piece for that year made the front page of the SF Chronicle - in color. 

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

If you can't contribute monetarily (and even if you can) we can still use your help in other ways.  We will be needing: 

  • Docents (people to tell riders of the TRIke about the piece) – 2 hour shift

  • Safety Crew (to make sure people don't do something “special” to hurt themselves) – 3 hour shift

  • Fire Perimeter Crew (to keep viewers a safe distance away from the burning piece) – 4+ hour shift the night of the burn)

  • Cleanup Crew (to eradicate all signs of the TRIke – clean up the Decomposed Granite that the piece is built / burned - on Saturday morning after the burn)

We can also use your help by sharing our project will all your friends.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools and like us on Facebook.  Tweet about us.  Blog about us.  Help us get the word out.

For More Info

You can visit our website - http://wizzard.com/bm2012/ or our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/#!/MayanTricycle

We have some great gifts for you if you donate to our project.  All our gifts have images that are essential to the project. For all the items with the stela on them, the stela depicts the day the Man burns (which is also the day the TRIke burns!! How about that!!!).  If you are getting one of the pendants, the glyph is one of the glyphs from the stela.  These are LIMITED edition pendants and are not being mass produced.  If you are getting the set of 5 glyph pendants, they are the five glyphs that make up the Long-Count Calendar for the day the Man burns. 
What Happens If We Don't Reach Our Goal
We are hopeful that we will get all the funding we need.  If we don't get it all here, we will just have to find it elsewhere.  But, we would prefer to have this be our last fund-raising effort.  We really need to shift our focus to building the piece and getting it ready to take to the desert.  With your help, this will be the last of our fundraising efforts.  
The Impact
The Mayan TRIcycle is going to be an imposing structure that should leave an impression on those who have a chance to see it and I hope a significant fraction of them also take the time to learn a bit about the Mayan culture and complexity of their way of thinking.
It is also valuable at Burning Man in that it is an art piece that will be set on fire and burned it to the ground on Saturday morning (look for it to burn at 2:00 am.).  Few thing burners value more than a big wood fire.
We will have a crew at the site to clean it all up and leave the playa as clean as it was before we started to build – LNT. 
As I stated above, this will be my 14th year to take art to Burning Man.  My past projects include:

A Place to Stand (2003)
Pagoda of Infinite Reflection (2004)
Project X (2005)
Intelligent Design (2006/2009)
THE END (2008)
Valley of Heart's Delight (crew member of South Bay CORE project 2011). 
In 2003, I was asked to be in the documentary Burning Man: Beyond Black  Rock (now available on NetFlix if you want to watch it).  I was one of three artists who was featured in the film. I am the guy who had the house fire. 
In 2000, a photo of my art piece for that year made the front page of the SF Chronicle - in color. 
Other Ways You Can Get Involved
If you can't contribute monetarily (and even if you can) we can still use your help in other ways.  We will be needing: 


Docents (people to tell riders of the TRIke about the piece) – 2 hour shift


Safety Crew (to make sure people don't do something “special” to hurt themselves) – 3 hour shift


Fire Perimeter Crew (to keep viewers a safe distance away from the burning piece) – 4+ hour shift the night of the burn)


Cleanup Crew (to eradicate all signs of the TRIke – clean up the Decomposed Granite that the piece is built / burned - on Saturday morning after the burn)

We can also use your help by sharing our project will all your friends.  Please use the Indiegogo share tools and like us on Facebook.  Tweet about us.  Blog about us.  Help us get the word out.
For More Info
You can visit our website - http://wizzard.com/bm2012/ or our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/#!/MayanTricycle

story:
HELP BUILD A MODEL LONG-TERM "VEHICLE" FOR EMPOWERING HOMELESS AND LOW-YOUTH TO FULFILL THEIR DREAMS THROUGH ART!

Youth Spirit Artworks is an innovative and dynamic green jobs and job training program based in Berkeley, California empowering and transforming the lives of homeless and low-income young people, ages 16 to 25, through art. Youth Spirit engages young people in creating both studio art to sell, as well as community art for neighborhood revitalization. Youth engaged in our studio art program paint art mugs, design and print tee shirts and tote bags, and paint on canvas, as well as creating other art to sell.

In our first five years we held 6 exhibits, 3 art auctions, and sold lots of art in our retail store. Now, after completing an exciting new business plan, our youth participants want to increase their sales of art by taking their work to local shopping areas where they can sell it even more actively. Our goal this year is to increase our revenues from outside sales of art from $2,000 to $15,000 by involving youth in selling art at specific sites 3 days each week.

In order to do that our youth need a GREEN mechanism for getting their art to market: an adult tricycle/art cart vehicle and matching bicycle for a second art seller to ride. We are asking for your help in raising funds to purchase these two art transportation vehicles.

story:
Thanks to Everyone Who Supported!!! 

Although we didn't reach our goal, we will still be able to use your contributions to make a difference. Follow us on www.facebook.com/theliquidproject. We'll keep you posted.

 

 

What is LIQUID?

LIQUID, founded in 2007, consists of a group of artists from various genres (visual art, music, dance, spoken word, hip hop, and drama). Through relatable and compelling storytelling we inspire youth to discover their passions and seek their purposes in life. Additionally, we teach mediums of visual and performing arts to youth that usually are not exposed to them at a professional level. Ultimately, we share core values like character, commitment, goal-setting/achieving and teamwork. 

 

The Challenge:

Arts programs continue to be cut from schools across the nation. It’s no coincidence that many youth seem to be disconnected, apathetic, and have a hard time finding purpose transitioning into adulthood. Utilizing the arts, LIQUID programs and workshops have been successful at helping to bring core values, passion and purpose to youth. Our community partners across the United States and abroad have requested our support in their local areas. In the past, we’ve donated our time and resources with a good measure of success. But now, the demand for our services have outgrown our ability to meet these needs on our own.

 

The LIQUID Project:

In a nutshell, here’s the One Year plan for The LIQUID Project:  We are setting up satellite workshops in several areas including Southern California, the San Francisco Bay Area, Chicago, and Washington D.C (to name a few). We plan to systematically go from city to city to teach youth fundamental art disciplines and train teams of mentors to continue the process as we move to the next city. The culmination of this project will result in a national stage production that brings youth from all over the country to perform together with the LIQUID team.

 

The Specifics:

We’re raising $150,000 to help ease the burden of carrying this very monumental, yet doable project alone. Your support goes directly toward purchasing art supplies, stage equipment, and paying stipends to the many artists who routinely continue to give of themselves without regard to compensation. Additionally, your gift will help us transport our gear around the country.

 

 

Other Things You Can Do to Help:

Please share The LIQUID Project with your friends and family in person and on social networks. Every donation helps. We’ve made a significant impact amongst youth on our own. With your support we’ll make an even greater, more significant impact. Thanks for your support.

story:
Pins for Swizz

Welcome to Pins for Swizz! We are Kodi Sershon and Willow Hayes: Proud pet-parents of Swizzle, who is (and we don't mean to brag) the best dog. Several months ago, Swizzle partially tore her ACL which is a ligament in her back knee. We've been doing our best to help Swizzle during this time but our vet has informed us a TPLO surgery is needed very soon and is the only way to fix the problem permanently.

We believe that Swizzle deserves to live her best doggy life and we want her back out there chasing balls, going on hikes, and running frantically in circles when the mood strikes her. Basically, all things she hasn't been able to do since the injury.

 

$$$

Unfortunately, the TPLO procedure is expensive. Like, $5,000+ expensive! Yikes!

Fortunately, Swizzle is a pretty darn likeable dog and many of Swizzle's friends have asked if we're going to set up a GoFundMe so that they can contribute and help out. Since we're both visual designers, it seemed appropriate that instead of fundraising in the classic sense of bake sales or car washes we could use our unique skills to set up something a little more fun. 

This is a flexible funding campaign. That means the campaign will fund whether or not we reach our goal. We set the goal for the estimated cost of the surgery. 

 

Pins

So, here we arrive at Pins for Swizz! We've each designed an enamel pin in our own unique styles to raise money for Swizzle's surgery. 

Willow's Swizzoro pin, based on a character from Swizzle's favorite Japanese children's film. This pin is 1.25" tall, 5 colors, with a gold finish. Hard enamel.

Kodi's Swizz Vibes pin, for the fashionably hip. This pin is 1.25" tall, black on metallic silver. Hard enamel.

 

Logistics

 

What happens if you don't meet this fundraising goal? 

We're getting this surgery either way! We still want Swizzle to live her best dog life. It's just a matter of how much debt we'll be in after.

How much money from a pin goes to Swizzle's surgery?

Obviously as much as possible, but it depends on how many we sell! Here are some of the production costs:

Producing 50 of each pin will cost $350, that's around $3 per pin at this low quantity. If we make 100 of each design that's down to $2 a pin.  Indiegogo also charges around 8% in fees for the fundraiser and to collect money from debit cards.

So if we sell 50 of each pin that's $1,030 in the Swizzle fund. $10.30 per pin. 

100 of each pin? $2,340 in the Swizzle fund with each pin raising $11.70. 

Why pins? Why not just ask for money? 

Because pins are awesome, and Swizzle pins are even better! We aren't going to ask for money without giving you something in return. You get a cool pin, we get help paying for Swizzle's surgery, everyone's happy! :)

 

Spread the word! #pinsforswizz

Short on cash right now? No worries! We'd love it if you could spread the word and share this fundraiser with anyone who might be interested by using the hashtag #pinsforswizz on your favorite social media platform. Thank you!

story:
An Introduction

My name is Bridget Ahearn, and I've been making one-of-a-kind hand painted pieces of vintage clothing since 2011. The ultimate mission for Old Crow is to inspire empowerment in all people through these wearable pieces of art. I'd hope share the process of learning, growing, and coming to a place of self love. In a world that pushes agendas, fear, and impossible standards, I believe that art is important and vital to balance the scales. Music, paintings, cinema, these are the expressions that show us the most beautiful side of humanity.

My campaign goal is to raise enough money to have 90% of my inventory screen printed. This would allow me to immediately fulfill my orders, provide a range of sizes for each design, making my pieces more affordable. All of the orders would be screen printed locally in St. Petersburg, FL by Trinity Graphics.

I plan to purchase and convert a Sprinter Van into a mobile shop. The Sprinter Van is a long-time dream of mine that would expand my network of customers and collaborators. I'll include my favorite locally-owned brands to broaden to the mission of the Van.

Goals

My target goal is $100,000.

Use of Funds: $70,000 to purchase and convert the Sprinter Van and $30,000 dedicated to screen printing jackets, tee shirts, and panties.

I've hand painted every single piece for Old Crow over the last 8 years. As my business expands, it's become a challenge to produce these orders by hand. The screen printed line would allow me to supply this demand. 

As for the mobile shop, here's the break down of the costs involved in purchasing and converting the Sprinter Van.

SPRINTER VAN: $59,770

SOLAR : $1200

ELECTRICAL: $1400

LIGHTS: $200

INSULATION: $500

WOOD: $500

KITCHEN: $2300

TOOLS: $280

HARDWARE: $350

DECOR: $200

COUCH: $150.00

FLOORS: $190

ACCESSORIES: $700

PAINT: $260

LABOR COSTS: $2000

PERKS

$15 donation- A pair of panties of your choosing

$33 donation- A t shirt of your choosing

$100 donation- A screen printed jacket of your choosing

$200 donation- A printed canvas of an original rendition major arcana tarot card of your choosing 

$1,000 donation- A custom hand painted vintage leather jacket

$5,000 donation- A hand painted ply wood 2x4 of an original rendition major arcana tarot card of your choosing 

$10,000 donation- 1 of each of the perks offered above and a gureenteed Sprinter Van stop and tour in your city

The Impact

Old Crow has been a constant source of purpose for me. In the darkest times, I've always been able to express myself fully through art. The therapeutic process of making art is a major crutch but the experience of sharing that art with others is hands down the most fulfilling part. I cannot express how much this project has changed me as a person. To be so lovingly received vis-a-vis my creations has given me confidence, self esteem and a certain something that there are no words to describe. Thank you all from the bottom of my heart for enjoying and supporting my creations.

My mission in life is to support people in the same ways that I've been supported. This opportunity to have a shop of my own to highlight other artists and small businesses is the open door I've been hoping for. 

I have supported myself and kept my business afloat for 8 years. I. know its time to take a step forward, and that this is all possible with the help of friends and strangers alike who feel that art is extremely important for reasons that are obvious and reasons that can be felt easier than expressed.

Risks & Challenges

After spending 8 years building this business on my own, the vulnerability of allowing others to contribute to its success on this level has been exhilarating. At this point, striking out in a van would force Old Crow to grow in so many ways. In addition to the growth of my business, it would help me reach and hopefully inspire/ be inspired by a wider audience. I would be challenged to further spread the love and expand the existing artistic community that Old Crow touches. 

Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.

I have put so much energy into my business that I understand the sacrifice and dedication it takes to overcome a challenge. I’ve also learned that with personal growth comes fresh creative energy that I can pour back into my designs. Stretching myself and my business to include screen printing and a mobile shop is a way to keep evolving as an artist and a business owner. 

Other Ways You Can Help

The fact that you've read this far means so much to me. If you're not in a position to contribute financially, but still want to help, please share this campaign via your social media, email or text. Every little bit helps. Each time you spread the word to another person this chain gets longer and the longer the chain the more support this campaign will receive. Thank you for being here and being a part of this journey.

Gratitude

Major thank you to Cat Coule for interviewing me and filming my campaign video. I'm so grateful for you, Cat.

Thank you to all of the photographers who have worked with me and who have allowed me to use their brilliant work in this campaign. Mike Valenzuela, Courtney Walker, Danielle Blonkenfeld, Becka and Kaylin Amabile. Also, thank you for all of the gorgeous women who've modeled for Old Crow and are in the launch video above. 

Thank you to Emily Norton and Brigette Black for helping me with the writing portion of this campaign. 

Big shoutout to my family and friends for being so incredibly encouraging and supportive throughout this entire process.

story:
2019 BEST YEAR OF MY LIFE!

                           JUST FINISHED FULFILLING A BOOK I POURED MY HEART INTO. 

                           BLACK FOREST WAS TOUGH. SO I DECIDED TO DO A SORT OF EXPERIMENT.

                           WILL THEY JUST LOOK AT MY ART AND THATS IT? I HOPE SO. THIS BOOK WILL BE A SKETCHBOOK/SHOWCASE OF MY WORK IN ALPHABETICAL ORDER. ITS SEXY SCARY CREEPY TRIPPY WEIRD. AND ALL SORTS OF OTHER THINGS. I KNOW YOU'REGONNA LOVE IT.

story:
Je suis un autodidacte en photographie depuis plus de dix ans. Depuis les débuts, l'Islande m'attirait pour ses paysages et sa culture. J'ai réalisé mon premier voyage photo dans ce pays en août 2015. Pendant ce voyage, un nouveau rêve m'est venu à l'idée; exposer mes photos en Islande. Ce rêve arrive six mois plus tard avec une invitation à une exposition de groupe à Djúpavík dans le nord-ouest du pays, dans les magnifiques fjords. À ce que je sache, je suis le premier canadien à exposer à cet endroit qui est très populaire auprès des touristes qui veulent sortir des sentiers battus.

Cette campagne de socio-financement m'aidera à la préparation de l'exposition et d'y participer en personne pour pouvoir échanger avec les autres artistes internationaux.  En échange, les donateurs peuvent choisir une photographie imprimé de leur choix à l'aide des contrepartie (Perks) à droite de cette page.

L'impression des photos doit se faire sur un médium durable pour les conditions environnementales particulières de la galerie (froid et humide). 

Le montant souhaité est de 6000 $. Ceci couvrira l'impression des photos (15 à 20) et à payer mon déplacement. Pendant mon séjour, je prévois faire de la photo pour alimenter mon portfolio sur l'Islande pour en faire une exposition dans la Péninsule acadienne à l'été ou l'automne 2016.

Même si le montant de 6000 $ n'est pas atteint, je vais quand même exposer mes œuvres en Islande. Seul le séjour sera affecté. 

Vous pouvez consulter les photos de mon voyage sur Facebook à l'adresse suivante https://www.facebook.com/jlp.islande ou jeromelucpaulin.com

Faites circuler dans vos médias sociaux préférés et merci de votre appui! :-)

canadien à exposer à cet endroit qui est très populaire auprès des touristes
qui veulent sortir des sentiers battus.
Cette campagne de socio-financement m'aidera à la préparation de
l'exposition et d'y participer en personne pour pouvoir échanger avec les
autres artistes internationaux.  En échange, les donateurs peuvent choisir une photographie imprimé de leur choix à l'aide des contrepartie (Perks) à droite de cette page.
L'impression des photos doit se faire sur un médium durable pour les
conditions environnementales particulières de la galerie (froid et humide). 
Le montant souhaité est de 6000 $. Ceci couvrira l'impression des photos (15
à 20) et à payer mon déplacement. Pendant mon
séjour, je prévois faire de la photo pour alimenter mon portfolio sur l'Islande pour en faire
une exposition dans la Péninsule acadienne à l'été ou l'automne 2016.
Même si le montant de 6000 $ n'est pas atteint, je vais quand même exposer
mes œuvres en Islande. Seul le séjour sera affecté. Vous pouvez consulter les photos de mon voyage sur Facebook à l'adresse suivante https://www.facebook.com/jlp.islande ou jeromelucpaulin.com

Faites circuler dans vos médias sociaux préférés
et merci de votre appui! :-)

story:
Short Summary

Art For Action is an international community arts initiative, established in 2012. Through each project we outreach to diverse, marginalised communities and give them a platform for expression. We use art as a medium for raising awareness about ever increasing international humanitarian issues.

The film above was made in  Colombia in 2015. 

Mural painted in Iraq refugee camp with Syrian children 2014.  


OUR NEXT STOP IS TANZANIA! 

Spring 2016

Amongst all the African Countries, Tanzania is the most peaceful but also the  poorest. 

While we are there we will focus on raising awareness about: 

*The 500,000 street children living in Tanzania

*Health and sanitation to prevent spread of the recent cholera epidemic

*Pre and post natal care for women and children

*The barbaric limb decapitation of people with Albinism

We will be painting at least one wall for each issue, and each wall will be painted by a different group of women and children. 

Each wall will be in the most relevant site for that particular subject matter, therefore having the maximum impact for the surrounding communities.

THIS IS YOUR OPPORTUNITY TO BE PART OF THE FUNDING INITIATIVE FOR THIS ORIGINAL AND EFFECTIVE PROJECT.

MEET THE TEAM

The artists involved will be a combination Rose Illingworth, who is the founder of Art For Action, internationally acclaimed Cosmo Sarson from the UK, EnRisco, a graffiti artist, skater and skatepark builder who runs Skatejam.org and two artists from the well known WACHATA graffiti crew from Dar es Salaam and . The project will be photographed by Ali Dunn.

The artwork we create will leave a legacy not just in public spaces but a positive impact for the children and communities involved. 

Wall 1 & 2: We are collaborating with Art In Tanzania to produce the first stage of the project:  painting in the Tageta township and a local village. Here we will bring focus on two local medical issues: the cholera epidemic and the much neglected natal care for women and children.

While we are hosted by Art In Tanzania we will be provided translators, internship volunteers and two film makers from a local university.

Wall 3: During the second part of the project we will collaborate with Tanzania Skate Miracle to reach vulnerable children living in Dar es Salaam (the commercial capital) and painting a Street Art Mural within their own surroundings, initiated through their own voices and ideas for their future. 

Skateboarding and ART are both powerful forms of creativity and are not dependent on language. They are therefore both very successful when reaching out to the most vulnerable youth all over the world.

Wall 4: We will raise awareness about human rights violations towards albinos and the horrific limb mutilations carried out due to superstitious beliefs. 

Walls 5+ The team will paint as many walls with as many vulnerable children as possible. 

The children involved will have the opportunity of making artwork side by side talented and internationally acclaimed artists! 

Supporting workshops will consist of portraiture, photography and stencil work. 

Rose Illingworth, the founder for Art For Action, is a freelance artist with two young children who travel everywhere with her. She has been successfully running these projects since 2012 in places such as Iraq refugee camps, safe houses in Sri Lanka, slums in Colombia, schools in The Gambia, Bedouins in Mount Sinai and most recently Calais Refugee Camp. 

Augustine from Tanzania Skate Miracle says "I  help children using skateboarding. I believe there are so many children who shall be interested to join your program and it's great idea to use art to spread messages"

The whole project will be documented throughout. The photos and films will be exhibited back in the UK along with the local Tanzanians' artwork and the portrait paintings by Rose Illingworth.

Where Are We Going?  Mixed media on canvas. 100x 60cm

 A percentage of Rose's paintings sold goes straight back to the communities we worked with via our partnership organisations.

All those involved in helping fund this project will be able to come to the exhibition showcasing our work done in Tanzania!

FUNDING. If we raise the full amount we can fulfil all our aims. 
If we do not, we will not be able to pay Tanzanian artists, we will have a minimal amount of art materials and we will have less opportunity to work with  Tanzanian marginalised communities. Also we will be unable to cover all the issues we have raised.
However, we will be travelling to Tanzania on the budget we reach, and we will work hard to do as much as possible with the funds we have raised. 
If we exceed our target  the money will go towards the costs of the exhibition to be held later in 2016.
THANK YOU FOR BEING PART OF ART FOR ACTION'S TANZANIA PROJECT!
We hope you like our perks and look forward to meeting you at the future exhibition!
www.artforaction.co.uk
www.skatejam.org
www.artintanzania.org
www.tanzaniaskatemiracle.weebly.com
www.cosmosarson.com
If you are unable to donate, then please spread the word and share this campaign.
THANKYOU.

If you are unable to donate, then please spread the word and share this campaign.


THANKYOU.

story:
Why Fertilitree?

We wanted a symbol that represented the East Bay and incorporated this years Burning Man theme of Fertility.  Oakland is the largest city in the east bay so we took the Oak tree + Fertility = Fertilitree.  Plus it makes a cool structure that people can climb on and provides shade during the day.

Check out photos of the work in progress in the Gallery tab!

Who are the East Bay Burners?

A small but mighty group of Burning Man enthusiasts living anywhere in or near the East Bay.  We meet monthly for happy hours, we love to build art and many of us camp together.  We have such a good group that folks from the South Bay, SF and even Reno often come to our events!

Why do you need money if this is community produced art? 

Art is expensive to build!  While the labor is all-volunteer, materials are expensive and often have to be purchased new for safety reasons.  Additionally, we pay rent for the build site and heavy equipment usage, transportation, insurance, and the ever popular fuel to burn it!  Oh yeah, and postage to mail your cool perks to you!

What do I get for contributing? 

You get our love and appreciation, a chance to participate in bringing burnable art to the playa plus some cool perks.  And if you want more than one perk, all you have to do is contribute to more than one option!  Price points are low so go crazy!

How else can I get involved? 

Come to our monthly happy hours at NIMBY!  You can purchase our cool Fertiltree cups and other unique swag at our events.  Or, come join us on build days!  Or, join the on-playa team!  Or, come to one of our fundraising events that include movie nights, BBQ's and more!

Where can I get more info? 

Sign up for the East Bay Burners announce list by sending an email to eastbay-announce-subscribe@burningman.com AND join our Facebook page @ https://www.facebook.com/groups/EBBCORE/

story:
Artists don’t just occupy! We occupy and beautify.

On October 30th at 1pm, a group of visual and performance artists will come together  to creatively occupy a Privately Owned Public Space (POPS) in Midtown Manhattan. In solidarity with Occupy Wall Street artists will perform an urban intervention that will beautify the space and call attention to how deeply entangled the private and public spheres have become.


We invite you to participate in our action by donating to our supply budget. In order to create ephemeral, semi-permanent, or permanent works of art our artists will need:

  • Glue
  • Tape
  • Markers
  • Sharpies
  • Paints
  • Brushes
  • Rollers
  • Plastic Tarps

We want the community to be involved! Donate a little, or a lot. Bring some supplies to our project. (We especially need recyclables!) Spend some time with our artists as they create their works, and stick around to see the final product.


We'll announce the exact place in a later update! We look forward to seeing all you there.


(Photo of altar by David Shankbone - http://www.flickr.com/photos/shankbone/)

story:
Our Story

The indiExhibit is an online, nonprofit artisan community that has members from across the globe. We currently find two of our members in desperate need of financial assistance.


One of these members has been with us since we started back in 2009 with only a handful of members. She is a mother of three children and her husband has been out of work for over 6 months. They have resorted to selling their belongings to make ends meet. They are coming dangerously close to losing their home. This year will mark her children's second year without a Christmas.


Our second member is facing a hardship of a different nature, but needs our help all the same. This lady has a number of life threatening illnesses and her darling "fur child", a Chihuahua named "Pixie", has helped her through it all. Now Pixie is very ill herself, with several tumors and possibly cancer. The vet says that she needs surgery immediately, however the surgery is $1200 and there is just no money for it.


Since our group is more like a large global family rather than just a group of artists, our members have rallied together to help these ladies in every way that we can. Members from our group have donated their own artwork and products as 'gifts' for people who donate to help. Members of The indiExhibit are also using every social networking angle that we can to help spread the word and help our ladies in need.


The Impact

The impact of this fundraiser is pretty simple. Two families are in need, families just like ours, families with children. Not only will this fundraiser bring them the financial assistance that they need, it will also help bring them encouragement and hope--something that no amount of money can ever buy. Every dollar will be split 50/50 to each member, until the amount of Pixie's surgery has been funded, then every dollar will go to our other member in need.


What We Need & What You Get

We all know that the economy is down and everyone's wallets are a bit on the light side, so our members have created gifting perks starting at just a small $5 donation--less than you would spend on your lunch at McDonald's!


For a small $5 donation, you will receive your choice of a hand poured, indiExhibit designer lip balm, made with organic ingredients, in a 1 oz metal tin. Each balm was handmade by indiExhibit founder and CEO, Shannon Justice. Flavors/Scents include Black Cherry, Fresh Baked Cookie, Pumpkin Spice, Strawberry Smoothie, Bubble Gum, Marshmallow and Mint Chocolate Chip. Each lip balm has a label designed by one of our very own indiExhibit members. (when you make your pledge, please number your top flavor/scent choice from 1-7, with 1 being your first choice and 7 being your last. We will try to send your top flavor/scent, however if it is sold out, we will send the next choice on your list)




For a $8 donation, you will receive a beautiful "Ruby Red Slippers" Brooch designed by indiExhibit member, Pixie Design. The brooch is made from polymer clay with a sparkly glitter finish, and a silver plated brooch pin.


For a $10 donation, you will receive a set of five 5x7 Limited Edition art prints by indiExhibit member, Gothic Toggs. Each print is printed on heavy card stock in a super matte finish and will be signed, dated and numbered  so you know you are getting a genuine Gothic Toggs print.


For a $15 donation, you will receive your choice of two glass tile pendants, each on a 8" silver plated ball chain, featuring the whimsical fantasy designs of indiExhibit member, Hinterland Harmony OR an signed copy of the first book in the new "Fair Hero Series" "Much Ado About Russian" by indiExhibit member, Kerry Rockwood White.      


Each pendant is unique as they are all handcrafted by KLeigh E of Hinterland Harmony at time of pledge. Each pendant is created using non toxic glaze, glass tiles, glass cabochons, sterling silver plated ball chain necklaces and AANRAKU bails. Each work of art is printed on high quality photo paper for the pictures so they will be bright and vibrant.


Each 6x9 paper back book is signed by fantasy author Kerry Rockwood White and is sure to keep you on the edge of your seat, craving more!



For a $20 donation, you will receive a custom created crocheted Holiday Doll by indiExhibit member, Brianne's Basics. Each doll is lovingly hand made by Heather Crow Nelson of Brianne's Basics and is just as cute and cuddly as can be.


For a $25 donation, you will receive a hand sewn sketchbook created by indiExhibit member, Gothic Toggs. This hand sewn, heavy foam backed book is 6x6 inches and has it's own beaded ribbon bookmark. It has 22 unlined pages. Tabitha Jones of Gothic Toggs will personalize yours just for you. (an email will be sent to you from the designer after your pledge)



For a $30 donation, you will receive a customized "Zebra Print Teapot" Binder designed by indiExhibit member, Klassy Kitchens. This beautiful Avery brand 3-Ring binder includes full-bleed, photo-quality printing on the front, back and spine, as well as 4 pockets and can be used as a photo album or recipe book! (an email will be sent to you from the designer for customization purposes after your pledge)



For a $35 donation, you will receive a delicious cookie bouquet by indiExhibit member, Divine Cookie Designs. Each cookie is freshly baked and hand decorated for any occasion and are just as yummy as they are beautiful! 



For a $40 donation, you will receive a beautiful 10 inch Melamine plate featuring the beautiful slopes of Aspen, Colorado by indiExhibit member, Aspen Rose Arts. This lovely plate is vibrant with full-color printing, drop and break resistant, easy to clean and dishwasher safe. (NOTE: not microwave safe!!!)



For a $75 donation you will receive a gift certificate for a custom created OOAK (one of a kind) sculpture by indiExhibit member, The Freaks Factory. (a $150 value) Your prize will be hand sculpted by Steve Benson of The Freaks Factory using polymer resins. (email will be sent to you by the designer for customization purposes after your pledge)



For a $100 donation, you will receive a handmade Swarvoski Crystal and Sterling Rosary by indiExhibit member, Annette Aben. (photo unavailable at this time)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't pledge, you can also help out by sharing our fundraiser on Twitter, Facebook, MySpace, email, blogs, or the old fashion way--word of mouth! Any help that we get is soo appreciated by both the members, their families, and our indiExhibit family as a whole. Thank you so much!

story:
THIS PROJECT has been POSTPONED until late this Fall or Winter, when I will have time to go for 2-3 months.  As suggested by funders, I will open a separate "Buenos Aires Tango, Tango, Tango" account and put the money raised here away for my return to the "Mecca" of tango. 

I do still plan to do a US Book/Tango Tour (mid-April-June 2012).  Thank you for your support!


My Story

Since before I knew how to write, I â€œwroteâ€ stories in pink-paged notebooks. 20 years later, that passion met tango. After taking a one-year leave from my job as an 8th Grade Language Arts (English) teacher in Seattle in 2008 to volunteer in the mountains of PerÃº and meeting tango along my travels around South America, my life changed completely. I was compelled to write, and write I did. After nearly 2 years of writing "moments" - on napkins, short one-paragraph Word Documents, poems, unsent text messages - and a chance encounter with a man who was finishing his Uruguay por el Mundo (Uruguay Around the World) trip who encouraged me to publish stories about my own travels, I realized that those pieces of writing I had been collecting were a book. Since then, the ideas bombarded me - I could barely keep up!

I spent the first part of 2011 finishing my collection/writing phase, organizing, revising, and editing my thoughts and learning a great deal about what it takes to format a book, design a cover, and self-publish. The resulting book, When 1+1=1: That "Impossible" Connection, is a journey through my memoir of getting know tango and myself, of learning about human interactions from my experiences on the dance floor.

My goal now is to get it out there and share it with the public, to not stand in the way of the book's success. I birthed this book and - like children - it has taken me and pushed me way outside my comfort zone. I feel I owe it to my book to do what I can to spread the message, that life is about connecting with one another.

My first improvised tour took me to Europe on a leap of faith, with little more than a box of books. Thanks to the support of gracious friends - old and new - I made my way from tango event to tango event, visiting 13 cities in 8 countries.

Next on my agenda to continue this work of getting my book out there, is a trip back to my "tango home" of Buenos Aires, the "Mecca" of tango, where I will reconnect with teachers, mentors, and friends who helped shape me over the last 3 years, promote my book and translate it into Spanish. To make this happen, especially on this short funding timeline (I just heard about IndieGoGo last week), I could really use your help.


The Impact

I believe that once you make art public, it's out there for people to interpret and interact with. The responses to my book have been inspirational and that is what fuels me to keep at this work of spreading the word, spreading the idea that we all could use a hug. Like keeping a painting in your basement, if no-one knows about it, it goes nowhere â€“ itâ€™s impact stops there. With your help, this will not be the case and the distribution of When 1+1=1 will go far beyond the 450+ books that are out in the world now. With your help, I will be able to expand the reach of my book to Buenos Aires and to Spanish speakers throughout the world; the impact of your contribution is limitless.


What I Need To Make It Happen & What You Get

With your support, I will get myself and my books to Buenos Aires. More specifically, I will:

- print 200 more copies
- pay shipping and customs fees
- purchase a ticket from Seattle to Buenos Aires and back, stopping through New York to plan for my U.S. Book/Tango Tour (my next project, April-June 2012)

I greatly appreciate your support and am excited to offer some unique perks to help entice you: photos from milongas (tango events) in Buenos Aires, a postcard from Buenos Aires, exclusive excerpts from my book, autographed copies of my book, a yerba mate and empanada merienda party, and even a chance to add tango to your next party!


Other Ways You Can Help

Writing the book was a big DIY (Do It Yourself) project, especially financially. Now that it's published, Iâ€™m ready to DIWO (Do It With Others) and to ask for help. No contribution is too small! Your help spreading the word is a huge help, too! Please pass the link/webpage to this project and/or to my book (www.gabrielacondrea.com) via email, Facebook, Twitter, Biznik, Linked-In, through word of mouth, as a conversation starter, ice-breaker, fun trivia fact, and the list of possibilities goes on and on... Thank you! Thank you!
story_txt:
THIS PROJECT has been POSTPONED until late this Fall or Winter, when I will have time to go for 2-3 months.  As suggested by funders, I will open a separate "Buenos Aires Tango, Tango, Tango" account and put the money raised here away for my return to the "Mecca" of tango.  

I do still plan to do a US Book/Tango Tour (mid-April-June 2012).  Thank you for your support!


My Story
Since before I knew how to write, I â€œwroteâ€ stories in pink-paged notebooks.  20 years later, that passion met tango.  After taking a one-year leave from my job as an 8th Grade Language Arts (English) teacher in Seattle in 2008 to volunteer in the mountains of PerÃº and meeting tango along my travels around South America, my life changed completely.  I was compelled to write, and write I did.  After nearly 2 years of writing "moments" - on napkins, short one-paragraph Word Documents, poems, unsent text messages - and a chance encounter with a man who was finishing his Uruguay por el Mundo (Uruguay Around the World) trip who encouraged me to publish stories about my own travels, I realized that those pieces of writing I had been collecting were a book.  Since then, the ideas bombarded me - I could barely keep up!
I spent the first part of 2011 finishing my collection/writing phase, organizing, revising, and editing my thoughts and learning a great deal about what it takes to format a book, design a cover, and self-publish.  The resulting book, When 1+1=1: That "Impossible" Connection, is a journey through my memoir of getting know tango and myself, of learning about human interactions from my experiences on the dance floor.  
My goal now is to get it out there and share it with the public, to not stand in the way of the book's success.  I birthed this book and - like children - it has taken me and pushed me way outside my comfort zone.  I feel I owe it to my book to do what I can to spread the message, that life is about connecting with one another.
My first improvised tour took me to Europe on a leap of faith, with little more than a box of books.  Thanks to the support of gracious friends - old and new - I made my way from tango event to tango event, visiting 13 cities in 8 countries.

Like keeping a painting in your basement, if no-one knows about it, it goes nowhere â€“ itâ€™s impact stops there.  With your help, this will not be the case and the distribution of When 1+1=1 will go far beyond the 450+ books that are out in the world now.  With your help, I will be able to expand the reach of my book to Buenos Aires and to Spanish speakers throughout the world; the impact of your contribution is limitless.



What I Need To Make It Happen & What You Get
With your support, I will get myself and my books to Buenos Aires.  More specifically, I will:
- print 200 more copies
- pay shipping and customs fees
- purchase a ticket from Seattle to Buenos Aires and back, stopping through New York to plan for my U.S. Book/Tango Tour (my next project, April-June 2012)

Your help spreading the word is a huge help, too! story:
THIS IS A FIXED FUNDED GOAL - IF THIS CAMPAIGN DOES NOT MAKE ITS GOAL, YOU GET YOUR MONEY BACK!

My name is Albert and I'm an artist.  When I was young, all I wanted to do was draw comicbooks.  During college I got that chance, but I worked on books that weren't my own.  In those days before computers and the internet boomed, aspiring comicbook artists looking to make a living were stuck doing other people's stories and books.

Now there's the internet, and imaging software, and digital DRAWING TOOLS! Now is an opportunity to draw and tell stories that I've always wanted to tell with an open and free distribution network that is the internet. All I need is the Intuos 5 Pen Tablet (http://www.wacom.com/en/products/intuos.aspx)  I'm a capable artist and I've used an Intuos before though not my own.  It allows me to draw digitally as if I were using traditional pen and ink.

I'm passionate about art and helping other artists.  The Intuos 5 will help me  communicate in the best way I know how...visually!

 

What I Need & What You Get

I need $500 to purchase the Intuos5.  The actual cost is about $442 on Amazon at the moment but with Indiegogo fees the total cost brings it up to $500.  As I stated earlier, this is a FIXED FUNDED campaign.  So it's all or nothing, if I don't achieve my goal then you get your money back!

If I achieve my goal, the Intuos 5 will be my single most cherished art tool!  I would be so ECSTATIC to create art everyday!  If by chance I achieve MORE than my goal, I can either give you your money back or deliver on the appropriate perk you contributed through or reinvest that money into other Indiegogo projects that support art.  

To all my campaign contributors you will be the recipient of the following perks (all of which will be created using the Intuos 5 pen tablet):

  • $1 - UNIQUE SKETCH JUST FOR YOU! - This will be a digital line drawing.  The subject matter will be up to my discretion but if you leave a note with your contribution, I may do something with it.  The final product will be like a surprise ;)

  • $10 - BASIC CARICATURE - This will be a black and white digital drawing of any one person of your choosing.  I can work off photographs.  (SIDENOTE: I was a caricature artist at Disney World and Disney World Resorts for 8 years, 1998-2006)

  • $20 - BASIC COMMISSION - This will be a black and white professional level digital drawing of any one character.

  • $50 - COLORED COMMISSION OR CARICATURE - One character or caricature in FULL COLOR digital art!

  • $100 - FULL SCENE COLORED COMMISSION with MULTIPLE CHARACTERS/CARICATURES and ELABORATE BACKGROUND - This is a fully rendered and dynamically composed piece of digital art.

If you are an appreciator of art, this won't be the only time you see me and my work.  You can see the fruits of your contributions continue through my posts on my deviantart portfolio at http://holaso.deviantart.com   Also all contributors, if interested will be alerted to my future works as I venture into the exciting world of self publishing!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may want to support my campaign but don't have the funds yourself, you can CERTAINLY help by making some noise and using Indigogo's SHARE tools to spread the word about my campaign.

 Have a good day!

- Albert
