story:
On August 15, Animals for Africa-Love Made Tangible will send three artists/educators to Africa to deliver over 200 lovingly hand-crafted stuffed animals made by citizens of the world for orphaned and vulnerable children in Malawi and Uganda.  During our four week stay, we will facilitate a variety of art education and artisan training programs with women, children and youth to seed economically empowering crafting cooperatives in impoverished communities.

 

Animals for Africa was born in Malawi in May, 2011 in response to the suffering and poverty I witnessed first hand while traveling with a group of wise women writers. As an artist/educator, I searched my soul for a creative way to respond to the heart-breaking stories of poverty, globalization and HIV/AIDS I heard and witnessed first hand on my journey.

  

One rainy afternoon, a few weeks into my trip, on a mountain in Livingstonia, I was moved to craft a little stuffed zebra doll for a 9 year-old orphaned girl I'd met named Witty.  I was haunted by Witty because she’d seemed so devastatingly sad and lonely. As I hand-stitched her name onto my little zebra creation, I realized I was infusing it with all the love and compassion I felt for her and all the other vulnerable women and children I'd met along the way.

My spontaneous “animal crafting” inspired my co-travelers as well, and soon they were not only creating their own animals to give to the orphaned children, we were detouring back to Tukombo Village to teach the women there how to make them - as a way to learn and practice practical craft-making skills. 

A few months after my return to the United States, I officially launched Animals for Africa-Love Made Tangible and since then, dozens of caring and compassionate citizens have happily hosted "Animal Art Parties," recruiting friends and raising funds to support the mission and vision. 

The original crafting cooperative in Tukombo has taken root and the women continue to meet weekly to make animals. Already, they have earned $350, a substantial amount considering that over 90% of Malawians live on less than $750 a year! With funds earned through their own creative efforts, the women were able to reinvest in more crafting materials for the cooperative, provide a bit more food for their own families and to purchase school uniforms for seven of the orphaned children in their village so they could attend primary school.  

With your support, we will be able to return to Malawi to develop and nurture the social enterprise we planted in Tukombo Village last May and to also seed several more crafting cooperatives through collaborations with the HALO Foundation and In Movement: Art for Social Change in Uganda. 

We have already receive a small grant from Art4Moore which will help pay for some crafting materials and lodging while in Africa for 4 weeks. We need to raise $15,000 more to cover plane tickets for three artist/educators to travel from San Francisco to Malawi, from Malawi to Uganda and from Uganda back to San Francisco.  We also need funds to cover ground transportation, meals and other travel related expenses.  Plus, we'd love to bring additional crafting supplies to leave for women and youth to continue developing their crafting cooperatives.

Additional donations will support the ongoing Animals for Africa mission-to economically empower people through creativity, connection and love by bringing citizens of the world together to create simple, folk-art inspired stuffed animals for vulnerable children in need and to seed sustainable social enterprises through artisan training.

 

We are  committed to fostering community and connection through grass-root crafting circles, art education, workshops and presentations with socially conscious collaborators and organizations, like CERI (The Center for Empowering Refugees and Immigrants), Soroptimists International and Kansas City Kansas Community College. 

Our long-range vision is to expand our artisan training and animal crafting campaigns to other countries and continents, to make more love tangible around the world.   

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

If you can't donate money as love, you can stilll help in many other incredibly impactful ways! You can become an "ambassador" simply by helping us spread the word about our mission and vision!

Please repost our campaign on facebook or resend through email to your family, friends and colleagues! 

You can also host an "animal crafting party" and help us by recruiting your friends to make animals for orphans and raise donations to seed crafting cooperatives in the impoverished communties that care for these children.

You can donate fabric and other crafting materials, or, if you are a Bay Area local, you can donate your time- by helping us pack up and ship our animal crafting kits.

And you can always show us your love by signing up for our newsletter and/or by  liking us on facebook!

We'd love to hear from you by email, too!

story: I, SANDRA WITHROW-ORR, AM A FREELANCE WRITER AND POET, GREETING CARDS WRITER OF â€œSUCI LOVEâ€™S GREATEST GIFT CHRISTIAN GREETING CARDSâ€, E-BOOK AUTHOR, WORSHIP LEADER, PSALMIST, SINGING SONGS OF DELIVERANCE, SONG WRITER, AND RECORDING ARTIST, MY DEBUT CD â€œDWELLING PLACEâ€ CAME OUT IN 2002, AND INCLUDED WITH THE BOOK-YOU SAY IT IS HARD BEING SING, SAVED, SANCTIFIED IT CAN BE DONE. THE NEW SINGLE â€œI SLIP INTO HIS PRESENCEâ€. I AM ALSO WORKING ON THE COMPLETE ALBUM I SLIP INTO YOUR PRESENCE. I AM A NATIVE OF BEREA, OHIO. I WAS RAISED WITH 2 BROTHERS AND 1 SISTER WITH CYCSTIC FIBROSIS A HORRIBLE DESEASE WITH NO CURE. GROWING UP WITH THIS AND ALL OF THE PAINS OF A MARRIAGE IN 1973 AND DIVORCE IN 1978 I ONLY MADE IT BY FALLING MADLY IN LOVE WITH THE KING OF KINGS AND THE LORD OF LORDS. YOU CAN NOT MAKE IT WITHOUT GOD. WHEN MY SISTER DENISE DIED IN 2002 GOD GAVE ME GREETING CARDS. I STARTED WRITING THEM OUT OF THE COMFORT OF THE LORD. I HAVE ALWAYS BEEN A CARD SENDER. THIS AND ENCOURAGE SOME SO THEY CAN MAKE IT ANOTHER DAY. IN 2007 THE LORD GAVE ME A BOOK IN MY SEASON OF SINGLENESS. THIS WAS TO ENCOURAGE SINGLES AS WELL AS MYSELF THAT IF YOU STAY IN HIS PRESENCE, WORD, AND PRAYER THEN YOU CAN GO THROUGH YOUR SINGLENESS, SAVED, SANCTIFED WHILE YOU WAIT FOR GOD TO MOVE TO SEND THAT SPECIAL SOMEONE IN YOUR LIFE. I MARRIED IN 2008, 2009 MY STEP DAUGHTER GOT CANCER. SHE WAS 28 YEARS OLD. ON OCTOBER 14, 2010 SHE WENT HOME TO BE WITH THE LORD. IN MARCH 2011 GOD GAVE ME A SONG I SLIP INTO YOUR PRESENCE. IN JULY 2011, I WAS LAYED OFF FROM MY JOB. DURING THIS TIME OF MY LIFE THE LORD HAS BEEN PUSHING ME DEEPER IN HIS ARMS AND MINISTRY. I NEED THE FUNDS TO MARKET BOOK, PUBLISH GREETING CARDS, PRODUCE VIDEO FOR THE SINGLE, AND BUY PRODUCT FOR ALL OF THE PROJECTS. I KNOW THAT THE BOOK, SINGLE, GREETING CARDS ARE GOING TO MINISTER AND HELP A LOT OF PEOPLE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED THE SAME THINGS. THERE IS NOBODY GREATER THAN GOD AND I WANT TO TELL THE WORLD. IN THE BOOK I TALK ABOUT THE STRUGGLES OUR FAMILY HAD WITH CYCSTIC FIBROSIS. I HAD TO STAY IN GODâ€™S PRESENCE , EVERYDAY WHILE GOING THROUGH THIS IN MY SEASON OF SINGLENESS. CYCSTIC FIBROSIS IS SUCH A HORRIBLE DISEASE. I PRAY THAT A CURE IS FOUND SO THAT OUR CHILDREN CAN STOP SUFFERING. OUR FAMILY HAS HAD SO MUCH HAPPINESS, BUT 2 GREAT LOSSES FROM THIS DISEASE. WE ALSO BEAT THE ODDS MY OLDER BROTHER IS 59 YEARS OLD RETIRED AFTER OVER 36 YEARS WORKING AS A DRIVER FOR UPS. HE IS A WALKING MIRACLE. THANK YOU FOR HELPING ME FUND, THE BOOK, SINGLE, CHRISTIAN GREETING CARDS, MARKETING, AND VIDEO.

story:
Edit - Campaigning continues here: http://igg.me/p/91969?a=261456 . Thank You!


My Story

Current Predicament:

I'm a 4th year BFA Illustration student at Edna Manley College, Jamaica, and I'm bent on putting together the best Independent Study project that I can. Having been forced to defer in 2011 due to chronic illness, 2012 is set in stone (as far as I'm concerned) as my year to shine. Unfortunately, having to buy a new computer, as well as most of the outstanding bulk of art supplies, has taken a huge bite out of my savings, leaving me with limited funds to cover my printing, remaining art material, and exhibition costs. This, however, doesn't tell the story about why I felt moved enough to seek help via a campaign. Not by a long shot.


The First Spark:

The driving force behind my original children's book project was ignited waaaaaaaaaay back in my early childhood, living and growing up in Jamaica. I learned to read at an early age, and I loved it! Throw my budding art talent into the mix, and I'd spend my time creating stories in my head, and illustrating them in large pen strokes. That right there was my idea of fun - and still is! As young as I was, however, I couldn't help but notice that many of the story books available to Jamaican children were mostly from North America, or the UK, and I really couldn't help but notice that these stories rarely (if ever) had characters that I could relate to culturally or ethnically. My school books followed the same pattern and, save for primary school books I'd borrow from my Grandmother's neighbours during my summer vacation in the country, Jamaican or Caribbean children's stories were a very rare sight. Two decades later, the situation is slowly improving and I'm finally in a position where I can contribute to the change. To do this, however, I'm going to need a lot of support.


The Impact

Source: LangiSketches



With very few Jamaican characters and printed stories available during my own childhood, I aim to make a different memory for current and future generations of young Jamaicans. I want child readers, and their caregivers alike, to be able to bond with young Charlene as she journeys through her own childhood with her trusted friends by her side. I'd like to spark the imaginations of many, especially the young, and encourage them to tell their own stories; to create their own worlds framed by their Jamaican and Caribbean identities. Additionally, I hope to showcase Jamaican culture nationally, regionally, and internationally as best as I possibly can. A third minor yet important aim for my project is to help break the firm local belief that art, particularly illustrative art, has limited applications and is an unwise career choice for young Jamaicans. As a people, we are known the world over for our creativity and our vibrant culture, and the long-help concept of the 'starving artist' has been one of the many stumbling blocks to our national development. My contribution may seem miniscule, a mere drop in the bucket, but it will be one that I will be proud and driven to make.


What I Need & What You'll Get

Pulling it all together requires purchasing outstanding art supplies (such as screen printing materials, and a few minor items), having items printed (e.g. signage, and merchandise), sourcing and buying materials for my display area, and covering installation costs(such as electrical wiring, painting, transportation, etc). I've established a goal of $2,000 USD (approx. $173,400 JMD) to cover the necessities, as well as to provide a modest contingency budget (in case *knocks wood* something tremendous occurs). If you look over to the right of my campaign page, you'll see a list of Perks awarded per donation amount - all featuring illustrations from my Independent Study. No matter how big, or how small, you're guaranteed a 'thank you' for helping me. Sweet, eh?

In this first phase of my project's plan (i.e. graduating from Edna Manley College), I wish to present a top-notch project for my final exam in May 2012 and student exhibition in June 2012. Should I not raise all the necessary funds here on IndieGogo, I will still continue on with my project, of course; I will just have to make adjustments to my productions - e.g., pare down elements in my exhibition - in order to fit within my budget. Either way, the show must go on! This is a project that I believe in wholeheartedly, and will see it to fruition one way or another.

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to donate? Not a problem! This recession has been beating most of us, so I understand completely. You can still help by spreading word of my campaign among your favourite haunts on the internet as well as your friends/family. Either way, you'll be helping an enthusiastic, ambitious (and broke!) student to end her final year on a very high note, and kick a worthwhile project off with a bang!

Quick Edit: My PayPal accepts US, Canadian, British, Australia, Euro, and Japanese currencies. I can't add Jamaican, though (boo =_=).
story_txt:
Edit - Campaigning continues here: http://igg.me/p/91969?a=261456 . Thank You!

My StoryCurrent Predicament:I'm a 4th year BFA Illustration student at Edna Manley College, Jamaica, and I'm bent on putting together the best Independent Study project that I can. Having been forced to defer in 2011 due to chronic illness, 2012 is set in stone (as far as I'm concerned) as my year to shine. Unfortunately, having to buy a new computer, as well as most of the outstanding bulk of art supplies, has taken a huge bite out of my savings, leaving me with limited funds to cover my printing, remaining art material, and exhibition costs. This, however, doesn't tell the story about why I felt moved enough to seek help via a campaign. Not by a long shot. The First Spark:The driving force behind my original children's book project was ignited waaaaaaaaaay back in my early childhood, living and growing up in Jamaica. I learned to read at an early age, and I loved it! Throw my budding art talent into the mix, and I'd spend my time creating stories in my head, and illustrating them in large pen strokes. That right there was my idea of fun - and still is! As young as I was, however, I couldn't help but notice that many of the story books available to Jamaican children were mostly from North America, or the UK, and I really couldn't help but notice that these stories rarely (if ever) had characters that I could relate to culturally or ethnically. My school books followed the same pattern and, save for primary school books I'd borrow from my Grandmother's neighbours during my summer vacation in the country, Jamaican or Caribbean children's stories were a very rare sight. Two decades later, the situation is slowly improving and I'm finally in a position where I can contribute to the change. To do this, however, I'm going to need a lot of support.The Impact

story:
Hello there! My name is Elise, and I am a printmaker, fresh Minnesota State University Moorhead BFA graduate, and Minnesota native currently located in Fargo, ND. I recently recived a scholarship to attend a class at Penland School of Craft in Penland, NC this summer. The class is a weeklong study into boxmaking for fine art books. I cannot express how excited I am to attend Penland, but I need a little help getting there. 

I plan to take my beloved 1995 Buick Regal, Sir Paul, on a roadtrip from Fargo, ND to Penland, NC, and then back up to Chicago, IL, where I will be relocating after my class to begin my art career. Sir Paul was once my Grandma's car, who loved to travel around the U.S. I'm taking him on one last roadtrip down to North Carolina, hitting at least five cities on the way down! 

 We wil depart from Fargo in late August, stopping in Madison, WI, Chicago, IL, DeKalb, IL, Knoxvillie, TN and ending of course in Penland, NC! Each city I will be stopping in has a graduate school or professional printmaking studio I will be touring in my pursuit of my Masters. 

 

The projected expenses for this two-week long trip break down like this:

Gas/Tolls:$600.00

Lodging: $120.00 (Need a place to rest my head in Madison, WI and Knoxvillie, TN)

Meals on the Road: $100.00

The remaining $80.00 on my $900.00 goal is budgeted to ship all of your sweet perks!

I have already (and very thankfully) been able to save the money I need for my class fees. I just need your help to get there and back again!

 

I am very excited to be able to bring you, the awesomest bunch of funders, some sweet perks, all made by my own two hands! I'm a firm believer in the beauty of the handmade, and can think of no better recipient for these gifts than all of you!

-All thank-you postcards, fine art prints, and thank-you notes will be printed/ written on fine art cotton rag paper and sent safely to your doorstep in quality packaging.

-Hand-bound sketchbooks will also be made from fine cotton rag paper, and bound with a strong waxed linen. 

-Cookies will be packaged and sent as soon as they are cooled in wax paper and a box!

-The scarves will be printed on cotton jersey fabric, with Drive-By Press's signature textile relief ink. The scarf will be completley washer/dryer safe and really neat!

 

I wish I could thank each one of you in person for your interest and support of my campaign. Attending this school has long been a dream of mine, and I could not be more excited for it. Your donation not only gets me to my class, it also helps me incredibly in my academic future. Getting to tour these schools all in one swoop is a rare gift!
 

  Thank you so much for your interest in my campagin! Please share this with anyone you think may be interested. Your help getting the word out is as important as your donations!

You can also view my website, Pulp, Press and Ink, and follow me on Instagram under the name ceramicbones to follow my roadtrip!

story:
Our Story

 

Our vision is to manifest a creative movement arts studio where we can teach various forms of therapuetic self expression using circus, improv dance, yoga and the flow arts as our platform. We also intend to create a homebase for the circus and performance art community in Raleigh where currently there is none. We believe these art forms are beautiful, empowering, and healing. Cirque de Vol Studios will provide a safe community atmosphere for folks from all walks of life to explore themselves, heal themselves, and express themselves through these art forms.

Our intention to create a home for dancers, movers, shakers and lovers of all forms of creative expression needs your help in getting our doors open.

 

These funds are needed to help with basic construction needs, aerial rigging, safety mats and flooring needed to operate.

 

A portion of the money raised in this campagin is allotted towards sending local at-risk youth to our Kid's Circus Summer Camps.

About Sara Phoenix, creator of Cirque de Vol Studios-

Sara Phoenix created Cirque de Vol Studios with her sister, affectionately nicknamed Sharebear, with the intention of combining her life passions into an inspiring community capable of fostering human growth through creative movement and circus arts.

She practices and performs hoop, aerial and fire dance in addition to yoga and  improv. She finds deep worth in practicing and sharing the meditative and healing joy that can be found in these art forms.

With her love of community and group-work, Sara Phoenix is the founder of Phoenix Rising Productions and initiated the formation of The Eclectic Circus Collective. She is also the Regional Director of the Triangle Vegetable Circus. Sara Phoenix has a bent for social justice and is most passionate about inspiring change through self work and the nurturing of  supportive communities. She loves children, laughter, and you!

Her goal is to work on the revitalization of Raleigh’s warehouse district while providing Raleigh’s circus, creative movement, and healing arts communities with a home to practice, teach, share and play in.

She believes that everyone has the power and potential to create a life they can truly love.

 
Our Intentions for Cirque de Vol Studios:

 

We intend to create meaningful living art performances.

We intend to awe our community with the magic of fire dance and aerial acrobatic performances.

We intend to empower folks by teaching these art forms in a safe community atmosphere.

We intend to encourage introspection, mindfulness and connection through improvisational dance.

We intend to encourage self awareness through the movement meditation found in yoga and the flow arts.

We intend to create community dance jams. A  family friendly space for folks to go dancing that is not a bar or nightclub.

We intend to encourage fitness through expressive movement.

We intend to teach the benefits of healthy living and eating using the circus arts through our own local chapter of the not for profit organization- The Vegetable Circus. (vegetablecircus.com)

The Impact

The type of impact Cirque de Vol Studios will have on our community is much needed. We plan to provide a new alternative to the community to express themselves creatively while cultivating healthy living skills. Circus arts help to improve both mental and physical health. Cirque de Vol Studios will be a place where folks can gather and support one another-it will be an awesome alternative to the gym, the bar or the playground that is completely new.We want to enchant our community by providing them with a chance to break free from stagnant routines with a fresh and unique new environment in which they can grow and interact with others through fitness, performance and play.

 

At Cirque de Vol, we recognize that the only way we can change the world is by first changing ourselves. We live to make life less difficult for each other. We live to create, and through our shared creative efforts, find communion and our home in the place of things. We recognize the interconnectedness of all beings and the important practice of empowering and inspiring eachother.

story:
“How can there be light that throws no shadows? There is no good that is not opposed by evil” – C.G. Jung

A shadow resides in each of us. Inspired by the work of psychologist and psychoanalyst, C.G. Jung, we explore the Shadow archetype through physical movement. Jung describes the “Shadow self” as something that consists of the negative expressions we avoid revealing others, and at times, ourselves. What we show the world, our Ego, is afraid of the capabilities of our Shadow and therefore suppresses it, ignoring that it is essential to who we are. Using dance as our medium, we invite what is buried to surface and compliment our light.

-----

femme. collective is a group of feminist-minded artists based in Philadelphia, PA. Formed in the summer of 2015, their aim is to bring more art and artist collaborations to the city through networking and showcase opportunities. The people of femme. collective continue to empower each other, support the artistic endeavors of their peers, and provide a platform for feminist-driven artists to collaborate in sharing their passions.

We invite you to collaborate on our project and mission. We are looking for your support of our annual dance performance for 2017. Please contribute to our campaign to allow femme.collective to continue networking Philadelphia artists and opportunities.

story:
Knowing from experience from our last three runs in August 2011-2013... August tends to roll around a lot quicker than expected. It never seems I have enough time in a year to prepare for these months. With all the prep work I do for every August, I've learned that it is never too early to prepare for August. During this time I sink all my energy to creating and capturing performances. I spend months prior to August coming up with unique innovative show concepts/ideas and I invest in better equipment. After all it's the month where a lot of my creative energy comes about. I am hoping to raise funds to prepare for the big month to afford equipment, and rent out a location where I will be creating in ways I am never able to.  This year I have even more planned, and even more creative ideas I am excited to execute than the last. If you are already a lover of my shows. Know that every little bit helps for purchasing equipment, software, props, and space. Any contributions big or small put into this campaign is deeply appreciated. In return, I will not disappoint in providing shows that will leave you in awe. My hopes is that by starting this campaign early, I will have a better chance to save up steadily and to reach these ideas that await to become my reality. I want to take you guys to new places, and share my passion for art through pushing the boundaries of what's possible in expression through live streaming performance art.

Thank you.
Joey Kim

story:
About Alchemy Art Labs

The idea for Alchemy Art Labs was born from Lauryl's desire to create a space in her community for artists who need support accessing affordable space outside of their own home, and an environment that will cultivate connections between artists in order for them to collaborate, develop skills and support each other through the professional artistic process. Alchemy Art Labs grew from there with the mission to support, educate, and enrich all humans through the arts. One of the ways Alchemy Art Labs plans to do this is to provide studio, gallery, retail, and educational space to the artist community and beyond. Artists, teachers, and students involved with the community will find new and creative solutions to the financial, logistical and emotional boundaries that come with being an artist. Alchemy Art Labs will also offer an inclusive and supportive environment for community members who do not necessarily consider themselves artistic but want to explore their creativity in a safe and group-oriented space. Alchemy Art Labs believes that every human is at the effect of creative impulses. By creating the space for creativity to flourish and feed, all humans will thrive in our community.  If you'd like more information about our business, scroll down!  


In order to successfully open Alchemy Art Labs we are hoping to raise all of the money for the initial costs of the business, as we are starting from nothing. This is asking a lot from the community, but we believe that the benefit of a community art space that is affordable and accessible to all will be well worth the investment.  Our Indiegogo campaign will cover our startup costs, but our first priority will be our space.  


The startup costs include rent, deposit, and utilities for our new space, as well as the buildout of tenant improvements.  We need services from many local professionals, including legal, financial, and tradespersons, which will be funded by donations, as well as ld industries.  We also need a myriad of supplies and materials in order to start offering the services we are planning to provide.   Alchemy Art Labs is committed to re-using, re-cycling, up-cycling, and buying second hand, everything that we can.  With an endeavor of this scale, we will need every bit of the campaign donations as well.   With space and materials available, we can very quickly gain financial self sufficiency.

Check out our fabulous perks, inspired by our passion for education, art journaling, and handmade goods!  

Hey, we know that not everyone can donate financially.  If you'd like to contribute services, time, or materials, please let us know!   Contact us at alchemyartlabs@gmail.com

Company Description:  

Alchemy Art Labs will provide studio, gallery, and educational space, while filling the gaps that are currently present in the creative community.  We will take the various artists, crafters, and experimenters, and pull them together under one roof.  We will draw on the successful model of co-working spaces, which are in high use in Boulder’s tech industries, in a creative setting.  There will be a focus on education for children and adults and a focus on artist professional development. The needs that will be addressed are:

Affordable and accessible options for artists to pursue their professional goals.

A venue to gather insight and direction in the artistic fields

A place for “non-artists” to pursue creative development in a safe and accessible way.

The reaching of a higher standard of supporting development at a young age.  We will reach beyond arts and crafts to teach full expression to clients of all ages and abilities.

A liaison and resource between current, more specified, arts businesses in Boulder County and beyond.


Mission Statement

Alchemy Art Labs is a social-based business invested in the support, education, and enrichment of all humans through the arts. Some of the ways we do this is to provide studio space, gallery space, retail space, and educational space to the artist community and beyond. Artists involved with us will find new and creative solutions to the financial, logistical and emotional boundaries, that come with being an artist. Every human is at the effect of creative impulses. By creating the space for creativity to flourish and feed, all humans will thrive in our community.



Vision Statement

Every human exposed to Alchemy Art Labs is greeted with compassion and guidance, and  their creative needs are fulfilled. All humans are exposed to support, education, space, beauty, depth, sustainability, growth, expansion, disruption of exhausted norms,  community, and inspiration.



Values Statement

We value support, community, and cooperation.  We think the necessities in our business, and in life, include:  love, listening, action, movement, growth, ease, beauty, intention, and learning. We value an approach that does not rely upon expected societal norms, and the established art culture. We are informal, but within boundaries that maintain our professionalism. Every member, regardless of their role, has the space to contribute and influence within the company. Profitability, through community action, is the driving force from which we generate growth, stability, and long term viability. 

We are each, and as a whole, responsible for our actions.

We are accountable for ourselves and our behaviors.  We act with integrity and courage, with conviction and intention, and we do what we say we will do.  We work together and act in solidarity with others to further our cause.  We think ahead, strategically.  We embrace fluidity and transparency in all aspects of our lives, business, and intentions.  We take an equal opportunity approach to art and the creative process.

Short Term Goals:

  • acquire funding for space, a build out, and 1 year of rent and utilities.

  • find a space

  • alter the space

  • recruit teachers to host classes

  • recruit clients

  • recruit artists to be involved

  • recruit artists to rent space

  • recruit artists to hang in gallery

  • identify revenue sources

  • acquire  funding for a part time sewing position for 1 year

  • acquire funding/donations for supplies/materials for 1 year

  • clearly define the roles of management as it evolves within the business



Long Term Goals

  • to be self sufficient, monetarily, by the end of the 1st year of operations

  • to hire a full time general manager during the first year of operations

  • to have the rentable studio space filled consistently

  • to have 3 to 5 classes happening per week

  • to have weekend workshops happen at least 2 weekends per month

  • to host 1 gallery event per month

  • to be able to pay a director salary after 1 year of operations


Reasons For Business


To promote art in our community in a way that values the artist and the creative process.

To provide low cost studio space for local artists in a supportive and inspiring environment.

To collaborate with and promote local artists through the gallery space and events.

To provide educational space for the community in a desirable environment.

To provide accessible classes for the community in a desirable environment.

To provide a community and event space in a desirable environment.

To provide support and resources in an area that is currently lacking.

  • Lauryl Danuff (Director)

    Background:

    • Professional Designation Degree in Fashion Design from The Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising, Los Angeles

    • Associate of Arts Degree from Front Range Community College, emphasis in art history and design

    • Employment within the arts, fashion and other businesses for 15 years.

      Own and operate ld industries Ltd., a custom housewares and fashion design production company in Boulder.

    • Held position as General Manager of a business for 5 years.  Managed team of 10 to 15 people, inventory, product management, customer service, HR, company direction and future, and day to day operations.  Organized and managed rotating gallery shows and events monthly.

    • Lauryl has experience building curriculum and hosting/teaching art for adults in collaboration with others.

    • Lauryl is involved with the planning, set-up and direction of all aspects of the business.

    • Lauryl will bring her knowledge of managing a business in combination with her long time work in the arts community to provide structure and operational knowledge to the business.  She will also use her position in the community to gather an artist/client/teacher support base to help the growth and sustainability of the business.



  • In the past 2 years, Lauryl has been laying the groundwork for this business by gathering her art community, building curriculum, hosting and teaching workshops, and putting together artist meet-ups and support groups.  All of these elements will be forwarded by, and will directly contribute to the mission and success of Alchemy Art Labs.

  • We are open to having more members who are aligned with the vision and values of Alchemy Art Labs.  


Management Structure


  • CU INVST Intern-team: The members are a part of the CU INVST program and are in their last year of their Bachelor degrees.

    • Kelley Anderson- B.S. in Humanities: Community and Social Development

    • Jessica Wambsgans- B.S. in Business: Business Consultant, doing business research and development

    • Sienna Dellephpiane- B.S. in Sociology: Marketing/Outreach and Network Coordination

  • Any business management will be under the direct control of Lauryl.

  • A General Manager will be hired who will be in control of day to day operations.

  • Staff members will be hired as needed and as funds are available.
story_txt:
About Alchemy Art Labs
The idea for Alchemy Art Labs was born from Lauryl's desire to create a space in her community for artists who need support accessing affordable space outside of their own home, and an environment that will cultivate connections between artists in order for them to collaborate, develop skills and support each other through the professional artistic process. Alchemy Art Labs grew from there with the mission to support, educate, and enrich all humans through the arts. One of the ways Alchemy Art Labs plans to do this is to provide studio, gallery, retail, and educational space to the artist community and beyond. Artists, teachers, and students involved with the community will find new and creative solutions to the financial, logistical and emotional boundaries that come with being an artist. Alchemy Art Labs will also offer an inclusive and supportive environment for community members who do not necessarily consider themselves artistic but want to explore their creativity in a safe and group-oriented space. Alchemy Art Labs believes that every human is at the effect of creative impulses. By creating the space for creativity to flourish and feed, all humans will thrive in our community.  If you'd like more information about our business, scroll down!  
In order to successfully open Alchemy Art Labs we are hoping to raise all of the money for the initial costs of the business, as we are starting from nothing. This is asking a lot from the community, but we believe that the benefit of a community art space that is affordable and accessible to all will be well worth the investment.  Our Indiegogo campaign will cover our startup costs, but our first priority will be our space.  The startup costs include rent, deposit, and utilities for our new space, as well as the buildout of tenant improvements.  We need services from many local professionals, including legal, financial, and tradespersons, which will be funded by donations, as well as ld industries.  We also need a myriad of supplies and materials in order to start offering the services we are planning to provide.   Alchemy Art Labs is committed to re-using, re-cycling, up-cycling, and buying second hand, everything that we can.  With an endeavor of this scale, we will need every bit of the campaign donations as well.   With space and materials available, we can very quickly gain financial self sufficiency.Check out our fabulous perks, inspired by our passion for education, art journaling, and handmade goods!  Hey, we know that not everyone can donate financially.  If you'd like to contribute services, time, or materials, please let us know!   Contact us at alchemyartlabs@gmail.com
Company Description:  
Alchemy Art Labs will provide studio, gallery, and educational space, while filling the gaps that are currently present in the creative community.  We will take the various artists, crafters, and experimenters, and pull them together under one roof.  We will draw on the successful model of co-working spaces, which are in high use in Boulder’s tech industries, in a creative setting.  There will be a focus on education for children and adults and a focus on artist professional development. The needs that will be addressed are:Affordable and accessible options for artists to pursue their professional goals. A venue to gather insight and direction in the artistic fields A place for “non-artists” to pursue creative development in a safe and accessible way. The reaching of a higher standard of supporting development at a young age.  We will reach beyond arts and crafts to teach full expression to clients of all ages and abilities.A liaison and resource between current, more specified, arts businesses in Boulder County and beyond.Mission StatementAlchemy Art Labs is a social-based business invested in the support, education, and enrichment of all humans through the arts. Some of the ways we do this is to provide studio space, gallery space, retail space, and educational space to the artist community and beyond. Artists involved with us will find new and creative solutions to the financial, logistical and emotional boundaries, that come with being an artist. Every human is at the effect of creative impulses. By creating the space for creativity to flourish and feed, all humans will thrive in our community.Vision StatementEvery human exposed to Alchemy Art Labs is greeted with compassion and guidance, and  their creative needs are fulfilled. All humans are exposed to support, education, space, beauty, depth, sustainability, growth, expansion, disruption of exhausted norms,  community, and inspiration. Values StatementWe value support, community, and cooperation.  We think the necessities in our business, and in life, include:  love, listening, action, movement, growth, ease, beauty, intention, and learning. We value an approach that does not rely upon expected societal norms, and the established art culture. We are informal, but within boundaries that maintain our professionalism. Every member, regardless of their role, has the space to contribute and influence within the company. Profitability, through community action, is the driving force from which we generate growth, stability, and long term viability. We are each, and as a whole, responsible for our actions.  We are accountable for ourselves and our behaviors.  We act with integrity and courage, with conviction and intention, and we do what we say we will do.  We work together and act in solidarity with others to further our cause.  We think ahead, strategically.  We embrace fluidity and transparency in all aspects of our lives, business, and intentions.  We take an equal opportunity approach to art and the creative process.Short Term Goals:
acquire funding for space, a build out, and 1 year of rent and utilities.
find a space
alter the space
recruit teachers to host classes
recruit clients
recruit artists to be involved
recruit artists to rent space
recruit artists to hang in gallery
identify revenue sources
acquire  funding for a part time sewing position for 1 year
acquire funding/donations for supplies/materials for 1 year
clearly define the roles of management as it evolves within the business
Long Term Goals
to be self sufficient, monetarily, by the end of the 1st year of operations
to hire a full time general manager during the first year of operations
to have the rentable studio space filled consistently
to have 3 to 5 classes happening per week
to have weekend workshops happen at least 2 weekends per month
to host 1 gallery event per month
to be able to pay a director salary after 1 year of operations
Reasons For BusinessTo promote art in our community in a way that values the artist and the creative process. To provide low cost studio space for local artists in a supportive and inspiring environment. To collaborate with and promote local artists through the gallery space and events.To provide educational space for the community in a desirable environment.To provide accessible classes for the community in a desirable environment.To provide a community and event space in a desirable environment. To provide support and resources in an area that is currently lacking. 

Lauryl Danuff (Director)
Background: 


Professional Designation Degree in Fashion Design from The Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising, Los Angeles
Associate of Arts Degree from Front Range Community College, emphasis in art history and design

Employment within the arts, fashion and other businesses for 15 years.
Own and operate ld industries Ltd., a custom housewares and fashion design production company in Boulder.

Held position as General Manager of a business for 5 years.  Managed team of 10 to 15 people, inventory, product management, customer service, HR, company direction and future, and day to day operations.  Organized and managed rotating gallery shows and events monthly.
Lauryl has experience building curriculum and hosting/teaching art for adults in collaboration with others.
Lauryl is involved with the planning, set-up and direction of all aspects of the business.
Lauryl will bring her knowledge of managing a business in combination with her long time work in the arts community to provide structure and operational knowledge to the business.  She will also use her position in the community to gather an artist/client/teacher support base to help the growth and sustainability of the business.


In the past 2 years, Lauryl has been laying the groundwork for this business by gathering her art community, building curriculum, hosting and teaching workshops, and putting together artist meet-ups and support groups.  All of these elements will be forwarded by, and will directly contribute to the mission and success of Alchemy Art Labs.
We are open to having more members who are aligned with the vision and values of Alchemy Art Labs.  

Management Structure
CU INVST Intern-team: The members are a part of the CU INVST program and are in their last year of their Bachelor degrees. 

Kelley Anderson- B.S. in Humanities: Community and Social Development
Jessica Wambsgans- B.S. in Business: Business Consultant, doing business research and development
Sienna Dellephpiane- B.S. in Sociology: Marketing/Outreach and Network Coordination

Any business management will be under the direct control of Lauryl.
A General Manager will be hired who will be in control of day to day operations.
Staff members will be hired as needed and as funds are available.

story:
And I'd like for you to be part of the team making the next big leap into the world of listening to music, movies and playing video games in 5.1.

This is my invitation to one and all to come aboard for a most exciting adventure. I need your help to promote my recently Patented miniature 5.1 surround sound listening system of loudspeaker placement.

First, if I reach my goal, I'll be showing it at America's largest Inventors Trade show, INPEX (Invention And New product Exposition) in June at Pittsburgh's David L. Lawrence Convention Center.




AFTER WAITING ALMOST FOUR YEARS


I FINALLY GOT MY PATENT

My Patent is based on my startling discovery that little loudspeakers can sound
the same at a few INCHES away, as they do at a few FEET away.

Hundreds of the biggest and best companies in the US will be at the Inpex Show, scouting to find, and take on new and unique inventions either by buying a patent outright or licensing to manufacture and sell. I will consider all ways.

You probably know that the costs for exhibiting in a high class trade show like this one can be very  high, and individuals, as well as companies, spend thousands to put their best foot forward.

Soon after the show, I'll introduce and demonstrate the invention to fellow recording engineers and mixers, audio enthusiasts, and speaker companies in Philadelphia, New York and Nashville. I'll also be inviting the press.

I've included the budget down below, and if we exceed that amount, I'll just keep plugging away, and show in more places like Chicago and L.A., and maybe more, and try to get on national TV. And if we go way over, I might even consider starting a company to make and distribute the platforms. 

If you make a pledge of any amount, you'll be invited to one of the showings, and you can bring your favorite video game, music or movies to try it out, or just bring yourself. 

We'll mount an extensive press campaign to all the trades with our 600 word releases also going to at least 100,000 journalists, twice.


I must put my best foot forward, but I can't do it without YOUR help.



This is John Fox, enjoying playing a video game with my Miniature Loudspeaker Placement Platform.

It also means lower cost equipment, including the amplifiers and the little speakers, and no need for expensive room treatment. The much lower volume levels mean that the power output needed is a fraction of what is needed in a full size sound treated room.

So, how did all of this come about?

I got the idea a few years ago when I was shooting my miniatures. I'm also a miniature craftsman and have made little working chandeliers, some of which are in museums.


This one



is hanging in the Ron Hubble "Solon" in the Taiwan Miniature Museum


I was writing my book, The Fine Art of Photographing Miniatures, especially chandeliers and rooms, and how to make them look like they're real and FULL size, like this one. 

I was setting up the lighting and the camera to shoot this room my wife had built. The cross bars in the photo show the camera positioning at eye level.



Note that the camera is only inches away at that established eye level of about four inches (four feet) off the floor


Seeing as how the furniture and chandelier looked so real at only a few inches away, I wondered how little SPEAKERS might sound from inches away. So, I went to work experimenting, and my research revealed that the intensity of sound levels drops off in inches just like it does in feet, and in the same proportions. Acting the same as light does in its intensity, they both follow the Inverse Square Law. The Patent Examiners, after intensive searching "prior art" Patents, found that no one had ever come up with this idea and after four years, issued my Patent. 

Thus, the newly Patented Miniaturized Loudspeaker Placement Platform

NOW IT CAN BE "MINI-FIELD" 

INSTEAD OF "NEAR-FIELD" - AND ONLY INCHES AWAY


So, a movie, music or a game addict, and even we STUDIO engineers, can crank it up at 3 AM, and not bother the neighbors. But now, I really need you to make a PLEDGE.


It was hard to come up with perks and incentives related to my invention, so, I decided to offer some of the finest dining places in the country and some famous jazz, country, classical, and Irish music places as perks and here's a few:

New York's

21 Club

Four Seasons

Carnegie Deli

 Birdland

NY Philharmonic Orch. at Lincoln Center

Meehan's Irish Pub in St. Augustine, FL

Philly's Old Ship Moshulu Restaurant

Grand Ole Opry 


or

or


OOh! does that look good!



 

or

or



or



The Gold and Platinum (perks) are similar to my real ones that you see here.



Here's a photo of some of my prototypes from a brochure


And especially my favorite prototype I am using in my studio. 

I LOVE MY LITTLE STUDIO WHERE I CAN DO ALMOST ANYTHING. AND THERE'S MY  "MINI-FIELD,"

 LF, C, RF, LR, AND RR. & Logic Pro X


But now, I really need you to make a pledge, and every dollar counts.

Our goal is $15,275, and my hopes are high that we reach it, and even go beyond. And if we do, rest assured that I will seek all means to promote the invention, with lots of publicity and continued plugging away. Who knows? If we go way over our goal, we might even start our own company making them from the prototypes shown, and find a distributor, and also license it.

With Indiegogo crowd-funding, if you don't reach your goal, unlike other crowd-funders, you will still get whatever the amount is. But we really need that amount to put it over right.

So please look over the proposed budget.

                       

              PRESENTATION TO AUDIO PROFESSIONALS

   AND SPEAKER  COMPANIES  NYC                                                   $1,416

PRESENTATION TO AUDIO PROFESSIONALS NASHVILLE                1,320

PRESENTATION TO AUDIO PROFESSIONALS PHILADELPHIA             350

INVENTERS SHOW  PITTSBURGH  JUNE 17- 20, 2014                       3,215

TWO 600 WORD PRO PRESS RELEASE (ERELEASES.COM)                998

LEGAL                                                                                                   2,000

ASSISTANT - SERVICES AND ALL EXPENSES  INPEX SHOW            1,100

ADDITIONAL AUDIO EQUIPMENT                                                           500

ADD PROTOTYPE                                                                                   150

DISPLAY MATERIALS                                                                              500

TRADEMARK                                                                                           375

PRINTING                                                                                                230

MISC                                                                                                        200

______________ 

$12,354

  

    

                                                                             INCENTIVES  15%     1,853

  _________________

     GRAND TOTAL         $14,207


INDIEGOGO FEES 4% if total is reached  If not reached it is 9%                    610

CREDIT CARD FEES 3%                     458


   _______________

FUNDRAISING Total  INCLUDING INDIEGOGO & CREDIT CARD             $15,275


ACTUAL MONEY FOR PROJECT  $12,354


So please help me get to that important show, where I can shout it all out to those important companies and then on to the three big city demonstrations RECORDING PROFESSIONALS AND SPEAKER COMPANIES. And, with your much needed help, that right company will find us, and we'll get the word out to everyone. So, PLEASE, make a pledge and I'll appreciate it, MORE than you'll ever know. Make a pledge and if you can get to Pittsburgh, I will be getting a limited number of badges to see the show. If not at Pittsburgh, at least you're invited to one of the demonstrations. Well, I hope to see you there.


So with your help, a great event is about to happen in the audio industry.


LAST AND LEAST IS MY SMART ASS DO NOTHING ASSISTANT, WITH HIS WISE CRACKS. SO, IT IS "BUCK" OFFERING HIS "BUCK" PLEDGE IN THE VIDEO ABOVE WITH, 

"YOU GOT CHANGE FOR A FIVE?"



SOME COMMENTS FROM MY FRIENDS SO FAR

"Good luck. 

"Good luck I can make a pledge through paypal." 

"What a really cool idea, can't wait to hear it! and congrats on the patent"

  "Very nice!"

              "Congrats on this very exciting project! best of luck to you and i will be happy to donate when the time comes!

       "Don, sounds great. VERY excited for your news and terrific developments!"

        "Excellent! Hope the trade show goes well...let me know."

        "I would like to donate to your efforts."

 "Hey Don, Sounds Great! I have my fingers crossed that it happens big for you!"

"Congratulations Don! I'm happy for you!"

"Great stuff don, yes keep me in touch on how things work out and I'll spread the word."

"Wow ok! Big Congrats Don!!!

"Congratulations on your roll out."

"like a great idea! Knowing your talent I predict
great success."

"Hey Don congrats mate, I'm happy for u!"

"Congratulations Don. Nothing is more satisfying or inspiring than to see passions birthed through tenacity and commitment. It is great news and my wish for you is that your vision is fully realized."

"Don, congratulations!  Glad you received your patent - a great milestone!"

"Wow. I can see you put a lot of work in this. Well done"




Please make a pledge!

and my wish for you is that your vision is fully realized.""Don, congratulations!  Glad you received your patent - a great milestone!""Wow. I can see you put a lot of work in this. Well done"
Please make a pledge!

story:
Help the Burlesque Hall of Fame protect our collection


The Burlesque Hall of Fame, the world’s only museum dedicated to preserving the legacy of burlesque, needs your help. At the beginning of July, the Burlesque Hall of Fame was informed that the building where the vast majority of our collection is stored would be seized under eminent domain for the widening of Interstate 15, Las Vegas’ main interstate artery.

Our collection consists of thousands of costumes, photos, posters, stage props, scrapbooks, and other items associated with lives and careers of some of the biggest stars not just in burlesque but of the stage and screen, too: Gypsy Rose Lee, Ann Corio, Sally Rand, Lili St. Cyr, Tura Satana, April March, Jayne Mansfield, Blaze Starr, Tempest Storm, and of course our own Jennie Lee and Dixie Evans, among hundreds of others. It is a critical piece of history.

This sudden, unexpected development is not one our modest operating budget can easily cover. While we’re looking into all available options for assistance to cover direct moving costs, our needs are much greater than any agency is likely to offer. At a minimum, the collection must be inventoried and each piece examined, packed for transit, moved, and then re-inventoried and re-examined. And of course, we want to do more than the minimum.

The current facilities are climate-controlled, pest-controlled, and secure, but lack any space to organize or work with our collection. While the timing of this new move is far from ideal (you can barely move your arms in Las Vegas in August, much less a museum), it presents an ideal opportunity for us to not just continue to shelter the collection in “suspended animation” but to fully revive it, by upgrading to facilities where we can access, study, and restore these priceless historical treasures.

Our goal, above and beyond simply protecting our collection, is to provide the facilities our collection deserves: a larger space to accommodate new acquisitions, with shelves and racks for properly organizing everything, archival-quality storage materials to store it in, and suitable environment to work in. Your tax-deductible contribution will bring us closer to this goal, and to the larger goal of being able once again to put these pieces on display in all their glory, both virtually and in person.

Here’s what you get

In addition to the incredible feeling of satisfaction that supporting the Burlesque Hall of Fame gives you, we are offering the following premiums to IndieGoGo donors:

  • Donate $25 and we’ll list your name on a special “Thank You” wall on our website.

  • Donate $50 and you’ll get your name on the “Thank You” wall AND a 2012 Weekender T-Shirt in the size of your choice.

  • Donate $100 and you’ll get your name on the “Thank You” wall, a 2012 Weekender T-Shirt, AND an exclusive BHoF logo tote bag that we’re having made special just for this fundraiser.

  • Donate $500 and you’ll get everything we already mentioned AND an invitation to attend (free of charge, of course) a special VIP Event held in Las Vegas during 2013 BHoF Weekender, where you will join other elite BHoF supporters and a bevy of special guests.

  • Donate $1000 and you get to bring a date. That is, you’ll get TWO invitations to the VIP event, TWO T-Shirts, TWO tote bags, and we’ll even put two names on the “Thank You” wall if you want.

story:
The Golden Ticket

My studies in architecture have led me to the Black Rock Desert in Nevada, where the Burning Man festival is held each summer.  This year over 60,000 people are going to build a temporary city for their art festival.  I've made it my master's thesis project to study the festival, and more importantly I've made it my project to participate too.  

I'm going to be spending a month down in the desert this summer, helping to build art projects, documenting the festival, and introducing Black Rock City to all the puppets and projects I'll bring along with me.  

So for the next month, I'm rallying support so I can secure my transportation, and bolster my camp with a series of art projects.  Those art projects are the focus of my campaign, and will be surfacing through the next month as I prepare to embark on my pilgrimage to the desert.  There's going to be a tutu or two, masks, puppets, a dada edition of a book, and a large, oyster-shaped, tent named the Pearl Palace. And I hope that list is just the beginning.  I'll be adding each item to the perks list as they come available, and keeping you well informed of how the campaign is progressing.

Please spread the word, I can't wait for you to join in on my project!

story:
Heels on Wheels: Keep the Glitter Sparkling!

 For 2013, we are looking to crowd source $5,000 towards our organization's sustainability.

 Heels on Wheels is a group of interdisciplinary performing artists and event producers who create fabulous and inclusive performance-based cultural works and community events that are produced from sites of femme/inine-positive queer embodiment. 

Heels on Wheels emerges from an active anti-oppression, intersectional, radical queer, feminist and liberatory standpoint boldly asserting: art can change our world. 

 As event organizers we've created space for over 150 artists to share their stories, their truths, and their creativity live in front of amazing audiences. We've gathered 200 people at four different community conversations, and 100 at workshops. We've entertained, inspired, and educated over 2,000 folks across Canada and the continental U.S. at shows that are always financially accessible and often all-ages. 

 Heels on Wheels produces an annual Glitter Roadshow tour, a monthly Opentoe Peepshow revealing new works by queer artists, a Cabaret to End Patriarchy, and one-offs that have included the epic events Beyond Visibility, and Mixploratorium, and more.  

 Our shows, events, and dialogues reveal the power in our under-represented communities by including local acts, facilitating discussions on activist art, and touring social justice and anti-oppressive cultural works.By actively complicating what it looks like, sounds like, and IS like to shamelessly and lovingly  represent femininity, dandyness, fey, femme and queer lady, this work confronts misogyny and sexism and uses cultural works to sabotage the status quo of gender, sexuality, and “feminine” appearance, replacing it with many visions and ideas of what thriving and surviving as femme folks can be. 

WHY YOU SHOULD RAIN SOME GLITTER ON US!!

We've been working together for almost four years and are currently building our organization's infrastructure so we can work together more democratically, sustain our cultural work, and include more people in the core organizing, curating, and producing group. 

 For this -- we need seed money! To start a business bank account, to apply for grants, and to combat income inequality by paying honorariums so more people can work with us. 

 As a working-class and poor people-led organization, we know that taking time off work without pay is not always an option, and we don't want that reality to keep any femme who wants to work with Heels on Wheels out, so some of this money will go towards income reimbursement for touring artists.

 Lastly, we plan to hold a visioning retreat in Summer 2013, and want to make it financially accessible for everyone who wants to attend to do so. 

 Our events are mostly volunteer-run, and the money we do make goes to space rental [not cheap in NYC!], paying artists too-small honorariums, and a $25/week practice space the Heels on Wheels core folks share. For tour, using a feminist model that all labor is equally valuable, we pay artists and staff the same wage. This equalled, considering all the time on tour [10 hours a day]: $1/hour for the first tour, and $2/hour for the next two tours. The tour organizing is paid at about $0.50-$1/hour. Heels on Wheels is a labor of love that we want to continue, and to do so we want to invite more people in, and be able to provide more sustainable honorariums to them.

MORE ABOUT OUR SPARKLE

The people presenting art onstage and community organizing in their home city of Brooklyn all build power for traditionally-marginalized LGBTQ stories and people. Heels on Wheels is working class-led and multi-racial, and includes and showcases cisgendered and trans folks, QPOC, mixed race, and white folks, sex workers, immigrants, survivors, and more: all fiercely political feminist queer artists whose work weaves punk herstories, survival strategies, and wild costuming into escape artistry. These are stories that do not have enough outlets on a regular basis and that's one reason this tour is important!

“The Heels on Wheels Roadshow is a glorious campaign to put femininity in the spotlight. I totally applaud and approve. It is a delicious combination touring glitterati and local sparkle that showcases some serious queer talent. Don’t let them pass you by!”

– Lois Weaver, Obie-Award Winning Performer, Lecturer Queen Mary University of London

story:
The Birth of CollaboNation

My name is Jessie, I have been a portrait artist for the past 5 years, and have always been mesmerised by the beauty and fragility of the human condition, the walls we put up, and the complex networks of emotion that sit so closely behind them. During my years of practice though, there has always been something missing for me. It was one event in May of last year that finally shed light on what that was. 

In Union Square, Manhattan last May, I rolled out a huge canvas on the pavement with some paints and brushes, and asked passers by to join in in helping me fill it with colour. The day that followed was the most beautiful display of human connection and expression I have ever witnessed, and brought me the most happiness of anything I have ever done.

People from all walks of life dropped what they were doing and sat with me for 5 minutes, 15 minutes, 2 hours, and not only contributed to a vibrant and living artwork that grew and morphed throughout the day, but opened up to me and each other about their lives, their passions and their worries, their plans for the day, the poem they had written for their girlfriend, how their mum was pissed off with them because of this or that. Connecting with someone next to them that on the subway would not have recieved a smile. 

It struck me then, that this was what I wanted as an artist. I want to be the vehicle that cracks through those walls, that breaks the fear of creation and expression that the vast majority of society has. To create an opportunity for the beauty and positivity of collaborating and connecting with your fellow man or woman, boy or girl for the pure sake of enjoyment in a passing moment, to be seen and to be appreciated as a fundamentally human concept that has been somewhat squashed in our busy, modern world.

CollaboNation at Burning Man Festival, Black Rock Desert, Navada

http://www.burningman.com/whatisburningman/

"Mission Statement..

Our mission is to produce the annual event known as "Burning Man" and to guide, nurture and protect the more permanent community created by its culture. Our intention is to generate society that connects each individual to his or her creative powers, to participation in community, to the larger realm of civic life, and to the even greater world of nature that exists beyond society. We believe that the experience of Burning Man can produce positive spiritual change in the world. To this end, it is equally important that we communicate with one another, with the citizens of Black Rock City and with the community of Burning Man wherever it may arise. Burning Man is radically inclusive, and its meaning is potentially accessible to anyone. The touchstone of value in our culture will always be immediacy: experience before theory, moral relationships before politics, survival before services, roles before jobs, embodied ritual before symbolism, work before vested interest, participant support before sponsorship. Finally, in order to accomplish these ends, Burning Man must endure as a self-supporting enterprise that is capable of sustaining the lives of those who dedicate themselves to its work. From this devotion spring those duties that we owe to one another. We will always burn the Man. "

Not only does CollaboNation's values and intentions resonate harmoniously with those of Burning Man, but it is a temporary, transient society that assembles from all across the world in a collaborative and self reliant epicentre of conscious human celebration. 

The artwork that we create at Burning Man will be a collaboration between you guys, the funding contributors, from different places across the globe, and those at burning man that have travelled from all across the world to the Black Rock Desert - collaboratively funded, collaboratively created, and collaboratively experienced. Each contributor taking that seed back to their homes and effectively spreading it across the world.

In the transient spirit of Burning Man, at the end of the festival and upon completion of the artwork, when all contributors have expressed and released what they needed to, the piece will be cremated and ashes savoured as a token of the moment in time when all of us crossed paths and gave our piece.

As contributors you are a fundamental piece of the artwork! of the magic! This artwork is all about the experience of collaboration and where it can take us as human beings, without your contribution it does not exist!

 What You Get

In Summary, this instalment of CollaboNation will result in

1. an enormous artwork created by a global network of beautiful human beings both physically present at Burning Man and present by contribution: celebrating, cultivating, and proliferating a collaborative attitude.

2. a short film/ documentary on the entire process and experience from birth to cremation, capturing the unique and beautiful personalities that contribute and their stories.

3. photo documentation including portraits of each burning man contributor and verbal musings from each.

4. the birth of a global project - Burning Man will be the launchpad for CollaboNation as a movement, with scope to travel across the globe, capturing the creativity and expression, and gaining insight into the minds of humans from contrasting walks of life -  ending in an exhibition of artworks from across the world and a social documentary on the people behind the paint.

UNIQUE PLEDGE REWARDS

$5 -

- the warm fuzzy feeling of being a part of a global, positive, collaborative movement.

- an email of gratitude with an acrostic poem of your name.

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


$35 -

- a certificate of contribution

- a letter of gratitude

- a copy of the burning man/ CollaboNation documentary on dvd, complete with inlay of finished artwork.

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


$50 - 

- A2 glossy poster of the finished piece

- certificate of contribution.

- letter of gratitude

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


$65- 

- limited edition a1 size glossy poster of the finished piece

- a certificate of contribution

- letter of gratitude

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


$170 - 

- an A1 size, fine art glicee print on Canson Vilen cotton rag (art gallery standard) of one of my original works ( visit www.jess.bush.com to have a look!)

- a letter of gratitude

- a certificate of contribution

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


$200 

-  limited edition hardcover book of photos of contributing painters with musings from the contributors about what they have painted.

-  glossy a2 poster of the finished piece

- a certificate of contribution

- a letter of gratitude

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


-$300 

- an exclusive portrait of you done by me a2 size -  www.jessbush.com for examples of my work! 

- a letter of gratitude

- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


-$400 

- go down in history! send in a photo of yourself and have a burning man contributor paint an interpretation of your head on the original piece - receive an a3 fine art print on Canson Vilen cotton Rag (art gallery standard) of that section with a photo of the contributor who painted your face, accompanied by their musings at the time.

- limited edition a1 print of the final piece

- certificate of contribution

- a letter of gratitude

- a VIP feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage


$1500 - 

- the ashes of the cremated artwork divided among the 5 oceanic contributors in a decorative urn.

- limited edition hardcover book of photos of contributing painters with musings from the contributors about what they have painted.

- a glicee art print of the finished piece in A2 OR A1 size. FINE ART STANDARD on Canson Vilen Cotton Rag  (art gallery standard)

- a certificate of contribution

- a handwritten letter of gratitude

- the CollaboNation at Burning Man dvd documentary complete with inlay of the completed artwork. AND a special clip of us singing you a personalised thank you song.

- a VIP feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage

What We Need 

We need the funds to get myself and my videographer over there with the minimum gear possible! I've calculated it out to be around $8750 Here's the breakdown...

-  flights - approx $1200 one way per person = $4800 for both return to L.A.

-  budget transport and accommodation - from reno to black rock https://secure.rentalcarmanager.com/sslwicked/WickedCanada133/CAStep2.asp?refid=&URL=  $1246 for 14 days

- food and water for 2 people for one week $300

- shady sail for painters - $200

- survival supplies (e.g sunscreen and baby wipes!) etc = $200

- festival tickets - 380 per person =  $760 

- materials -

 - canvas = $300

 - paints = $30 for 6 x 1 pint colour tubs (value pack) x 4 =  $120  + $50 for extra white and other colours 

 - paint brushes - $200

 - printed photographs of portrait contributors $25

 - rags, buckets for water, cleaning cloths/towels = $30 

 - batteries and chargers - $100

 - memory cards/ external hard drives for storage of footage - $300

- collaboNation flag and pole - $100

and to cover the distribution of pledges, 28% ($2450) needs to be added to the final goal! which brings the funding goal to $11200


The Impact

The difference your contribution will make - 

 - your contribution is a vital piece of the artwork. The piece is more about the experience of its creation and how it comes together than the end result. although the end piece will be beautiful and an infinite token of the experience.

Where CollaboNation has already spread joy, created beautiful art and uncovered amazing stories..

- Union square, Manhattan New York City May 2013

- Surry Hills, Sydney, street-side activation October 2013

- One Day Sundays street block party, Marrickville, Sydney March 2014


Other Ways You Can Help

There are ways in which you can greatly help the flourishing of CollaboNation if you can't help with funding! I need you to help spread the word!! spread the love and the awareness! As I have said before, this whole experience is built on working together, so the more we all pitch in in the ways that we can, the more beautiful the impact will be!

- A2 glossy poster of the finished piece
- certificate of contribution.
- letter of gratitude
- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage

$65- 
- limited edition a1 size glossy poster of the finished piece
- a certificate of contribution
- letter of gratitude
- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage

$170 - 
- an A1 size, fine art glicee print on Canson Vilen cotton rag (art gallery standard) of one of my original works ( visit www.jess.bush.com to have a look!)
- a letter of gratitude
- a certificate of contribution
- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage
$200 
-  limited edition hardcover book of photos of contributing painters with musings from the contributors about what they have painted.
-  glossy a2 poster of the finished piece
- a certificate of contribution
- a letter of gratitude
- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage

-$300 
- an exclusive portrait of you done by me a2 size -  www.jessbush.com for examples of my work! 
- a letter of gratitude
- a feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage

-$400 
- go down in history! send in a photo of yourself and have a burning man contributor paint an interpretation of your head on the original piece - receive an a3 fine art print on Canson Vilen cotton Rag (art gallery standard) of that section with a photo of the contributor who painted your face, accompanied by their musings at the time.
- limited edition a1 print of the final piece
- certificate of contribution
- a letter of gratitude
- a VIP feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage

$1500 - 
- the ashes of the cremated artwork divided among the 5 oceanic contributors in a decorative urn.
- limited edition hardcover book of photos of contributing painters with musings from the contributors about what they have painted.
- a glicee art print of the finished piece in A2 OR A1 size. FINE ART STANDARD on Canson Vilen Cotton Rag  (art gallery standard)
- a certificate of contribution
- a handwritten letter of gratitude
- the CollaboNation at Burning Man dvd documentary complete with inlay of the completed artwork. AND a special clip of us singing you a personalised thank you song.
- a VIP feature in the rolling credits of the CollaboNation documentary and on the CollaboNation webpage
What We Need We need the funds to get myself and my videographer over there with the minimum gear possible! I've calculated it out to be around $8750 Here's the breakdown...
-  flights - approx $1200 one way per person = $4800 for both return to L.A.
-  budget transport and accommodation - from reno to black rock https://secure.rentalcarmanager.com/sslwicked/WickedCanada133/CAStep2.asp?refid=&URL=  $1246 for 14 days
- food and water for 2 people for one week $300- shady sail for painters - $200- survival supplies (e.g sunscreen and baby wipes!) etc = $200
- festival tickets - 380 per person =  $760 
- materials - - canvas = $300 - paints = $30 for 6 x 1 pint colour tubs (value pack) x 4 =  $120  + $50 for extra white and other colours  - paint brushes - $200 - printed photographs of portrait contributors $25 - rags, buckets for water, cleaning cloths/towels = $30  - batteries and chargers - $100 - memory cards/ external hard drives for storage of footage - $300- collaboNation flag and pole - $100and to cover the distribution of pledges, 28% ($2450) needs to be added to the final goal! which brings the funding goal to $11200The ImpactThe difference your contribution will make -  - your contribution is a vital piece of the artwork. The piece is more about the experience of its creation and how it comes together than the end result. although the end piece will be beautiful and an infinite token of the experience.Where CollaboNation has already spread joy, created beautiful art and uncovered amazing stories..- Union square, Manhattan New York City May 2013- Surry Hills, Sydney, street-side activation October 2013- One Day Sundays street block party, Marrickville, Sydney March 2014Other Ways You Can HelpThere are ways in which you can greatly help the flourishing of CollaboNation if you can't help with funding! I need you to help spread the word!! spread the love and the awareness! As I have said before, this whole experience is built on working together, so the more we all pitch in in the ways that we can, the more beautiful the impact will be!

story:
The Story Begins...

"Narin the Mermaid" began as a character I created and performed at a Rennaissance Faire a year and a half ago. It started as a way to bring more traffic to the vending booth I was working at, but I got far more than I bargained for! The expressions on the faces of the young and 'young at heart' as I interacted with them were absolute Magic. Not the kind of magic that we get from watching CGI effects on a screen, but Magic that you can reach out and touch. For a few brief moments, folks BELIEVED that Mermaids were real, and I was hooked ( no pun intended ). And I realized that I could use Narin to accomplish much bigger things!

I am going to make a series of story books featuring full color art photography of Narin in beautiful river and wetlands scenes, and use these story books in partnerships with organizations that are passionate about clean water.

What these " Mo-nees" will go toward...

- publishing and printing expenses to produce the first book

- travel and photography expenses needed to create the photographic images to be used in the book.

- costuming expenses to improve Narin's appearance to make her even more believable and magical, including a professionally made tail.

This is the fish tail that we have chosen to replicate, it is the orange spotted sunfish that lives in rivers and large streams in the North Eastern US. Isn't he a lovely buggar?! 


The Impact

I believe that We need to begin educating people in a way that is fun and easy to identify with. In my history as Narin, there has never been one person, young or old, that does not smile as they pass me...

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand funds are tight for many folks right now, so just share the heck out of this project! If you run into an organization with goals that match ours, let them in on what we are trying to do here.

Please, SHARE the Magic.....and keep wishing on the waves !
