story:
Who am I and a short summary about Viva La Vida

My name is Polina Porras Sivolobova.

I am an artist and today I am asking you to be part of a new project: a unique, one-time-only urban intervention, performance, performative action, celebration, ritual, and participatory art: Viva La Vida.

Viva La Vida which translates as Joy of Life, a Hurray for Life is inspired on Frida Kahlo’s last painting a still life with watermelons where she 'carved' the words Viva La Vida in one of the watermelons.

I have been an artist for twenty years (in 1992 I started my career making spray paint art and selling them in fairs in the Southwest) and in these years I have done many things: spray paint paintings, drawings, murals, prints, collages, puppets, plays, videos, documentaries, scripts, installations, books, stories, masks, costumes, photographs, performances, urban interventions, actions, and ephemeral art.

More on my work

www.polinaporras.com

https://www.facebook.com/Polina.P.Sivolobova

https://vimeo.com/polinaporras

Initially scheduled to be performed on November 19 - 22, 2013, during the XII World Congress of the Organization of World Heritage Cities. The new date for Viva La Vida is in December, between Christmas and New Year's.

During my residency in the city of Oaxaca, Mexico (summer 2013) I found a beautiful site of historic and cultural value, also as many Mexican monuments with a sad and bloody past. I couldn't resist conjuring a performance in my head, my heart and my body. I had that urgent sensation that many performers have: to go and just do it - disregarding the risk of either being imprisoned or being unnoticeable. I decided that to convey the message of this piece I couldn't risk my freedom or my anonymity - I want a lot of people to know about it and experience it with me from beginning to end. 

This is where you come in...help me go back to Oaxaca and do an urban performance on the plaza of the church of Santo Domingo de Guzmán.


As a statement, as a gift, as a celebration of Mexico's rich culture in a blend of watermelon hearts, ancient rituals, bloody pasts and conflicting presents, and joy of life as revolution: Viva La Vida, with original music by guest artists Jesús González-Gutiérrez and Arturo Camacho. And just for a brief time, the plaza will be transformed, people will be invited to participate in a performance of synergetic rituals of Mesoamerican people and of catholic people. 

Why performance

Performance art, the art of activating bodies and space through actions, allows to create an alternative world where new meanings can emerge through non-quotidian interactions, thus the possibility of dreams and other ways of being.

Why Oaxaca

A statement, a proposition that performance art, when brought to life, becomes part of a site's history, through people's embodied memory, just as historical events. Except that in Viva La Vida I seek to decontextualize a city's icon (the church of Santo Domingo) by bringing actions and symbols from the city's conflicting past. Our actions as individuals and as societies create our present as well as a road to the future. Oaxaca de Juárez,  declared by the UNESCO as a Humanities Cultural Patrimony city is rich in culture, natural resources, art, history, gastronomy, and one of Mexico's main touristic attractions yet it is also a city where thousands of children are without school, where there is violence against women, social inequality, and racial discrimination. These conditions, good and bad, play a role in people's everyday lives creating dynamic platforms for actions, reactions and interactions.

What I need and what you get.

I want to pay all people who will contribute in this work: musicians for creating and performing new music, photographers for taking great pictures which will live for ever and will allow anyone who won't be present to see a glimpse or to have a memento, the videographers for capturing every moment through video and will allow us to relive it any time we want and to pay my self for creating this work which I hope you all enjoy and...this is my job. Besides that: I need to get to Oaxaca, live an eat, buy lots of watermelons and other things, print photos and make books.

This is what I need:

Artist and Musicians                                      $  1,700

Administrative                                                       400

Photographers                                                      400

Videographers                                                      400

Transportation 

Airplane ticket NYC-Oaxaca-NYC x 1                   800

Local transportation: people and props                 100

Lodging (hey, I have friends in Oaxaca)                    0

Promotion                                                              250

Materials

Watermelons, costume and other items                350

Permits                                                                  300

Meals                                                                     200

Photos                                                                   150

Books                                                                    300

Shipping                                                                  50

Total                                                                 $ 5,400


Perks

Anything helps and even the minimum $ 10 gift will give you the inside scoop of 'behind the scenes' (or behind my brain).

The hand-made book about Viva La Vida, I would love to have one of those!

Besides, wouldn't it be great to have a one-week coach on creativity? (take a look at Baroque Night). And above all, you will get the joy of making Viva La Vida possible!

I am holding on to many details about this piece because I don’t want to spoil it. What I can say is that it will be a performance rich in images, sound, symbols and actions using Santo Domingo's Baroque style and aesthetics of the local indigenous people and no humans, animals or plants will be harmed, only temporary natural dyes on public buildings and possibly a few minor non-harming ideological shocks to some people. I will be notifying local authorities about this event.

Spread the word! Thank you, thank you.

polinaporras@gmail.com


Polina Porras Sivolobova is a visual and performance artist. She has done work in drawing, video, photography, documentaries, street interventions and performance. In 2010 she shot and directed a documentary about her grandmothers: one Russian and the other Mexican, each in their respective countries - Mi Abuela, Моя Бабушка (My Grandmother, My Grandmother). Some of her street interventions are ¿Dónde están Piecitos Azul? an interaction with the children street-vendors in Chiapas, Mexicoand Queens of Love interacting with the immigrant community of Jackson Heights, New York. Her latest performance One and Not the Same Skin, a twenty-four hour piece, talks about personal transformation using clothing as a metaphor. Her artwork has been shown at the Hemispheric of Peformance and Politics, El Museo del Barrio, The Smithsonian Institute, The Queens Museum of Art, Grace Exhibition Space and Glasshouse in New York City. Polina is the founder of Avocado Pit, an artist-based initiative that seeks the development and promotion of multidisciplinary art and art education. In the last years, she has taught multidisciplinary art workshops in schools, libraries and museums as well as immigrant communities in the city of New York. Polina’s artwork, in its majority autobiographical, seeks to create a dialogue of poetic actions using personal experiences related to gender and her Russian-Mexican identity in diverse contexts. Polina has a Master in Fine Arts and Art and Design Education from Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, New York. She lives and works between New York City and Oaxaca, Mexico.

story:
UPDATES

 

13/02/2012:

 

Just snagged one of my favourite illustrators to help out with EIA. More details soon. I'm stoked!

 

09/02/2012:

 

Check out this awesome track from Phil Hamelin of www.philhamelinmusic.com! Iâ€™m so excited to see what else he has in store, as well as the excellent artists Iâ€™ve recruited with your help! Keep sharing the project, and let me know what you think about the video â€“ itâ€™s your input that makes this happen!

 

ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA - Persecution Delusion

 

04/01/2012:


Recruited a co-writer and a few artists! Production is underway on a demo trailer and eventual playable demo. Thanks for all your support! Keep trading the tapes! 

27/12/2011: 

Changed the title of the project from "NV High" to 'ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA', as it better reflects my vision for the project as a slice of life instead of Degrassi: Mental Illness Edition. Extensively revised the description.

Our Story

 

My name's Karl Parakenings. I'm a writer, graphic designer, narrative designer, and artist, currently on medical leave from an MA in English Literature.

 

I'm making an interactive graphic novel about living with an undiagnosed mental illness. Itâ€™s called ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA.

 

 

During my recent treatment, a big hurdle that I've had is trying to figure out how freaky I am: are there other people who think like me? Will I be looked at strangely because I mention my meds in conversation or ask not to go into a bar because I'll be overwhelmed to the point of panic?

 

I want to help others with these diseases to feel like they fit in, like there are other people out there that have to deal with the elephant in the room. Most of all, I want to create resources that their friends and family can use to understand what everyday life is like for them. Itâ€™s not only children who are affected by ADHD; teenage and adult men and women are affected as well. It's not only teens who get depressed; 80% of North Americans will have a period of severe depression in their lives. It's incredibly common.

 

But as it stands, mental illness is incredibly underrepresented in games and in mass media. For family and friends of sufferers of mental illness, and even for sufferers themselves, there are very, very few role models. If you have this illness, or if you know someone who has this illness, you're told to give them a suicide prevention hotline number.

 

But what do you do when they're crying so hard that they're shaking? How do you get your support and empathy across the gulf of severe depression? There are few examples to follow, and none in the interactive medium of games.

 

I want to change that.

 

 

Along with my longtime friend and fellow ADHD sufferer D. McDowall, I'm creating an engaging and interactive graphic novel that features people who are mentally ill as people first, coping with everyday problems which are made more difficult by their disability, and those that care for and support them.

 

 

The Impact

 

A conservative estimate puts the number of adults with ADHD at seven million. Thatâ€™s just according to the current diagnostic criteria, which are slated to become wider in 2013. In other words, thatâ€™s just the amount of people who were diagnosed as children who continued to adulthood still fighting the disorder. People like me, who were diagnosed as adults, arenâ€™t factored into that.

 

 

Thereâ€™s a high chance of people with ADHD also having other disorders like anxiety and depression as well. Up to 37% of people with ADHD have depression or similar disorders. Those at risk for alcohol abuse climb to more than 50% in the population with ADHD. Think about how many moral panics you hear every year about teen substance abuse. In my case, I drank heavily because I wanted my brain to calm down. Iâ€™ve since stopped, but how many like me are out there right now?

 

Iâ€™m reaching out to all these people and saying to them, â€œLook, there are people like you in the world. This is how you can cope. This is what you can tell your friends and family about this disease, and how they can best help.â€

 

Iâ€™m going to make ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA regardless of the funding we get through IndieGoGo. But you can help me make this happen, and you can help me get it to people who need to see it.

 

 

Funding Goals

 

As it stands, if I make my goal, Iâ€™ll have enough money to make ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA the way I want to. If I go any further than that, all additional resources will go towards making this game as fantastic as possible â€“ adding new characters and new storylines, a wider variety of locations, things like that.

 

If the funding goes far enough over the mark, Iâ€™ll use the additional funds to secure development licenses and hardware that will allow me to port this game to iOS. 

 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Iâ€™ll be honest â€“ Iâ€™m just scraping by with my freelance work. If you canâ€™t donate, I understand.

 

 

 But if you relate to this project at all, if youâ€™ve known people with mental illness and witnessed their struggle, or if you have it yourself, the best thing you can do is to share this project on Facebook, Google Plus, Twitter, or other social media using the tools above.

 

Point friends and family to ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA, ask them to share it, and together weâ€™ll all make this interactive graphic novel a reality.

 

If you want to find out more about attention-deficit and hyperactivity disorder, please consult Mental Health Canada here, the Centre for ADHD Awareness at www.caddac.ca, or this informative series of slides about the economic cost of ADHD at http://www.caddac.ca/cms/CADDAC_pdf/Weiss%20The...

 

If you think that you have ADHD or depression, see a doctor as soon as you can. If they say you don't but it's getting in the way of your life, get a second opinion.

 

Thank you for reading.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Iâ€™m using Ren-Py, a Python-based visual novel creation kit, to create ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA. Because of my varied background, excepting music, I could do the whole thing myself.

 

The problem is time.

 

As a freelance graphic/web designer, most of my time has to go to business considerations first: finding clients, billing, invoicing, marketing my brand, networking, etc. Then I spend most of whatâ€™s left actually working. Thereâ€™s precious little time and no income left for side projects like ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA.

 

Every dollar you donate to this project goes towards its development, both buying time for me to work on it and buying actual assets and resources used in its development.  If I donâ€™t make my goal, itâ€™s all going towards these parts of development. Iâ€™m making this graphic novel even if I have to eat ramen to do it.

Art

 

Traditionally visual novels sprouted from Japanese anime and manga and, today, maintain the styles and conventions of that medium. I want to move beyond that. ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA will feature a dynamic take on the visual novel genre, one that borrows liberally from the styles of artists like Daniel Clowes, Adrien Tomine, Rebecca Dart, Erika Moen, Jess Fink, and the video game developer Cing to create an independent, subversive take on the visual novel form.

 

In other words, I donâ€™t want to make a VN just like all the others out there. I want to make one that looks and feels unique.

 

Other amateur projects like Katawa Shoujo have taken years to amass an art team with the skills necessary to develop the game. Iâ€™ve already reached out to many artists with the skills and style needed to make ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA a success. Help give me the ability to hire them and make this plan a reality.

Music

 

With sufficient funds, I can hire musicians through sites like http://freelancemusiccomposers.com/ and http://www.youngcomposers.com/ and work with them to create a soundtrack to ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA thatâ€™s both attractive and effective. If youâ€™ve ever seen a film like Brick, Jurassic Park, Pulp Fiction, The Life Aquatic or The Third Man, you know that music can make or break an emotional scene. Aside from everything else, I want ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA to be a story that resonates with people emotionally â€“ and I need music for that.

Advertising and Marketing
If this gets any funding through IndieGoGo, it'll have some word-of-mouth exposure. But any game, especially one that has any hint of education or awareness behind it, needs advertising to survive and succeed. And advertising costs money. Not only that, but I'd like to actually print flyers and cards to promote the game at various industry events, and that needs money too.

 

 

 

Finally, Perks

 

 

Brought Your Lunch From Home
$5 
 
Your mom leaves a note in it! It warms your heart. So do the pepperoni sticks.

 

 

*Free download of ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA on release

*Early access to development blog

*Early access to public demo

*Name listed on special thanks 'Crowdfund Investors' page of website



Buys a Burger Every Day
$25
 
It's greasy, but man is it satisfying.

 

 

*Free download and early access as above

*Signed thank-you card from me (may include doodles)

*Name listed on special thanks 'Crowdfund Investors' page of website


Brought Salad and Couscous
$50 
 
It's never too early to take care of yourself. You'll be standing while everyone else has coronaries at 21.

$100

story_txt:
UPDATES 
 
13/02/2012:
 
Just snagged one of my favourite illustrators to help out with EIA. More details soon. I'm stoked!
 
09/02/2012:
 
Check out this awesome track from Phil Hamelin of www.philhamelinmusic.com! Iâ€™m so excited to see what else he has in store, as well as the excellent artists Iâ€™ve recruited with your help! Keep sharing the project, and let me know what you think about the video â€“ itâ€™s your input that makes this happen!
 
ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA - Persecution Delusion
 
04/01/2012:
Recruited a co-writer and a few artists! Production is underway on a demo trailer and eventual playable demo. Thanks for all your support! Keep trading the tapes! 
27/12/2011: 
Changed the title of the project from "NV High" to 'ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA', as it better reflects my vision for the project as a slice of life instead of Degrassi: Mental Illness Edition. Extensively revised the description.
Our Story
 
My name's Karl Parakenings. I'm a writer, graphic designer, narrative designer, and artist, currently on medical leave from an MA in English Literature. 
 
I'm making an interactive graphic novel about living with an undiagnosed mental illness. Itâ€™s called ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA.
 
 
During my recent treatment, a big hurdle that I've had is trying to figure out how freaky I am: are there other people who think like me? Will I be looked at strangely because I mention my meds in conversation or ask not to go into a bar because I'll be overwhelmed to the point of panic?
 
I want to help others with these diseases to feel like they fit in, like there are other people out there that have to deal with the elephant in the room. Most of all, I want to create resources that their friends and family can use to understand what everyday life is like for them. Itâ€™s not only children who are affected by ADHD; teenage and adult men and women are affected as well. It's not only teens who get depressed; 80% of North Americans will have a period of severe depression in their lives. It's incredibly common.
 
But as it stands, mental illness is incredibly underrepresented in games and in mass media. For family and friends of sufferers of mental illness, and even for sufferers themselves, there are very, very few role models. If you have this illness, or if you know someone who has this illness, you're told to give them a suicide prevention hotline number.
 
But what do you do when they're crying so hard that they're shaking? How do you get your support and empathy across the gulf of severe depression? There are few examples to follow, and none in the interactive medium of games.
 
I want to change that.
 
 
Along with my longtime friend and fellow ADHD sufferer D. McDowall, I'm creating an engaging and interactive graphic novel that features people who are mentally ill as people first, coping with everyday problems which are made more difficult by their disability, and those that care for and support them.
 
 
The Impact
 
A conservative estimate puts the number of adults with ADHD at seven million. Thatâ€™s just according to the current diagnostic criteria, which are slated to become wider in 2013. In other words, thatâ€™s just the amount of people who were diagnosed as children who continued to adulthood still fighting the disorder. People like me, who were diagnosed as adults, arenâ€™t factored into that.
 
 
Thereâ€™s a high chance of people with ADHD also having other disorders like anxiety and depression as well. Up to 37% of people with ADHD have depression or similar disorders. Those at risk for alcohol abuse climb to more than 50% in the population with ADHD. Think about how many moral panics you hear every year about teen substance abuse. In my case, I drank heavily because I wanted my brain to calm down. Iâ€™ve since stopped, but how many like me are out there right now?
 
Iâ€™m reaching out to all these people and saying to them, â€œLook, there are people like you in the world. This is how you can cope. This is what you can tell your friends and family about this disease, and how they can best help.â€
 
Iâ€™m going to make ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA regardless of the funding we get through IndieGoGo. But you can help me make this happen, and you can help me get it to people who need to see it.
 
 
Funding Goals
 
As it stands, if I make my goal, Iâ€™ll have enough money to make ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA the way I want to. If I go any further than that, all additional resources will go towards making this game as fantastic as possible â€“ adding new characters and new storylines, a wider variety of locations, things like that.
 
If the funding goes far enough over the mark, Iâ€™ll use the additional funds to secure development licenses and hardware that will allow me to port this game to iOS. 
 
 
 
Other Ways You Can Help
 
Iâ€™ll be honest â€“ Iâ€™m just scraping by with my freelance work. If you canâ€™t donate, I understand.
 
 
 But if you relate to this project at all, if youâ€™ve known people with mental illness and witnessed their struggle, or if you have it yourself, the best thing you can do is to share this project on Facebook, Google Plus, Twitter, or other social media using the tools above.
 
Point friends and family to ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA, ask them to share it, and together weâ€™ll all make this interactive graphic novel a reality.
 
If you want to find out more about attention-deficit and hyperactivity disorder, please consult Mental Health Canada here, the Centre for ADHD Awareness at www.caddac.ca, or this informative series of slides about the economic cost of ADHD at http://www.caddac.ca/cms/CADDAC_pdf/Weiss%20The...
 
If you think that you have ADHD or depression, see a doctor as soon as you can. If they say you don't but it's getting in the way of your life, get a second opinion.
 
Thank you for reading.
 
 
What We Need & What You Get
 
Iâ€™m using Ren-Py, a Python-based visual novel creation kit, to create ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA. Because of my varied background, excepting music, I could do the whole thing myself.
 
The problem is time.
 
As a freelance graphic/web designer, most of my time has to go to business considerations first: finding clients, billing, invoicing, marketing my brand, networking, etc. Then I spend most of whatâ€™s left actually working. Thereâ€™s precious little time and no income left for side projects like ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA.
 
Every dollar you donate to this project goes towards its development, both buying time for me to work on it and buying actual assets and resources used in its development.  If I donâ€™t make my goal, itâ€™s all going towards these parts of development. Iâ€™m making this graphic novel even if I have to eat ramen to do it.
Art
 
Traditionally visual novels sprouted from Japanese anime and manga and, today, maintain the styles and conventions of that medium. I want to move beyond that. ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA will feature a dynamic take on the visual novel genre, one that borrows liberally from the styles of artists like Daniel Clowes, Adrien Tomine, Rebecca Dart, Erika Moen, Jess Fink, and the video game developer Cing to create an independent, subversive take on the visual novel form.
 
In other words, I donâ€™t want to make a VN just like all the others out there. I want to make one that looks and feels unique.
 
Other amateur projects like Katawa Shoujo have taken years to amass an art team with the skills necessary to develop the game. Iâ€™ve already reached out to many artists with the skills and style needed to make ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA a success. Help give me the ability to hire them and make this plan a reality.
Music
 
With sufficient funds, I can hire musicians through sites like http://freelancemusiccomposers.com/ and http://www.youngcomposers.com/ and work with them to create a soundtrack to ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA thatâ€™s both attractive and effective. If youâ€™ve ever seen a film like Brick, Jurassic Park, Pulp Fiction, The Life Aquatic or The Third Man, you know that music can make or break an emotional scene. Aside from everything else, I want ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA to be a story that resonates with people emotionally â€“ and I need music for that.
Advertising and Marketing
If this gets any funding through IndieGoGo, it'll have some word-of-mouth exposure. But any game, especially one that has any hint of education or awareness behind it, needs advertising to survive and succeed. And advertising costs money. Not only that, but I'd like to actually print flyers and cards to promote the game at various industry events, and that needs money too.
 
 
 
Finally, Perks
 
 
Brought Your Lunch From Home
$5 
 
 Your mom leaves a note in it! It warms your heart. So do the pepperoni sticks.
 
 
*Free download of ELEPHANT IN ABSENTIA on release
*Early access to development blog
*Early access to public demo
*Name listed on special thanks 'Crowdfund Investors' page of website

Buys a Burger Every Day
$25
 
 It's greasy, but man is it satisfying.
 
 
*Free download and early access as above
*Signed thank-you card from me (may include doodles)
*Name listed on special thanks 'Crowdfund Investors' page of website
Brought Salad and Couscous
$50 
 
 It's never too early to take care of yourself. You'll be standing while everyone else has coronaries at 21.

story:
Bournemouth Emerging Arts Fringe

15th October – 1st November 2015

www.b-e-a-f.co.uk

https://www.facebook.com/bournemouthfringe


Bournemouth Emerging Arts Fringe (BEAF) is the largest open-access, multi-art form festival in Bournemouth. Only in its second year, the festival offers an unmatched platform for local creatives across 18 days. With your support we want to celebrate the extraordinary talent we have in this area and to present a festival that reaches as many people as possible.


We set out to present a festival that represents the diverse range of voices and art forms that make our community great. With this in mind, a small team of volunteers have been working around the clock to ensure that anyone who has an idea for an event for this year’s festival can take part, yes - anyone! From emerging to established artists, we ensure that everyone’s event is included and that all submitted events are featured on our websites, social media and, with your help, a printed programme. The fringe will support artists to reach new audiences and gain industry exposure and experience. For many, this could be the most significant platform opportunity they’ve had to date.


Audiences will be able to enjoy a diverse range of events, including exhibitions, talks, workshops, theatre, live music, poetry, a film festival and so much more. With events taking place across the town, from the centre to the suburbs, the place will be bursting with creativity. What’s here on your very own doorstep may just surprise you. We invite you to join us as we discover new places and faces, to listen, to think, to talk, to dance, to laugh and to be together. Sound good?


Why BEAF needs your help?

Last year's event was done on a shoestring and brought to you by a host of talented, local bournemouth volunteers, artists & creatives. The festival showed just how much potential there is for an event like this in the town. But, there is a limit to what can be achieved on a shoestring. We think we can do better. We think that Bournemouth deserves better.


This year a dedicated team of volunteers continue to give their time and talents for free, and a selection of local businesses and organisations are supporting us in any way they can. There are things that need paying for with money though, and that’s where you come in.


With money we can raise our game. We can reach more people. We can provide just that little bit of extra support to the artists who need it. We can make ambitions reality. There’s a whole host of things we need from flyers and printed programmes, to make sure as many people know about the festival as possible, to paints, rentals, fuel, food, screens, banners - you name it, we need it.


What You Get . . .

The bottom line is your pledge will support our homegrown talent and give them a platform to showcase their amazing work. What’s more is that you also ensure that there will be 18 days of extraordinary events to choose from and enjoy right here in Bournemouth.


We appreciate every penny, and depending on how many of those you can afford to give, there are a range of perks to choose from.


On top of this, our favourite local businesses have got on board to offer you some amazing discounts on their products and services during the Fringe dates.


Businesses supporting us with discount tickets include:

  • Crooked Book

  • Little Pickle Deli

  • The Factory Studios

  • Harry Ramsdens

  • Jalarra

  • Goat and Tricycle

  • Two Little Mocking Birds

  • Chaplin's & The Cellar Bar

  • + more


We've also got some goodie bags with all sorts or BEAF branded bits and bobs for you to keep.


PLUS One of our biggest local artistic exports, Stuart Semple has generously donated an original painting on paper for something truly unique to reward you for your support. 'YOU FILTHY ANIMAL'  Collage, spraypaint & acrylic on Saunders Waterford paper 25 x 25cm (9.8 x 9.8 inches) 2013

PLUS Orbital (www.orbital.co.uk), a well established local creative and digital agency is offering a FREE £175 SEO report for BEAF supporters. Delivered in PDF format this in-depth report will cover all technical aspects of your business website, however large or small. Using 3 keywords provided we will identify your current ranking on Google and make further keyword targeting recommendations and identify website issues and errors that are currently reducing your ranking on Google.


The Impact

Our main priority is our printed programme which we'd love to make 10,000 copies available to reach that many people and more. This will be the first year that a printed programme will be available. This is a quality designed programme to really set the benchmark for what we have on offer during the fringe. The programme is the ultimate exposure for those artists involved in the fringe who are organising and funding the events themselves.

Any surpluses will help us help the artists and volunteers in whatever way we can:

  • providing transport of artworks

  • lunches for invigilators

  • artwork description vinyls

  • paint

  • flyers


Risks & Challenges

We'd love this programme to be appearing all over Bournemouth (Coastal BID have promised to hand out some for us in London too!)  but of course we might not reach our goal . . . .what will we do then?


  • The festival is going ahead come-what-may, we are dedicated to delivering the biggest open access arts festival in Bournemouth.

  • The BEAF Team has some impressive credentials especially in the social media sphere, our current campaign reaching over 100k on facebook alone.

  • Momentum! The fringe is on a roll with over 170 submissions and artists, local businesses and organisations involved there's is no stopping us.


Our backup plan is to have the programme available digitally of course but this will certainly limit the impact of the festival and excludes those without internet and social media access.


Other Ways You Can Help

We always need more help! If you can assist with invigilating, building, making, moving, clicking . . . anything! we'd be happy to hear from you. Email the BEAF Team on: info@b-e-a-f.co.uk

We look forward to sharing this years Bournemouth Emerging Arts Fringe we all of you, thank you.

story:
Traveling Suitcase Installation Project

The process of compressing objects into their most compact and portable form has fascinated me since childhood. Portability translated into the potential for travel and adventure; the lure of unknown shores coupled with a self-sufficiency that transcended place. Much like the magic of Mary Poppins’s suitcase filled with an incomprehensible host of items and objects, I longed to conjure an illusion of the impossible. 

The Traveling Suitcase Installation Project is an attempt to reach that dream. The journey begins with a residency at Dundee Contemporary Art, in Dundee Scotland, to produce a series of large-scale woodcut prints that can compress into a suitcase and reanimate into a sculptural installation. Following the creation of the work in Dundee, the Traveling Suitcase Installation Project will embark on an expedition of short-term pop-up exhibitions in Dundee, Weimar, Berlin, and Venice. 

For each venue on the exhibition tour a vintage inspired Luggage Label is being produced. 

These Luggage Labels are being offered for your tax-deductible donation:

Traveling Suitcase Installation Project Official Luggage Label


Luggage Label for GENERATORprojects in Dundee, Scotland, and WerkStadt in Berlin, German.

If you can't contribute funds you can still take part!
You may be asking yourself in what other ways you can contribute to the campaign? Volunteering!  Social media is an excellent outlet for volunteering and in particular by sharing this unique URL to your favorite platform (or platforms) to help get the word out! The Traveling Suitcase Installation Project team understands that our community of friends, family and networks is our greatest champion.

story:
ABRAZO CARIBEÑO GRACIAS AL CIRCO

El pasado mes de diciembre de 2014, la organización sin fines de lucro, EDUCARE, Escuela de Circo, recibió la invitación de la Escuela Nacional de Circo de Cuba y del Centro Nacional de Escuelas de Arte (CNEArt), para participar en la segunda edición del Festival Pista Joven a celebrarse del 17 al 20 de febrero de 2015, en la Habana Cuba.  Por tal razón escogimos un estudiante representante del proyecto comunitario Circo Social, que atiende jóvenes en riesgo social de la comunidad de Dorado, Puerto Rico.  Luego de un arduo trabajo y entrenamiento por parte de nuestro joven Bryan Martínez y el director artístico Jafet Ramos Irizarry se sometió la solicitud para la participación de Bryan en este festival.  La ENC en Cuba y CNEArt aprobaron la participación de nuestro artista, siendo el PRIMER JOVEN PUERTORRIQUEÑO QUE REPRESENTARÁ A NUESTRO PAÍS en un festival de circo internacional!! CUBA NOS ESPERA!!! Por tal razón te invitamos a que aportes tu granito de arena a este intercambio fraternal Caribeño.  

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes

Para viajar a Cuba necesitamos:

  • 2 Pasajes y dos visas con un valor de $2,080.00
  • Gastos para estadía y comida aproximadamente entre $500 -$ 1,000
  • Los fondos que recaudemos mediante esta campaña se utilizarán para los gastos de pasajes, visas, estadía y alimento para lograr que Bryan nos represente.
  • Si aportas podrás obtener una recompensa: abrazos, talleres de circo espectáculos entre otras recompensas.  

Impacto

  • ¡Podrás aportar a que el proyecto Circo Social Puerto Rico logre una nueva meta y que nuestros jóvenes se motiven aún más! 
  • ¡Formarás parte de un intercambio fraternal entre dos tierras Caribeñas!
  • Será la primera vez que un joven puertorriqueño represente a Puerto Rico a nivel internacional gracias a las artes circenses.
  • Además, estarás aportando al Documental de la Historia del Circo en Puerto Rico.  Dirigido por Glorimar Sierra, quien acompañara a Bryan en esta aventura, para documentar información importante de nuestra historia del circo.  

Desafíos

EDUCARE es una Organización Sin Fines de Lucro, por tal razón necesitamos de tu ayuda para alcanzar nuestro objetivo: MONTAR A BRYAN EN UN AVIÓN PARA QUE REPRESENTE A NUESTRO PAÍS DIGNAMENTE. 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

No tienes que aportar grades cantidades si todos aportan un granito de arena podemos alcanzar nuestra meta:

  • Comparte nuestra campaña a tus familiares, amigos, compañeros, novi@s, abuelitos, vecinos, tíos, primos o a cualquier persona que pueda colaborar o que pueda pasar esta información.
  • Recuerda que puedes enviar esta campaña por las redes sociales, emails, etc.

MUCHAS PERO QUE MUCHAS GRACIAS POR SER PARTE DE ESTA AVENTURA!
story_txt:
ABRAZO CARIBEÑO GRACIAS AL CIRCO El pasado mes de diciembre de 2014, la organización sin fines de lucro, EDUCARE, Escuela de Circo, recibió la invitación de la Escuela Nacional de Circo de Cuba y del Centro Nacional de Escuelas de Arte (CNEArt), para participar en la segunda edición del Festival Pista Joven a celebrarse del 17 al 20 de febrero de 2015, en la Habana Cuba.  Por tal razón escogimos un estudiante representante del proyecto comunitario Circo Social, que atiende jóvenes en riesgo social de la comunidad de Dorado, Puerto Rico.  Luego de un arduo trabajo y entrenamiento por parte de nuestro joven Bryan Martínez y el director artístico Jafet Ramos Irizarry se sometió la solicitud para la participación de Bryan en este festival.  La ENC en Cuba y CNEArt aprobaron la participación de nuestro artista, siendo el PRIMER JOVEN PUERTORRIQUEÑO QUE REPRESENTARÁ A NUESTRO PAÍS en un festival de circo internacional!! CUBA NOS ESPERA!!! Por tal razón te invitamos a que aportes tu granito de arena a este intercambio fraternal Caribeño.     Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes Para viajar a Cuba necesitamos:  2 Pasajes y dos visas con un valor de $2,080.00 Gastos para estadía y comida aproximadamente entre $500 -$ 1,000
Los fondos que recaudemos mediante esta campaña se utilizarán para los gastos de pasajes, visas, estadía y alimento para lograr que Bryan nos represente.
Si aportas podrás obtener una recompensa: abrazos, talleres de circo espectáculos entre otras recompensas.  
   Impacto  ¡Podrás aportar a que el proyecto Circo Social Puerto Rico logre una nueva meta y que nuestros jóvenes se motiven aún más! 
¡Formarás parte de un intercambio fraternal entre dos tierras Caribeñas! 
Será la primera vez que un joven puertorriqueño represente a Puerto Rico a nivel internacional gracias a las artes circenses.  Además, estarás aportando al Documental de la Historia del Circo en Puerto Rico.  Dirigido por Glorimar Sierra, quien acompañara a Bryan en esta aventura, para documentar información importante de nuestra historia del circo.      Desafíos EDUCARE es una Organización Sin Fines de Lucro, por tal razón necesitamos de tu ayuda para alcanzar nuestro objetivo: MONTAR A BRYAN EN UN AVIÓN PARA QUE REPRESENTE A NUESTRO PAÍS DIGNAMENTE. 
    Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar  No tienes que aportar grades cantidades si todos aportan un granito de arena podemos alcanzar nuestra meta:   Comparte nuestra campaña a tus familiares, amigos, compañeros, novi@s, abuelitos, vecinos, tíos, primos o a cualquier persona que pueda colaborar o que pueda pasar esta información.  Recuerda que puedes enviar esta campaña por las redes sociales, emails, etc.   MUCHAS PERO QUE MUCHAS GRACIAS POR SER PARTE DE ESTA AVENTURA!

story:
Hello from Hartford!

The University of Hartford, Hartford Art School, Class of 2015 BFA photography majors need YOUR help!  We’ve been working hard for the past four years producing work and studying the craft of photography.  Our class consists of a diverse group of 12 photographers all producing unique work.  All of our hard work and dedication culminates in our BFA Senior Thesis Exhibition:

“Light Beyond the Looking Glass” 

opening in the 

Joseloff Gallery (West Hartford, CT) 

on April 25th, 2015

A lot of preparation goes into curating a show like this, and that’s where YOU come in!  Though we’ve been baking up a storm and satisfying sweet tooth’s across campus with our monthly bake sale fundraisers, we still need help raising the finances to cover refreshments for our guests, advertisement for our show, and most importantly, to help cover the cost of framing for all of our hard work! 

This exhibition marks an integral part of our lives as artists.  It will serve as the segway from our years as students to our future as professional working artists!  We want this event to be as enjoyable for you as it is momentous for us!

Any donation amount will help, but if you donate an amount of $25, $50, or $100 towards our $1000 goal, we will not only guarantee a killer exhibition, but we’ll send you each signed prints of our work!   Not to mention, you would have our undying gratitude for helping us achieve our goal! 

So what do you say? Lets make this a great, fun-filled night full of friends, food, and Photographs!

Even if you can’t contribute, that’s OK!  We need help spreading the word of our event to as many people as possible!


And don’t forget to click on the share icon for our Indiegogo page as well!

Thanks everyone! You rock!

story:
UTSA UNDERGROUND is a new project by the UTSA Music Marketing program that will present an evening of cross-disciplinary performances in the tunnel system below the Main Campus.

UTSA UNDERGROUND will showcase the hidden talents of the UTSA student body.  So many students on campus with unique talents are busy with class schedules and outside jobs.  The student sitting next to you in class could be a poet, rockstar, or a visual artist. This is an opportunity to present these unrecognized talents to the rest of the university in a place that is integral to the inner workings of the campus, yet largely unnoticed by the student body: the underground tunnel system.

Your contribution to our trail-blazing project will aid with production and marketing costs for this and future UNDERGROUND events.  Thank you for considering our project!

story:
What Is Perversion?

Perversion is a multimedia organization, featuring art, literature, music and fashion. Perversion revolves around one of the etymological roots of the word "perversion," which is something that has been corrupted from its original form. We aim to pervert traditional notions of art and expression to bring you what we find to be beautiful.

We feature artists from all over the world and accept submissions on a 24/7 basis via our website. We are currently based out of Jacksonville, Sarasota, Tallahassee, Newark (DE), and are expanding to more cities across the U.S with every passing week.

We released our inaugural issue, which was entirely self-funded, in April 2014, and we're excited to bring you Issue Two at the end of August. Our first print run was limited to a small quantity and was just a sample of what we can do. Although we're very proud of our first-born, we're even more excited about our sophomore debut.

And even though our hearts bleed ink for the world of print, the digital word is our mistress. On our website perversionmag.com we showcase and update content multiple times a week, and we also feature in-house video series such as The Yellow Apartment, The Simpletons, and more to come. 

The Yellow Apartment: Radio Birds Do Dishes from Perversion Magazine.


Why You Should Donate

With your help, we're hoping to quadruple in size with our second print run. We want to print about 2,000 magazines, so we can get them in as many venues as possible. It's our mission to get our magazine in the hands of more people that want to read them and become part of what we're doing.

We're also excited to continue with, and expand on, our in-house productions, procure office space in Jacksonville, and begin to pay our employees for all of the hard and beautiful work they consistently do.

We're not asking you to throw money at us blindly, either. We have tons of interesting items for you to purchase and enjoy while simultaneously supporting our cause. So join us and release your inner pervert.


Tokens of Our Affection

Yes, we have toys for you.

Some people like those things called shirts; we have 'em bundled with Issue Two. We'll also throw in a dashing PM sticker.

And if you're not into material goods, we have our Issue Two available in both print and digital download, and multiple combo bundles. Please understand that buying something from us isn't just a superficial, everyday commodity of consumption (that's a mouthful); it's also a way for you to support a group of people trying to make a difference in the art and publishing world. We love doing what we're doing, we love the content we get to feature, and it's our dream to continue perverting.

If you're unable to donate right now, show your support elsewhere by submitting your creative work to us, following us on our social media platforms (@perversionmag Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram), or by telling your Aunt, Stepmom, and milkman about us.

story:
Welcome to the indieGogo funding campaign for Double Dare Ya! 

Double Dare Ya will be a printed, full-colour anthology featuring comics, illustrations, essays, and interviews about and inspired by Riot Grrrl, zine culture, and punk rock feminism, including critiques of the movement in terms of inclusivity and examining its relevance in feminism today. Contributors range from UK and international comics artists and illustrators (such as Tom Humberstone, Lizz Lunney, Katie Skelly, Marc Ellerby, Laura Callaghan and more!), poets (Chrissy Williams and Amy Key), journalists/writers (such as Leigh Alexanders and Rhian E. Jones) and political activists (full list of contributors with links below!).

I’m thrilled to announce that the amazing Donya Todd will be on cover art. Donya is part of Comic Book Slumber Party, has edited the kick-ass girl anthology Bimba Comics, and has also published a book through Blank Slate, Death & The Girls, available at all good comic shops. Endpapers for the book will be designed by the superb Kristyna Baczynski.

The funding amount will cover printing of 200 copies of the book, as well as Hot Topic trading cards – contributor Steven Walsh, with the help of Hannah Chapman, will be making sets of 57 trading cards based on the names mentioned in the song Hot Topic by Le Tigre, all illustrated by different artists (list to follow). Here’s the song, if you’re unfamiliar! One random trading card will be included with every copy of the book, plus a couple of complete sets will be available as funding incentives.

Any amount that gets donated over the printing and postage plus profits of the sale of the book will be divided up amongst the contributors in payment for their artwork/writing. 

Meanwhile, here’s a list of the contributors so far, in alphabetical order (possibly more to be announced up until October):

Artists/writers: 

  • Sammy Borras
  • Sarah Broadhurst
  • Sarah Burgess
  • Laura Callaghan
  • Francesca Cassavetti
  • Lucie Ebrey
  • Marc Ellerby
  • Sarah Graley
  • Liz Greenfield
  • Sally-Anne Hickman
  • Tom Humberstone
  • Eleni Kalorkoti
  • Lizz Lunney
  • Lize Meddings
  • Jessica Penfold
  • Julia Scheele
  • Katie Skelly
  • Donya Todd

Writers:

  • Leigh Alexander
  • Alistair Bohm
  • Enna Cooper
  • Rhian E. Jones (whose featured piece you can read here as a preview!)
  • Amy Key
  • Becky Luff
  • Chrissy Williams

Incentives will include a 5-badge set with artwork from some of the contributors, a full Hot Topic trading card set, and two prints and/or personal commissions by editor and contributor Julia Scheele.

There will be more perks with contributions by other project artists added over the next few weeks!

The book will be officially launched at Thought Bubble convention in Leeds on the 15th of November - you can pick up your copy there or it'll be sent out afterwards!

story:
We Always Aim High

At GRMakers (http://www.grmakers.com), we don't settle for the safe option.  GRMakers is a Grand Rapids area co-working space dedicated to providing its community with a collaborative environment with access to a workshop where they can manufacture almost anything.  We have watched art rise from our space, businesses find success, and our members grow both in skill and in confidence.  When we were approached by our artist, Denise Langeweg, to help create one of the largest robotic LED light sculptures ArtPrize has ever seen, we knew we had to be involved.  After many months of discussion on what would make this a successful project, we identified our goals:

  • Recycle LED Light assemblies donated by Tekton Tools.
  • Occupy the entire four story glass stairwell at the Urban Institute of Contemporary Arts (UICA) and fill it with light.
  • Utilize our talented community members to design, fabricate and promote this project.
  • Create a unique collaborative experience for the ArtPrize audience.
"Exposed" is an interactive art installation that is built like a chandelier.  It hangs from the ceiling and begins as a 30 ft tall spiral structure brilliantly lit with approximately 30,000 LED lights.  What makes this sculpture unique is that audience interaction causes the top and bottom spirals to part in the middle and expose a sculpture hidden in the center.  Imagine a giant, tapered, brightly lit slinky opening on its own and you have a small idea of how amazing this is going to be.



This is going to be expensive...

Almost everything about this project is costly.  What we need:

  • Materials (metal, motors)
  • Machine time (waterjet)
  • Custom electronic controller boards and related wiring/hardware
  • Custom programming of controller
  • Insurance

Why this, why now?

Being artists, tinkerers, technologists, fabricators, and designers, we know we work best when we team up.  Collaboration is the focus of our community, GRMakers, and the the ArtPrize theme of our venue, the UICA.  We knew we had to be involved in a big way so we set our goals very high..., four stories high.
Why:
  • We want to show the ArtPrize community and its audience that art is accessible to everyone, not only by experiencing it, but also having the ability to create it.
  • We've had a number of our members create individual ArtPrize pieces before and have collaborated on others.  Last year, we were happy to collaborate on Gon Kirin (http://www.facebook.com/gonkirin) and help them be successful.
  • ArtPrize is the perfect opportunity to communicate this idealistic concept of participation in art and build our community of friends dedicated to an open, collaborative spirit.

What we face...

We have a thousand hours of work ahead of us before the opening of ArtPrize in September.  We always have the worry in the back of our minds, and hearts, of how we are going to afford each next step of the project.  More funding would help us to focus only on the process of creating a very ambitious project.

Our artist and our community of collaborators are talented, selfless individuals who are very excited about being part of this project.  They are intent on doing a world class job creating something that will be memorable to everyone who sees it, touches it, and interacts with it.

Progress To Date...

Laser cutting the steel 1/3 scale prototype:


    Half of 1/3 scale steel prototype hanging up at i3 Detroit:

    Machining the cone mounts:

    Servo Drive Motor donated by Kane Engineering:

    Extrusion, Linear Bearings, and accessories donated by Rapid Control:

    Final CAD Design:

    Salvaging LED Light Boards:


    Is there any other way else I can help?

    Yes, yes and more yes!  We need hands.  Many hands to help disassemble the light assemblies and get the LED boards ready for installation, to help with the welding the hundreds of feet of steel, to help program the custom boards for dynamic light control.  Simply put, yes, you can help.  You can be part of this.  You can be an artist with us!

    • Disassemble and prepare the LED boards for installation.
    • Assembly/assist in welding the hundreds of feet of steel.
    • Program the LED controller boards for dynamic light control.
    • Wire thousands of feet of wire.
    Yes, you can help.  You can be part of this.  You can be an artist with us!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Alex. Some of you will have known me long enough to know that my name could also be Alexxphoto or Alexx Legends based off of what geological part of the country you live in. Greetings long lost friends. 

I am looking to fund a new wave of work that is apart of a life long project I am doing titled Everything Beyond Hindsight. The work is somewhat my own realization that I have no roots anywhere and its terrifying and amazingly freeing at the same time. It celebrates every possible emotion one can feel being a career gypsy especially love, loss, desire and loneliness; things that come often when you move as much as i do.

You can see more here http://aintbadmagazine.com/Alex-Christopher-Wil...

The intention of this fundraiser is to reconnect with all of you and to continue to have stories to photograph and tell. I will be flying to Atlanta for a week and then doing a short stint in New Orleans to see my coast family; PSKY, Mordechai, AFFOF, TS,TW... I hope that all of you could join me at Beaus place for some great times.

What I Need & What You Get

So here is what I need to make a Gulf Coast retreat to happen:

  • If I buy the plane tickets far enough in advance it will cost $350 and the greyhound ticket to New Orleans will cost $90
  • What I can offer as a huge thank you is an 8x10 print from the trip and a love letter filled full of sweet ready made goodies that I find along the way.
  • As I don't fully expect to raise enough money in time, Ill have to be honest. If there is no way to refund you, ITS GOING STRAIGHT TO RENT because lets be honest I live in New York City. BUT BUT BUT, I will still include 8x10 prints to send out to those who contributed!

The Impact

If you contribute to my escape from the concrete jungle, you will more than likely receive a text message from me at 1030pm asking to crash on your floor. You'll also receive many questions, requests and otherwise for me to take your photograph. I will also make you dinner and play with your cat at no extra cost; this all comes with the package deal. Where can you go wrong?

Risks & Challenges

Since I work on a freelance basis, it will be very difficult to navigate how successful this project will be and whether or not I should be booking shoots during that time. I would love to come down before thanksgiving to see Travis and Oktawian's thesis show. That will also be a great time because no one will have left the city for the holidays yet. However, I wouldn't be opposed to waiting until early December either.

Other Ways You Can Help

Buy me a beer and tell me you wish you could move to New York City. I wont judge you.

The intention of this fundraiser is to reconnect with all of you and to continue to have stories to photograph and tell. I will be flying to Atlanta for a week and then doing a short stint in New Orleans to see my coast family; PSKY, Mordechai, AFFOF, TS,TW... I hope that all of you could join me at Beaus place for some great times.
  What I Need & What You Get So here is what I need to make a Gulf Coast retreat to happen: 
If I buy the plane tickets far enough in advance it will cost $350 and the greyhound ticket to New Orleans will cost $90
 What I can offer as a huge thank you is an 8x10 print from the trip and a love letter filled full of sweet ready made goodies that I find along the way.
 As I don't fully expect to raise enough money in time, Ill have to be honest. If there is no way to refund you, ITS GOING STRAIGHT TO RENT because lets be honest I live in New York City. BUT BUT BUT, I will still include 8x10 prints to send out to those who contributed!
 
  The ImpactIf you contribute to my escape from the concrete jungle, you will more than likely receive a text message from me at 1030pm asking to crash on your floor. You'll also receive many questions, requests and otherwise for me to take your photograph. I will also make you dinner and play with your cat at no extra cost; this all comes with the package deal. Where can you go wrong?
  Risks & ChallengesSince I work on a freelance basis, it will be very difficult to navigate how successful this project will be and whether or not I should be booking shoots during that time. I would love to come down before thanksgiving to see Travis and Oktawian's thesis show. That will also be a great time because no one will have left the city for the holidays yet. However, I wouldn't be opposed to waiting until early December either.
  Other Ways You Can HelpBuy me a beer and tell me you wish you could move to New York City. I wont judge you.

story:
What's this all about?

I’m going to Korea!  I’ve already bought the tickets, booked a residence & shipped the art!

Who am I?

Hi!  My name is Sara, and I’m a fractal artist!  What’s a fractal?  Fractals are essentially infinitely repeating mathematical patterns.  And I am totally obsessed with them!  They are everywhere in nature- the branching structure of trees, for example, is a type of fractal pattern.  Self-similarity is the key feature of any fractal:  simple patterns & forms that are repeated at all scales.  What you get is a structure of infinite complexity, derived from a very simple set of rules.

An artist who likes math?

Yep.  I’ve always loved science & nature, so I couldn’t pass up the chance to go to the local Science & Technology magnet high school.  But I also grew up in a home that fostered creativity and a love of art.  So when I decided to go to the Maryland Institute College of Art, I knew that I needed to find a way to bring my two loves together!  Fractals are the perfect marriage of science, mathematics & art.  So much beauty can be derived from these amazing mathematical patterns!  And I want to show them to the world!

So why Korea?

I’ve recently been presented with a FANTASTIC opportunity: To show my work at the Annual Bridges Art & Mathematics Conference!  This week-long conference is dedicated to “bridging” the gap between math & art.  Just like I am!  And it will be filled with amazing artists, professors, mathematicians and other talented & creative folks with the same passion as me!  And *I* get to share my work with them!  This year the conference is being held in Seoul, South Korea.  (Woah)  But I couldn’t pass up the opportunity to travel to a new, exotic place & meet all of these amazing like-minded people.  

The Drifters Series:

Selected for Bridges Seoul 2014


My hope is that this will be a transformative experience for me.  This will be my first solo trip to a foreign land!  I’ll get to talk to people from around the world, and share ideas about math & art, meet an idol or two, and maybe even learn some new techniques. And of course be inspired to create all kinds of new fractal art!

Where do you come in?

Well, as you can imagine, Trips to Korea do not come cheap!  Aside from airfare & lodging, it also costs money to prepare & ship my artwork that will be on display at the conference, as well as the registration fee for the conference itself.  So that’s where you come in.  Regardless of the funds that I raise here, I AM going to Korea!  It’s a done deal.  But I hope that a few people in this amazing community will offer a little support to my cause.  I will be in your debt forever (and you’ll get cool stuff too!)  ; )

Like fractal magnets, or prints!



What happens next?

I'll continue to post cool videos and updates on my campaign progress- keeping you informed about my preparations for the trip, perk production & general math artiness!  I'll also be posting videos straight from the Bridges 2014 Conference in Seoul.  You'll get to follow along on this exciting new adventure WITH ME! 


Thanks!  See you in Korea!  <3


Links:

Infinite Creature Designs (Me!)

www.infinitecreature.net
Infinite Creature on Facebook

2014 Bridges Conference

Bridges Seoul 2014
Bridges Exhibition Gallery

Fractals & Other Math-y Things

Wiki - Fractals
Wiki - Flexagons

Special Thanks to my friends!

Pearl and the Beard
and
AFRU Gallery

story:
Are you sick of artists being asked to do something for free?  Here’s your chance to join a good cause!

The sixth edition of L.A.’s premier performance art gathering will present over 40 performers, distributed across a host of Chinatown galleries and public spaces on the 26th of July between 12 Noon and 10 PM.

This Indiegogo campaign is to raise funds in order to pay the performers of Perform Chinatown for the first time.  We’ve got art, music and commemorative T-shirts in exchange for your contributions, which will be divided equally amongst the performers.  Even if you can’t donate anything, please share this campaign on your social media sites.  Thank you for your help!

This year’s rendition pools the complementary curatorial talents of Doug Harvey (Chain Letter, LA Weekly Annual Biennials), Lee Lynch (The Murder of Hi Good, headmaster of Teenage Wasteland of the Arts), and Paige Wery (Artillery magazine, The Good Luck Gallery).

Perform Chinatown 2014 : CHAOS REIGNS! stretches the boundaries of Performance Art to include live experimental music, historical reenactments, survivalist workshops, guided meditation rituals, chess tournaments, poetry, dance, video, and food – as well as the cutting edge New Genre happenings that define the field.

SO FAR Participating venues include The Good Luck Gallery, Melody Lounge, Human Resources, Jancar Gallery, The Public School, Formerly Fong’s, KK Gallery, Outpost, Actual Size, Coagula Curatorial, Cause Gallery, Jancar Gallery, The Grand Star, Smaller Form Space, Skunkworks, Scoops and more!

SO FAR 2014 Performer List: Reverend Ethan Acres, China Adams, Bas Jan Ader, The ALHAMBRA Chinese-American Children’s Choir, Joshua Aster, Patrick Ballard, Tony Banuelos, Genevieve Belleveau, Don Bolles, Gul Cagin, Kristin Cammermeyer, Charmaine's Names, Claudia Cano, Connie, Ben Cuevas, Christian Cummings, Steve Craig, Ben Cuevas, Michael Decker and Broc Smith, Joe Deutch, Dani Dodge, Dog the Bounty Hunter, Kate Durbin, Earth Like Planets, Everything is Terrible, F (Marnie Weber, Doug Harvey, & Daniel Hawkins), Matt Fielder, Simone Gad, Pascale Georgiev & Kingston Trinder, Kio Griffith & Ted Byrnes, Hell(O) (Martin Durazo, Ichiro Irie, Mike Dee), Inmo, Angie Jennings, Amy Kaps, KCHUNG, Keith Walsh Experience, Ali Kheradyar, John Kilduff, Zachary Kleyn, Mannlicher Carcano, Audrey Moyer, Raphael Noz, Atsuko Okatsuka, Mariko Passion, Sarah Petersen & Veronique d'Entremont, Mary Anna Pomonis, Al Ridenour, steve roden, Guan Rong, Ross Rudel, Matthew Savitsky, Michael Q. Schmidt, Greg Shank, Molly Shea, Aaron Sheppard with Sylvia Welch, Joey Skaggs, Skunkworks (Crystal Erienson, Patricia Burns, Charlie Minchenberg, & Andrea Breiling), Brad Spence, Chris Springer, "StarryKitchen" (Marisa Williamson and Lex Brown), The Tin Woodsman, Tiny Top Pataphysical Circus, Jason Triefenbach, Tupac, Urban Crop Circle/Sumi Ink Club, Christine Wertheim, Miggie Wong, Wounded Lion, Aaron Wrinkle, Yarnbombing Los Angeles, and more!

story:
Hi! We are the Iron Monkeys.

Founded in 2006, the Iron Monkeys are a metalworking collective based in Seattle, Washington. Known primarily for forging heavy industrial steel into intricate, delicate patterns, we have progressed from making small, stand-alone steel sculptures to creating large-scale multifaceted gathering spaces which increasingly incorporate propane fire elements. 

And we are back for 2014!



The story of the Agora of Light.

In 2014, we decided to build upon the mythology of the Guardian of Dawn from 2013.  The Guardian of Dawn was a project about fearing the unknown. The Guardian served as the protector of the Acolytes, keeping them safe and warm amidst the darkness.  This year, the Acolytes have developed an unquenchable curiosity and, with the blessing of the Guardian, have ventured out into the darkness seeking their own light.



Each night of their travels the Acolytes build a fire and gather around the flames. They recreate home. Applying lessons learned from the Guardian they create a warm, welcoming gathering space. It’s what they know best, and they do it well. In the face of so much that is unknown and unknowable their nightly conclave in the Agora of Light is a comforting talisman, a necessary piece of familiarity. 

After countless sunrises, sunsets and nights telling stories around the fire, a nascent wisdom emerges within the Acolytes. Their stories  coalesce into something that is not uniquely of them and yet is not foreign. Certain words begin to resonate: Temperance, Honor, Gratitude, Courage, Wisdom, Justice. These words are the catalysts of interaction in the Agora of Light, and a fresh understanding - one born of experience rather than acceptance - emerges.

Won't you come in out of the dark?


Cool, but what is it going to look like?

The  Agora of Light is a 60-foot-wide circular plaza.  Its outside edge is defined by 3 sets of columns and 3 sets of curved benches.  Standing on either side of these benches will be LED-illuminated Acolytes.  



Seating is a very important component for us this year, and as such we are building 3 sets of 3 pull out benches. These benches will decrease in height as they pull into the center, creating amphitheater-type seating. 

We are also building a 36-foot-wide center pavilion for the Agora.  This pavilion will be built out of 4'x8' steel petals.  Some of the petals will be made of sheet steel which will be piped with propane flame effects, and the rest of the petals will be covered in steel screen.  Our goal with the pavilion is to provide a shaded place in the day, and a warm gathering space at night for participants.  We will be bringing the pavilion to Critical Northwest for a trial run in late July.

And finally, we are building 3 new Fire Zen Gardens for the Agora of Light.  These Zen Gardens will be placed inside the Agora to allow people to warm up while playing with fire.


Your help matters!!

We need your help to make Agora of Light come to light!  There is no way we could create our art without the support of our community.  In fact over 50% of our revenue is through your contributions, and we thank you greatly for that.

Here's what we need to make this community space become a reality:

  • Steel to create 
  • Trucks to transport
  • Fuel to travel
  • Propane to light it up!
  • Welding wire and gas
  • Sanding disks, oxygen, propane, drill bits, and other consumables
  • Storage space as we build
  • More steel and screen


The thank you gifts:

Commemorative Brass Coins - Each hand stamped and numbered



Chain Mail AGORA Coin Bracelet


Monkey Tail Pendents


The 6 virtues coin necklace : Temperance, Honor, Gratitude, Courage, Wisdom, and Justice


Stickers



T-shirts and hoodies (This is last year's version)


Iron Monkey Fire Pit.  This fire pit is about 35-inches-wide at the top, and the bowl is about a foot deep.




The Iron Monkey Crew

The Iron Monkey Crew is made up of between 12 and 16 people.  We are teachers, doctors, animal whisperers, tech folks, coffee experts, photographers, entrepreneurs, and generally normal-ish people.  We all volunteer our time to make and bring our art to events in Seattle, Black Rock City and beyond.  We very much hope you enjoy it.



Other Ways You Can Help

There's more than one way to help us!

  • Spread the word! Share our campaign with your friends and family!
  • If you are in the Seattle area come to our events at Equinox Studio!  Check our Facebook page or website for dates and info.
  • Purchase Playa Staples, and keep your camp from flying away!

http://www.ironmonkeyarts.org/buy-playa-staples.html


And, don't forget to stop by and say, "Hi!" to us on playa, during the Georgetown art walks and at Critical Northwest!
