story:
Back Story

I'm Rocky, the owner of White Dragon Paper, LLC.    White Dragon Paper is a small business that started in 2007 when I got bored over the summer between semesters at my community college.  I started with about $20 worth of supplies from the thrift store and some internet tutorials.  Over the past 8 years I've gone from working out of a plastic tub in my basement to collaborating with other handmade paper artists, sharing studio space and equipment, and expanding my products to include hand bound books and stationary.  It's become a part time job that allows me to do the work I love and still get my bills paid.

 Vision

Paper is EVERYWHERE. It's so prevalent in our daily lives it becomes static in many people's minds.  When I tell people that I make paper, the most common assumption is that I make origami, or cards, or some other art using ready-made commercial papers.  I have to explain first that, yes I make cards and books, but first, before anything else, I have to create the sheets of paper I am going to use.  Many people see paper as a medium on which to make art, not a medium out of which art can be made.  I like to challenge that notion by focusing on the paper itself when making my art.  I want to reduce wasted paper and cardboard, give new life to old materials, make human connections through my work, and give back to the communities that have made White Dragon Paper what it is today.

Through White Dragon Paper I try to share this perspective with as many people as I can.  Exposing young kids to this idea early puts the idea into their head to question materials and art, and inspires them to use old materials in new ways.  Art fosters creativity, confidence, and curiosity.  I often talk to people who say they made paper in scouts or at school using dryer lint, or are familiar with paper mache.  Through White Dragon Paper, I want to follow up on these initial, basic exposures and teach people to look at paper that they were going to throw away, and think "Who can use this?  Can I do something more with it?"

These expansions and collaborations have allowed me to do wonderful things, including expending my business products lines and giving back to the community. In the summer of 2014 I volunteered to teach paper-making to a camp full of kids who have or have had cancer, for a full week (and I'm excited to have been invited back this summer).  This year I've been contacted by some local libraries to teach recycled paper arts to their teens.

So why have I started this campaign?

I am currently renting the use of a Reina paper beater from one of my studio roommates.  The Reina paper beater is a particular brand of Hollander beater, a machine that churns recycled office paper, cardboard, or plant fibers up into a mush that can then be used to make sheets of new paper.  New, these machines cost upwards of $9000 depending on the model and size.  Some sell for $16k.  Finding these machines used is like finding a blue lobster.  It happens, but people tend to hang on to their paper beaters as long as they can because there aren't many of them made, they're expensive, and they're easier to repair than replace if they break down.  When a used beater does pop up for sale, the seller has their pick of offers.

An opportunity to purchase a Valley paper beater (the little brother to the Reina beater) fell into our lap.  I won't always be located in Columbus where I am able to share equipment with the artist I currently rent usage from.  My girlfriend is in the last years of her Masters program for Library and Information Science.  She may get a job out of state after she graduates, and I'll go with her with our two rescued dogs, rabbit, and fish in tow.  When we move, I will need to have a paper beater to go with me so I can continue my paper-making.  Fundraising $9000-$16000 to purchase a paper beater new is a much steeper goal than the $3000 this artist is asking for his used Valley model.  The additional $1000 of this campaign's goal is going to be used to cover materials and shipping for perks, as well as to make sure we end up with a lump sum of $3000 to hand the artist as payment for the Valley beater after all the fees and taxes are taken out (approximately 10%) of the money raised.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $4000 to cover the complete cost of this goal.  $3000 will go directly to the artist we are purchasing the Valley Beater from.  We expect 10% of the raised funds to go toward fees and taxes, and the remaining $600 is going to cover materials and shipping for all of the great perks we're offering to those who help!

All of our perks will put in your hands something that embodies the core principles of White Dragon Paper, LLC.  They will include paper hand made by me from 100% recycled materials and books made with recycled, upcycled, and scrap materials.

Perks include a hand written thank you card, book key chains, a personal journal/sketchbook, and gift packs of various handmade papers, books, and recycled paper items.

Of course, there is the risk that we won't meet our funding goal.  Should we fall vastly short and only raise a few hundred dollars, we will used the accrued funds to purchase more materials to donate toward our volunteer service at the camp this summer.  We already volunteer a week of our time, as well as certain equipment, but the camp organizers purchase all the consumable materials we need for the week such as fiber, wood, and dye.  If we make it half way or should we fall just a few hundred dollars shy of our goal, we will look into additional sources of donations to cover the gap after the IndieGoGo campaign has ended.

What will we do if we raise more than $4000?  Well, first of all that would be AWESOME.  What we would do with the extra money would depend on how MUCH more we raise.  A few dollars?  We'll send it toward the summer camp to help cover supplies for our week in 2015.  $1-500?  We'll reach out to the Columbus, Ohio community to sponsor as many free workshops for local kids and teens as we can afford with it.  A thousand extra?  We'll sponsor local workshops, and purchase a pop up tent for the studio to use on bright sunny days for festivals, workshops, and community projects.  Thousands more?  We'll sponsor several workshops for the local community, buy the tent, and put the remainder of the funds toward purchasing a small, used pickup truck to transport all the equipment we use for workshops and festivals.

How Paper Can Impact the World

Paper-making is my passion.  I got so hooked with those first few sheets of paper that I made in 2007 that I never stopped.  I didn't worry about how big this could get or how I would affect so many people.  I just made the paper and rode the waves that came from the ripples I created.

By contributing to this project, you will be fueling my passion.  You'll be helping me keep boxes upon boxes of used paper out of the landfills.  Your impact will be with me as I pulverize each batch of paper and pull each sheet.  You will have helped each sheet and each book or each child's project come into being and go on to impact someone else's life when they use it to record their poetry or send invitations to their wedding.  Not only will you be supporting a small business that is dedicated to giving back to small communities, you'll be supporting one that also is very conscious of its impact on the global community.  We work to find ways to reduce the largest category of waste produced by Americans each year, and in doing so also foster creativity, exploration, curiosity, and out-of-the-box thinking in the young kids who will be decision-making adults in a few years time.

White Dragon Paper, LLC started very small, but has continued to see steady annual growth in both annual revenue and community involvement.  I want to continue this trend, and having a Valley Paper Beater of my own would mean that no matter where I go in the future, I'll have what I need to continue the work of White Dragon Paper, and continue spreading the word about how wonderful recycled paper is.

Risks and the Game Plan

Our biggest risk is not meeting our goal.  Unfortunately you can't buy just a piece of this machine. In order to be able to take advantage of this unique bit of fortune, we need to raise all of the funds.  In order to meet our full goal, I am setting up this campaign as a "home base" at which donors and interested parties can track our progress.  Beyond the web though, I will be approaching individuals and groups that have been supportive or expressed interest in my work over the years, and talking to as many new people as will listen.  I will be utilizing social media such as Facebook (White Dragon Paper, LLC) and Twitter (@WhiteDragonPapr) to spread the word and reach more potential donors.  I try to think of it this way: At most, we need 4000 people to donate $1.  But if we can get everyone to donate $100, we only need 40.  So we need to get somewhere between 40 and 4000 people to contribute.  We can do that right?  I think so!

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you just can't donate right now, but you can still be a crucial, massively helpful part of this campaign by using IndieGoGo's share tools to spread the word, and sharing my posts on Twitter (@WhiteDragonPapr) and Facebook (White Dragon Paper, LLC) as we move through this campaign.  Any support is welcomed.
story_txt:
Back Story I'm Rocky, the owner of White Dragon Paper, LLC.    White Dragon Paper is a small business that started in 2007 when I got bored over the summer between semesters at my community college.  I started with about $20 worth of supplies from the thrift store and some internet tutorials.  Over the past 8 years I've gone from working out of a plastic tub in my basement to collaborating with other handmade paper artists, sharing studio space and equipment, and expanding my products to include hand bound books and stationary.  It's become a part time job that allows me to do the work I love and still get my bills paid.

 Vision
Paper is EVERYWHERE. It's so prevalent in our daily lives it becomes static in many people's minds.  When I tell people that I make paper, the most common assumption is that I make origami, or cards, or some other art using ready-made commercial papers.  I have to explain first that, yes I make cards and books, but first, before anything else, I have to create the sheets of paper I am going to use.  Many people see paper as a medium on which to make art, not a medium out of which art can be made.  I like to challenge that notion by focusing on the paper itself when making my art.  I want to reduce wasted paper and cardboard, give new life to old materials, make human connections through my work, and give back to the communities that have made White Dragon Paper what it is today.
Through White Dragon Paper I try to share this perspective with as many people as I can.  Exposing young kids to this idea early puts the idea into their head to question materials and art, and inspires them to use old materials in new ways.  Art fosters creativity, confidence, and curiosity.  I often talk to people who say they made paper in scouts or at school using dryer lint, or are familiar with paper mache.  Through White Dragon Paper, I want to follow up on these initial, basic exposures and teach people to look at paper that they were going to throw away, and think "Who can use this?  Can I do something more with it?"
These expansions and collaborations have allowed me to do wonderful things, including expending my business products lines and giving back to the community. In the summer of 2014 I volunteered to teach paper-making to a camp full of kids who have or have had cancer, for a full week (and I'm excited to have been invited back this summer).  This year I've been contacted by some local libraries to teach recycled paper arts to their teens.
So why have I started this campaign?
I am currently renting the use of a Reina paper beater from one of my studio roommates.  The Reina paper beater is a particular brand of Hollander beater, a machine that churns recycled office paper, cardboard, or plant fibers up into a mush that can then be used to make sheets of new paper.  New, these machines cost upwards of $9000 depending on the model and size.  Some sell for $16k.  Finding these machines used is like finding a blue lobster.  It happens, but people tend to hang on to their paper beaters as long as they can because there aren't many of them made, they're expensive, and they're easier to repair than replace if they break down.  When a used beater does pop up for sale, the seller has their pick of offers.
An opportunity to purchase a Valley paper beater (the little brother to the Reina beater) fell into our lap.  I won't always be located in Columbus where I am able to share equipment with the artist I currently rent usage from.  My girlfriend is in the last years of her Masters program for Library and Information Science.  She may get a job out of state after she graduates, and I'll go with her with our two rescued dogs, rabbit, and fish in tow.  When we move, I will need to have a paper beater to go with me so I can continue my paper-making.  Fundraising $9000-$16000 to purchase a paper beater new is a much steeper goal than the $3000 this artist is asking for his used Valley model.  The additional $1000 of this campaign's goal is going to be used to cover materials and shipping for perks, as well as to make sure we end up with a lump sum of $3000 to hand the artist as payment for the Valley beater after all the fees and taxes are taken out (approximately 10%) of the money raised.   What We Need & What You Get We need $4000 to cover the complete cost of this goal.  $3000 will go directly to the artist we are purchasing the Valley Beater from.  We expect 10% of the raised funds to go toward fees and taxes, and the remaining $600 is going to cover materials and shipping for all of the great perks we're offering to those who help!
All of our perks will put in your hands something that embodies the core principles of White Dragon Paper, LLC.  They will include paper hand made by me from 100% recycled materials and books made with recycled, upcycled, and scrap materials.
Perks include a hand written thank you card, book key chains, a personal journal/sketchbook, and gift packs of various handmade papers, books, and recycled paper items.
Of course, there is the risk that we won't meet our funding goal.  Should we fall vastly short and only raise a few hundred dollars, we will used the accrued funds to purchase more materials to donate toward our volunteer service at the camp this summer.  We already volunteer a week of our time, as well as certain equipment, but the camp organizers purchase all the consumable materials we need for the week such as fiber, wood, and dye.  If we make it half way or should we fall just a few hundred dollars shy of our goal, we will look into additional sources of donations to cover the gap after the IndieGoGo campaign has ended.

What will we do if we raise more than $4000?  Well, first of all that would be AWESOME.  What we would do with the extra money would depend on how MUCH more we raise.  A few dollars?  We'll send it toward the summer camp to help cover supplies for our week in 2015.  $1-500?  We'll reach out to the Columbus, Ohio community to sponsor as many free workshops for local kids and teens as we can afford with it.  A thousand extra?  We'll sponsor local workshops, and purchase a pop up tent for the studio to use on bright sunny days for festivals, workshops, and community projects.  Thousands more?  We'll sponsor several workshops for the local community, buy the tent, and put the remainder of the funds toward purchasing a small, used pickup truck to transport all the equipment we use for workshops and festivals.
How Paper Can Impact the World
 Paper-making is my passion.  I got so hooked with those first few sheets of paper that I made in 2007 that I never stopped.  I didn't worry about how big this could get or how I would affect so many people.  I just made the paper and rode the waves that came from the ripples I created.
By contributing to this project, you will be fueling my passion.  You'll be helping me keep boxes upon boxes of used paper out of the landfills.  Your impact will be with me as I pulverize each batch of paper and pull each sheet.  You will have helped each sheet and each book or each child's project come into being and go on to impact someone else's life when they use it to record their poetry or send invitations to their wedding.  Not only will you be supporting a small business that is dedicated to giving back to small communities, you'll be supporting one that also is very conscious of its impact on the global community.  We work to find ways to reduce the largest category of waste produced by Americans each year, and in doing so also foster creativity, exploration, curiosity, and out-of-the-box thinking in the young kids who will be decision-making adults in a few years time.
White Dragon Paper, LLC started very small, but has continued to see steady annual growth in both annual revenue and community involvement.  I want to continue this trend, and having a Valley Paper Beater of my own would mean that no matter where I go in the future, I'll have what I need to continue the work of White Dragon Paper, and continue spreading the word about how wonderful recycled paper is.   Risks and the Game Plan Our biggest risk is not meeting our goal.  Unfortunately you can't buy just a piece of this machine. In order to be able to take advantage of this unique bit of fortune, we need to raise all of the funds.  In order to meet our full goal, I am setting up this campaign as a "home base" at which donors and interested parties can track our progress.  Beyond the web though, I will be approaching individuals and groups that have been supportive or expressed interest in my work over the years, and talking to as many new people as will listen.  I will be utilizing social media such as Facebook (White Dragon Paper, LLC) and Twitter (@WhiteDragonPapr) to spread the word and reach more potential donors.  I try to think of it this way: At most, we need 4000 people to donate $1.  But if we can get everyone to donate $100, we only need 40.  So we need to get somewhere between 40 and 4000 people to contribute.  We can do that right?  I think so!
    Other Ways You Can Help  I understand if you just can't donate right now, but you can still be a crucial, massively helpful part of this campaign by using IndieGoGo's share tools to spread the word, and sharing my posts on Twitter (@WhiteDragonPapr) and Facebook (White Dragon Paper, LLC) as we move through this campaign.  Any support is welcomed.

story:
My name is Stacey. I am a full time artist who designs enamel pins.

I started @oldstoriesph on Instagram as a way for me to share my art and designs to the world.

This campaign is a step to making my work as an artist into a brand that creates fun, collectible and wearable art through the help and support of people in this community. It is my second pin campaign so far and I really hope to share them to the world. ♥

INITIAL FACTS:

1. This is a FIXED funding campaign.

- Funds will be returned at the end of the campaign if the initial goal is not met.

2. SURVEYS will be sent to all backers via e-mail when the campaign ends.

-Remember to check your emails if you have backed this project. This is where you will choose which designs you are ordering.

3. Please make sure to double-check your shipping information and email.

- To make sure that your pins arrive safely to the correct addresses and that I may easily contact you for future updates.

4. Lastly, if you're interested in any designs that are not yet unlocked, don't hesitate to make your pledge so we can all reach the goals and unlock them together! :D Thank you!

 

THE COLLECTION

This collection focuses on childhood favorites from the first two generations of the Poke mon games. I named the collection "Ace Trainer" because I chose Pokemon that you would encounter from Ace Trainers (NPC's that you battle) in the game - mostly in or on your way to Victory Road. These are fully evolved and more commonly used 'mons for battle. I wanted to make them look fierce and powerful but still cute at the same time. I also made sure to choose one mon of each type! ♥

***ALL PINS will be priced regularly at $12 after the end of the campaign***

This is because the designs are very detailed and there are many colors.

***ALL PINS will be priced regularly at $12 after the end of the campaign***
Look out for more designs as we reach higher funding goals!
Sticker sheets and prints of all designs are also available for purchase separately!
 

FUNDS

To have enamel pins produced is a lengthy and costly process and can only be made using the funds from this campaign if the minimum goal is met. I will be shipping and managing everything from the Philippines, but I will be having them made outside of the country by a manufacturer that I trust with producing only high quality pins.

These funds go completely to:

- 85% Manufacturing and shipping.

- 10% Backing cards and packaging materials.

- 5% Indiegogo Fees.

Every backer of this campaign receives extra benefits in the form of discounts and freebies.
 
 
 

Production and Shipping Timeline:

Once the funding campaign has ended, production can begin. It takes about a month to manufacture.

After grading and packing all orders I'll be shipping them via local post. All mail is registered and can ship anywhere internationally. This usually takes 2-4 weeks with a tracking number. (Not accounting for possible delays)

If everything goes smoothly, your package will arrive by Feb/March, 2019. You may always contact me for any inquiries regarding your package.

 

Risks & Challenges

***Please note that this timeline is only if no manufacturing and/or shipping delays occur. I have no control over the manufacturing side (and if there are defects I may have them remade because I wont send defective products) and I also have no control after I have released your package for delivery. This is an estimate time and some packages may arrive sooner/later than others.***

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount of support that anyone could ever give is very much appreciated.

If you can share this campaign in any way, please do - and a big thank you to you!

Indiegogo has share tools available to share on other social media platforms.

You may also check or tag my main page on Instagram @oldstoriesph where I post all my updates and announcements outside of Indiegogo. Thank you so much!

story:
Short Summary

The art of gigposter design is a genre in and of itself; however, its merits are often denied. It's a blind task, illustrating a show that has yet to be seen, to fit a tone that hasn't been set. What was once an incentive for fans to leave a concert, now causes those fans to swarm the merch table after; it's a diverse art form melding music and imagery. A solid poster not only encapsulates the experience of a fantastic show, but solidifies the memory. 

We rarely get such a solid exhibition of East coast gigposter designers in our area, and it's such a shame, seeing that New York and the East coast in general have so much talent to offer.  This gallery will highlight some of that amazing talent, showing beautiful posters created for incredibly talented bands by amazing artists; the artists we chose to highlight will showcase various different styles of poster design from several different genres of music.

In keeping with the DIY spirit of gigposter design, this exhibition will be held at a local print studio in Gowanus Brooklyn.  If inspiration should strike you, you'll have the opportunity to take classes teaching you the basics of screen-printing!

Why Donate?

Donating funds keeps this show free to the public; we want to get as many people in the doors as possible so they can witness this exciting and vast (although often overlooked) genre of artwork.

All funds will go to renting out the space for the gallery, hanging the work, refreshments, and any relevant shipping costs.  Poster sales go to the artist.

Poster shows are not entirely common in New York, and it's important that we establish a presence in this community as well as show the general public that the art of gigposter design is an exciting and broad genre!

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough, if you can't contribute please spread the word and help us reach our goal!  And, of course, come on out to the show on June 22nd 2012!

story:
What we do:

Creations for Charity is an annual fundraising event to give new and official Lego sets to underprivileged children during the holidays.

We have a unique way of doing this. We raise money by selling custom Lego creations made by Lego builders from all over the world. Since 2009, we raised about $17,000 and donated over 1,100 brand new Lego sets to organizations like Toys for Tots, Make-A-Wish, and childrens hospitals across multiple cities in the US.

This year we are expanding our donations to two countries outside the US: Chile and Croatia, and we need a lot more funds to buy enough Lego to make this happen. This is why we launched this campaign.


What we need and what you get:

When you make a donation or purchase a custom Lego creation, you will help us buy new and official Lego sets for the children. If the feeling of knowing that you have brightened the holidays of a child in need isn't enough, then check out these incentives:

Perks

  • Wristband printed with Creations for Charity and our icon.

  • Ornament printed with our logo.

  • A magnet made entirely out of Lego elements featuring a custom printed tile with our logo and two custom-chromed red bricks.

Commission a custom creation from an experienced Lego builder! Take a look at examples of what we can build for you:

Please note: pending the number of commissions we receive, commissioned creations are not guaranteed to arrive before Christmas as each will take hours or days to design and build.

If you're a Lego builder and would like to donate a creation, we would be happy to add it to our store!

Where does the money go?

A small portion of our funds goes towards making these awesome thank-you gifts you just saw, and the rest is used to buy Lego for the kids. We have distribution coordinators in our donation areas who will be scouting out the biggest sales on Lego so we get the most bricks for our buck. We typically buy Lego sets at more than 40% off!

We donate the Lego sets to organizations that specialize in distributing toys to children in need. They include Toys for Tots, Make-A-Wish, childrens hospitals, and orphanages. This year, we will be donating in Chicago, Dallas, Grand Rapids, Los Angeles, Chile, and Croatia.

Why is this important?

It's hard to find a kid who doesn't like Lego, but some have never owned a Lego set or much of other toys. When we give Lego, we give a toy that sparks the imagination and provides endless possibilities of play. You may have fond memories of yourself growing up playing with Lego, and if so, be thankful. We would like to see more children growing up with these memories.

 

To learn more about Creations for Charity and its coordinators. Please visit our website, creationsforcharity.org.


Questions or comments? Email us at info@creationsforcharity.org.

story:
Fitchburg Artistree started as a simple idea and grew into something bigger in only 8 months. Created by artists, we just wanted a place to create and display our art and interact with one another. As time grew on we realized we weren’t the only ones who felt this way. We planted the seed, started to branch out, and began to realize what kind of impact we could truly have on this wonderful city of ours. We are a group of students, recent college graduates and community members, and where we don't collectively have a lot of money to pursue this mission of ours, we ask you simply for your help.

 

     Fitchburg, MA was once a booming city with a busy downtown. Like many other cities in New England, Fitchburg has seen much better days. There are several empty storefronts along our 2-mile downtown area, and a pretty rough reputation. The dilapidation is not a fitting image for a community like ours. We have countless talented artists and musicians as well as dedicated, culturally diverse community members who love Fitchburg. It is our goal to use this money not only to sustain ourselves as Fitchburg Artistree, for our artists and our community, but also to help the economic recovery of our city and potentially be deemed a cultural district of Massachusetts. 

 

     Funding is extremely important to reaching our full potential. Because we have been sustainable solely on small donations/admission at the door during our shows, we needed to have a fundraiser to go beyond just being able to pay for rent, utilities, insurance and compensating bands based on what we make during a show. We have a lot of improvements and a few small things that need fixing around the space, and where we're fortunately paying less for rent than what the space is supposedly worth, our landlord won't be putting any extra expenses into it. It's all on us. We also strive to purchase and install proper gallery lighting, paint a few murals in the space, and get a legitimate sign for out front. One of our most important things we're fundraising for is a house PA system. They can be pretty pricy, but as a part music venue it's imperative we purchase one in the near future so we no longer have to borrow equipment from musicians that we know.

     Aside from these essentials, we'd love to go above and beyond. We want to begin community mural projects throughout the city. We've talked with Cleghorn Neighborhood Center about designing and creating a mural with their youth center in their neighborhood with local artists. We believe this pop of color and meaningful depictions of our city and community would bring a great deal of positive energy. We would also use funding for planning and implementing community festivals in our parks, which would include live music from local musicians, live art demos, activities for all ages, and participation from local businesses and restaurants.

    We just want to be able to remain sustainable, providing art and music for the community. Everyone that puts this together is strictly volunteering. None of us ever get paid, but that's okay. We're not doing it for money. We do this because we enjoy it and we believe in our mission. We look at Artistree as a great opportunity in all aspects for many people; an outlet for creative expression, cultural exploration, building experience and a resume in the field of business, art, communication, and so many more fields. 

 

 

 

 

 

If you can’t contribute funding at this time, that’s all right. Just spreading the word about our organization and mission, or even coming down to one of our shows is helpful. Support of any kind we are grateful for and cannot thank you all enough.

story:
The Alley Rats began as a personal comic idea of mine describing the misadventures of Rubi Red, an incredibly street-smart and witty raccoon, and her gang the Alley Rats. This eclectic group of misfits include Sir Aaron the 5th (a snobbish ex-rich cat), Rocky (a goofy love-struck raccoon), Crystal (a panda who loves nothing more than to doodle all day), Justin Kat (a very hyper and somewhat annoying cat), Estabon (a very grumpy labrador), and Kiki Fox (a fun and loving fox who gets in everyone's business). The setting is a small, multicultural town on the coast of India and the stories are tall tales of their survival against other colorful animal gangs, society as a whole, and their own silliness!  
 
  After a few years of doodling these characters and developing their profiles I decided to bring them to life in an all new animated web series! Of course this will take some financing and that's where you come in!!! We need money to pay for music, sound effects, voice actors, writers, advertising, etc, etc. This is a dream coming true for me, to share with the world my imagination, and those helping me are excited and devoted to this project as well.
 
  If you decide to help us, feel free to give a little or a lot, any help will be greatly appreciated and rewarded too! We thank you in advance for your kindness and generosity, and, well, see you back in the Alley!

story:
We are a handful of young artists and friends, from the heart of Transylvania.

We are involved and committed to our community and  through this project

we strive to bring people a little happiness in their lives.

Our goal is to artistically promote our beautiful city Alba Iulia, a city whose heart

is a medieval Vauban fortress  recently restorated.

In order to do that, we need you to help us sculpture a snow-fortress in the middle

of the real fortress.

It’s snowing outside and the whole team is ready

 

To make our project real, we need some tools and supplies

to give the snow the shape we want.

 

This is our project from last year. It had a real success in our community,

so this year we aim higher !

story:
• Notre histoire

Les journées de la Tunisie nouvelle aspirent à faire connaître le foisonnement de la culture tunisienne sous ses aspects les plus contemporains tout en participant à l’effervescence de la scène culturelle montréalaise. Pendant ces quelques jours, la Tunisie nouvelle va à la rencontre du public québécois à travers des événements mettant à l’honneur l’art et la pensée.

Cette année, du 18 au 21 avril, les JTN relèvent encore le défi d’une programmation audacieuse et avant-gardiste en vous proposant le concert d’une talentueuse artiste, issue de la scène alternative tunisienne Badiaa Bouhrizi alias Neyssatou, « de la Tunisie à Montréal: MobilisationS » un projet photo alliant exposition en salle et affichage extérieur, une projection de courts métrages d’animation tunisiens et une webconférence sur le journalisme citoyen.

Plus de détails sur notre site officiel : http://www.journeesdelatunisienouvelle.com/

et sur notre page Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/JTNMontreal

  • Programmation des JTN 2012

Mercredi 18 avril à 19h : Soirée d'ouverture des JTN

Entrée gratuite/ Lieu:salle Laure-Gaudreault, Centre Saint-Pierre, 1212 rue Panet, Montréal.

Jeudi 19 avril à 19h : Tunisie… tout court, projection de courts métrages d’animation tunisiens

Évènement gratuit/ Lieu: ONF, 1564 Rue Saint-Denis, Montréal.

Évènement Facebook :https://www.facebook.com/events/247312602025060/

Vendredi 20 avril à 19h  : Concert de Badiaâ Bouhrizi, alias Neyssatou

Prix d'entrée : 25$ (taxes incluses)/ Lieu:Le Cabaret du Mile End, 5240, avenue du Parc, Montréal.

Évènement Facebook :https://www.facebook.com/events/286631158075934/

Samedi 21 avril 2012 à 14h: Webconférence : le journalisme citoyen, enjeux actuels et perspectives d’avenir

Entrée gratuite/ Lieu: Centre Saint-Pierre, 1212 rue Panet,salle Laure-Gaudreault, Montréal.

 Samedi 21 avril 2012 à 19h: Exposition "MobilisationS de la Tunisie à Montréal" et cocktail de clôture

Entrée gratuite/ Lieu:Salle de la Élastica, 3e étage,4602 boul. St-Laurent, Montréal et affichage extérieur dans les rue de Montréal.

Évènement Facebook :https://www.facebook.com/events/225958757502692/

  • Ce que vous accomplissez par vos donations

        En soutenant les JTN, vous participez à la promotion et à l’expansion d’un événement novateur, vous œuvrez au rapprochement des cultures et vous contribuez à faire connaître de talentueux artistes.

        Vos dons financeront en partie les Journées de la Tunisie nouvelle. Ils seront utilisés entre autres pour les frais de location de salles, les achats de billets d'avion des participants, les impressions d'affiches, etc.

        Pour toute donation, quelque soit son montant, vous aurez notre profonde gratitude !

        Pour une donation de 20 CAD et plus, vous recevrez un poster dédicacé par notre magnifique chanteuse Badiaa Bouhrizi alias Neyssatou.

        Pour une donation de 40 CAD et plus, vous recevrez le Tshirt des JTN 2012 ainsi qu’un poster dédicacé par notre fabuleuse chanteuse Badiaa Bouhrizi alias Neyssatou.

        Pour une donation de 60 CAD et plus, vous recevrez un billet privilège (billet régulier en vente à 25 CAD) pour le concert de Neyssatou du 20 avril 2012 à Montréal et un poster dédicacé par l’artiste.

        Pour des raisons de logistique, ces lots ne pourront être livrés qu’au Canada.

        Un reçu sera fourni à chaque donateur et nous allons mettre en place un système vous permettant de suivre l’utilisation des dons.

       Vous pouvez aussi nous aider en 

        Parlant des Journées de la Tunisie nouvelle autour de vous.

        Rejoignant notre page facebook et en invitant vos amis à le faire : https://www.facebook.com/JTNMontreal

story:
Summary

In celebration of the 5th anniversary of the Black Rock French Quarter, we are creating something unique. We want to bring back the spirit of earlier Burning Man, when the richest experiences were found not at some established location on the Esplanade or the big audio wings, but out in the deep playa.

Our new project is a miniature village, surrounded by a night market, complete with coffee house, bakery, jazz, bar, and other amenities, that roams the deep playa, location always unknown. The experience is completely immersive, featuring performers in costume, as well as a look and sound unlike anything else at Burning Man. At the core of the village is a vehicle designed to deploy this experience for brief visits at different points around the city, and then pack it up and move it someplace else under cover of darkness. Our roving village and night market can be found through decoding secret messages broadcast on the radio, through special tracking devices that react when we are near, or through blind luck.

Story

The year is 1799. The War of Independence concluded 16 years ago. Napoleon is marching through Egypt. The War of 1812 looms 13 years in the future. The new republic stands proud, but the future is uncertain, as the mighty nations of Europe battle across the four corners of the globe.

Radical voices are heard in the parlors and bars of New Orleans. The Earth is nothing more than a bloody chessboard for kings, emperors, and sultans, to whom the lives and freedoms of the common man mean nothing. If the liberty of the American states is to be preserved, it must find refuge beyond the reach of warring empires.

Click for more of the story...

Vehicle

Our vehicle is an auspicious (and oddly Masonic) 33 feet long, cobbled together from pieces of a fanciful French Quarter of the year 1799. Its engines are powered by a reaction of absinthe and champagne, and it is carried through space by an array of whirligigs operating on principles long since forgotten. Amid the jumble of mismatched wrought iron balconies and shuttered windows, fly the banners and signs of the citizens and businesses that took flight from this Earth in search of freedom. As visitors stroll the top deck, admiring the view of the open night above our village, they are serenaded by a vintage player piano in full view. On the front of the vehicle, the first thing one sees as it approaches through the dusty dark, is a beautiful face, looking towards our destiny, with her eyes always closed.

Rewards

Copper Medallion

Decoder Medallion

Supper Club

Suite

Budget

Vehicle $9,000
Batteries $300
Parking $500
Metal $3,500
Wood $3,000
Foam $800
Wrought Iron $1,200
Decor $300
Paint and Stain $800
Sound System $900
Computer $1,200
Cooking Equipment $500
Refrigeration $300
Player Piano $300
Furniture $900
Registration $1,200
Insurance $1,000
Electrical $900
Lighting $900
Subtotal $27,500
Anonymous Donation $8,500
Total $19,000

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can get to Los Angeles, we need all the help we can get building and outfitting the vehicle that forms the core of our mobile village. Carpenters and welders are especially handy, but there is work for anyone who can hold a paintbrush or cook a meal for the troops who are working! Email lucifer@goldencafe.org if you want to lend a hand!

         

Join The Night Market

Surrounding our mobile village in the deep playa is a night market that your camp or vehicle can join! Want to serve chai from your trike? Or set up massage tables on your vehicle? Or bike out with the rest of the members of your brass band? Or do tarot readings from your rickshaw? Or pull up with your mobile whiskey bar? The Black Rock Bakery, Golden Cafe, and Cafe de la Fin du Monde have already figured out how to deploy miniature popup versions of their services, and if those camps can do it, then ANY camp can do it. Email lucifer@goldencafe.org and we'll help you figure out how to be part of the night market!

story:
You can continue to give to Exnihilo by going to www.exnihiloartcenter.com donations are tax deductible.


Help us build an artist retreat center in The Bahamas.

It will be the first of its kind in The Bahamas, providing resources to:

  1. Visiting artists
  2. Local Bahamian artists
  3. Local school students

To build the first bungalow with studio! 

One bungalow will allow us to launch an artist residency program at the end of 2014.

$50,000 = 1 single story bungalow that can house 2 artists or 2 couples during a stay. 1 artist's stay is 30 days. 10 stays in one year = 20 artists or couples. 

What are stretch goals?

Our project has several phases. Our first goal of $50k buys just 1 artist bungalow. Stretch goals can grow Exnihilo Art Center to have the greatest impact on the community. More bungalows, workshop space, and a Gathering House with a Public Gallery. 

Each stretch goal that is reached will allow us to increase the number of artist's residencies we can award. PLUS it allows us to unlock more PERKS like A STAY  in the bungalow. We must reach the first stretch goal before being able to offer a stay on the island.

Here is a breakdown of what each stretch goal buys and who is impacted...

$100,000 = 2 story bungalow that can house 4 artists or 4 couples.

$150,000 = 2 story bungalow that can house 4 artists or 4 couples. Plus a teaching workshop that will bring art to the local school students.

$250,000 = 2-2 story bungalows that can house 8 artists or 8 couples. Plus a teaching workshop that will bring art to the local school students.

$500,000 = 2-2 story bungalows that can house 8 artists or 8 couples. Plus The Gathering House with teaching workshops, gallery, recording studio & public dining.

  1. We already have artists from around the world on a WAITING LIST. Your support will get this thing built and will help those artists.
  2. We also have local artists and schools on the island waiting with great anticipation for all the creative opportunities Exnihilo will bring. Your support will bring art to those schools.
  3. Clean up the island. One of the first programs Exnihilo will launch is JUNK-A-NEW. A recycling program that takes old rusty and abandoned vehicles that litter the island and resources them for sculptors to create art. Your support will clean up the island while making art.

What is an artist residency?

It is a place an artist can go for an extended period (1 month or more) to work on a project or body of work without distraction. Many major works through history have been produced in these locations. Learn more…

We are Blair & Bryan, professional artists with a desire to empower other artists. We feel a little shy about tooting our own horn, but Indiegogo says we should, so you can learn more about all the stuff we have done here.

We are fortunate to have some very talented advisors on our development team. All at the top of their game, they are artists, musicians, writers, even an oceanography expert! You can meet them here. You are the most important part of the next phase of this project. You are a friend, colleague or family member who have watched us diligently work away at this project from its beginning.

You are someone who we encouraged in your development or even introduced you to your art form. You are someone we nurtured and mentored. You are someone who’s life we have impacted in some way. 

You are that special person who just happened upon this campaign and is inspired to make the dream of art a reality for island schoolchildren.

 We have taken this as far as we can without help. The next part is up to you.

Whether or not you contribute to this campaign, a BIG way you can help us is to SHARE THIS LINK:http://igg.me/at/exnihilo/x/2116915

Post it to your Facebook wall, tweet about it, email your friends, send messengers on horseback, whatever your thing is. The more networks we can reach, the better we do!

By helping build Exnihilo you are accomplishing something that will help hundreds of artists for years to come, as well as bringing art education to an underserved generation of students.

Perks include some great handmade art and up to a one week stay on the island.

Your contribution is tax deductible.

"Perks" are what you get for your contribution. (if you choose to support the project but do not want a "perk" we have those options for you.) Because Exnihilo is an art center, we have some unique and handmade gifts as well as some island exclusives. (Upper right of page) Here is what they look like...

   

Learn more about the JUNK-A-NEW program!   Learn more about the JUNK-A-NEW program!

 

Some folks we'd like to thank:

Pierre Fortier of Chez Pierre's for the best place to stay and eat on Long Island Bahamas (the man can cook!)

Oramae Smith-Pinder and her sister Dyllis of the Long Island Authentic Crafter's Association for graciously allowing us an interview and plaiting demonstration.

Caitlin Strokosch, Director of The Alliance for Artists Communities.

Lauren Dicioccio, Sculptor.

Our focus group team (you know who you are) for all your help and critique.

Got questions? Please check out the gallery section of this campaign for lots more information, pics and videos about the project. Otherwise here are a few answers to those FAQs:

Q. What does the name mean?

A. Exnihilo is Latin for "out of nothing". It is often used within the phrase, "Creatio exnihilo", referring to creation out of nothing.

Q. Who gets to go once it is built?

A. Artists are chosen through an application process, are enrolled in a workshop or study abroad program.

Q. But I want to go!?

A. No worries, a selected portion of the year will be open for all creative spirits!

Q. How long will it take to build?

A. Once funded, the buildings are prefabricated, then shipped and assembled on the island. That process takes 6-12 weeks.

Q. Green building?

A. Yes! Not only will Exnihilo use solar & wind power, but the way the buildings are constructed saves energy. The are also hurricane resistant. We did our homework in selecting our builder. They have an amazing reputation for sustainable manufacturing practices. You can learn more about them here.

Q. How will Exnihilo help children on the island?

A. Visiting artists will be invited to hold workshops, concerts and demonstrations for the local schools. Local students will also have access to the facility for studio time.

Post it to your Facebook wall, tweet about it, email your friends, send messengers on horseback, whatever your thing is. The more networks we can reach, the better we do!

By helping build Exnihilo you are accomplishing something that will help hundreds of artists for years to come, as well as bringing art education to an underserved generation of students.
Perks include some great handmade art and up to a one week stay on the island.
Your contribution is tax deductible.


"Perks" are what you get for your contribution. (if you choose to support the project but do not want a "perk" we have those options for you.) Because Exnihilo is an art center, we have some unique and handmade gifts as well as some island exclusives. (Upper right of page) Here is what they look like...

   

Learn more about the JUNK-A-NEW program!   Learn more about the JUNK-A-NEW program!
 

Some folks we'd like to thank:Pierre Fortier of Chez Pierre's for the best place to stay and eat on Long Island Bahamas (the man can cook!)
Oramae Smith-Pinder and her sister Dyllis of the Long Island Authentic Crafter's Association for graciously allowing us an interview and plaiting demonstration.
Caitlin Strokosch, Director of The Alliance for Artists Communities.
Lauren Dicioccio, Sculptor.
Our focus group team (you know who you are) for all your help and critique.

Got questions? Please check out the gallery section of this campaign for lots more information, pics and videos about the project. Otherwise here are a few answers to those FAQs:
Q. What does the name mean?
A. Exnihilo is Latin for "out of nothing". It is often used within the phrase, "Creatio exnihilo", referring to creation out of nothing.
Q. Who gets to go once it is built?
A. Artists are chosen through an application process, are enrolled in a workshop or study abroad program.
Q. But I want to go!?
A. No worries, a selected portion of the year will be open for all creative spirits!
Q. How long will it take to build?
A. Once funded, the buildings are prefabricated, then shipped and assembled on the island. That process takes 6-12 weeks.
Q. Green building?
A. Yes! Not only will Exnihilo use solar & wind power, but the way the buildings are constructed saves energy. The are also hurricane resistant. We did our homework in selecting our builder. They have an amazing reputation for sustainable manufacturing practices. You can learn more about them here.
Q. How will Exnihilo help children on the island?
A. Visiting artists will be invited to hold workshops, concerts and demonstrations for the local schools. Local students will also have access to the facility for studio time.

story:
"We have seen some great work by those two individuals in our community and we feel it has helped a lot of our youth in feeling useful to the population."

Paul Quassa (Hamlet of Igloolik), MLA for Aggu

Minister of Education, 2012

To access our detailed proposal go to the "Gallery" tab on this campaign

We are Alexa and Patrick, partners in life and partners in art. Together we travel the world making art and painting huge outdoor walls, and after many art projects in the arctic, Nunavut and Nunavik by far continue to be the most inspiring places for us. 

Past successful projects in the North can be found here:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrickevoke/sets/72157640390721495/ 



We are very humbled to have been invited to Cape Dorset, Nunavut to paint a large outdoor mural on the hamlet's co-op building and collaborate with local artists. We will spend two months in town hosting art workshops for youth and creating the mural. 

  • a series of youth workshops led by Thompson and Hatanaka: techniques, brainstorming/ concept development, mural basics, intro to contemporary mural art practices
  • a series of youth workshops that will culminate in ten youth painting eight wildlife-proof garbage bins located around town



Northern News:http://www.nnsl.com/frames/newspapers/2012-07/jul23_12art.html

We will arrive in Cape Dorset on April 16th and wrap up the mural by the of June.


Cape Dorset is an Inuit hamlet located on Dorset Island near Foxe Peninsula at the southern tip of Baffin Island. Sculptures have been carved in the arctic for thousands of years, but Cape Dorset and specifically Kinngait Studio, has been the centre of contemporary art in the arctic since the 1950s, producing world renowned original prints, carvings and drawings. 

The history of contemporary art in Cape Dorset: 

://www.cbc.ca/player/Digital+Archives/Arts+and+Entertainment/Visual+Arts/ID/2412768717/

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eq6yq_SCyOI


http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Dorset

http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/nunavut/part-3-cape-dorset/article651262/


  • It is cold and dark for many months of the year, colour and imagination brings warmth to a frequented space in town.

  • Public art is a significant part of creating healthy cities worldwide including Canada in a big way: why not in Cape Dorset, a place that gives so much creatively to Canada and the world? 

  • Artistic exchange amongst Canadian artists

  • We have done many previous precedent setting murals in the arctic that continue to be appreciated in their respective communities

  • Connect with young artists, contribute to inspiring the next generation of Cape Dorset artists which is currently a challenge: 

  • http://www.cbc.ca/thecurrent/episode/2011/08/24/etched-in-stone-documentary/



  • We have support from the Ontario Arts Council and First Air for flights and a portion of our cargo                                                  
  • Alexa: I am volunteering to do this project as an aside to fulfilling a Chalmer’s Fellowship (my visit to Cape Dorset is supported by the Ontario Arts Council to experience the town and inform my career’s trajectory) 
  • We are the humble guests of the Kinngait Lithography studio apartment (accommodation is a major piece, many thanks)              
  • We are donating our original prints as perks for your support!           
  • Your support is needed to cover materials, cargo shipment, dangerous goods packaging (required to put paint on a plane), and artist honorariums for Patrick and two local artists                   
  • Our campaign represents a modest budget for such a project to ensure we meet our goal, surplus funding will go towards higher artist honorariums and supplementing the high cost of food, and potentially painting additional walls (update we have already exceeded our estimated materials and shipping budget!)


This is the site:


Images of the PERKS:


Cape Dorset Mural Project 

Lino Print

Ink on paper

12 x18"

for a larger image: 

http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrickevoke/12430861883/


Edith, linoleum print (the perk is a screenprint from this image), 15x22" by Alexa Hatanaka

Edith is a friend we made in Igloolik who helped us out everyday while painting murals in 2011 and 2012.

View larger: 

http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrickevoke/12266213933/in/set-72157640415057435


Skipping School For Merits, 30 layer screenprint, 24x36" by Patrick Thompson

This print was selected for the Guanlan International Printmaking Bienniel, 2013, in Shenzen, China.

view larger:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/16984862@N07/8445563361/in/photolist-dSiHKp

ADDHD

10 layer screenprint

edition of 25

(all pieces vary slightly in colour)

Patrick Thompson


Tug-o

etching on handmade paper, 9x15"

Alexa Hatanaka

View Larger: http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrickevoke/13276...


Kinngait (Cape Dorset, Inuktitut name) Handpainted sign!

We have been living in Nilaveli, Sri Lanka for three months working on our exhibition, opening in Zurich on March 20th. We just spent two days working with our friend Artist Sun, an 80 year old sign painter, who is the resident painter for the Cinema in Trincomalee, the larger nearby town. We often think about connections when we make our work and here is a nice one, linking our time in Sri Lanka to the Cape Dorset Mural Project.


OWN THIS ORIGINAL or get a postcard print for $15!!




       


Please follow this link to see some of our work done in the north over the past years:

 http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrickevoke/sets/72157640390721495/

To access our detailed proposal go to the "Gallery" tab on this campaign


PLEASE EMAIL support@indiegogo.com IF YOU EXPERIENCE A PROBLEM DONATING! 

If you wish to select a perk and donate more than is allotted you may do so :)

story:
Introduction

When people ask what I believe in, I say “the sky”. The sky represents many things to me. In Western Astrology, I am an Aquarian, which represents air, movement, space, and ether. Having been traveling from a young age, first as the daughter of a commercial pilot and as a teenager, as an international model, I have used my air element, the sky, as a means of transportation to exotic destinations. After my aspirations changed, I settled down in New York City to attend design college, where I was when Hurricane Sandy swept through. Amidst the turmoil and commotion of it all, I was presented with the opportunity for a moment of quiet reflection in the simple act of flying a kite. This experience gave me an important realization that our place in the universe is not to abuse or compete with nature, but rather to co-exist with it. The kite exemplifies this, as although we want to fly, we are tethered to the ground. 

 

 

Book Content

 

In Spring 2014, the author is going on a road trip across the country with her handmade kites on Route 66 from Chicago, IL to Los Angeles, CA and up the West coast (see Map). She will use her "kite stand" to distribute handmade kites to locals in various communities she stops through. She will also fly kites as spiritual objects at sacred Native American sites such as Monument Valley. The story and images from the trip will be compiled for an e-book and artist edition print book about sacred kite-making, entitled An Idealist's Guide to Tethered Flying Objects. She will also be developing a series of natural how-to kite projects inspired by people and places she meets along the way. She will be using Instagram and posting Youtube videos to document the journey so you can come along for the ride.

The Kite Cross at Far Rockaway, New York City 

 

Book Concept: Bring the Magic Home

Everyone has a story to tell about kites, all across the globe. I'm sure you have seen the famous movie The Kite Runner, where kites in India are flown and fought by entire cities at various times of the year, such as on Independence Day. In South America, kites are flown for sacred purposes such as to honor ancestors on Day of the Dead. In the West, kites have played a more scientific role as meteorologic instruments. The vast uses of kites throughout around the world tells us that kites are much more than a toy, they are a tool for shared human experience. The idea is that anyone can be a kite-maker, all it takes is a bit of curiosity and a desire to fly. 

 

Book Layout

The book will begin with an introduction to kites and the history of kites around the world. The bulk of the book will include 15-20 how-to kite projects. Each project will tie in with a specific place and time and focus on upcycling and using natural materials. Towards the end of the book, I will focus on community kite-making events and how you can organize your own kite-making workshop and even make a Kite Machine where you live. The book will conclude with flying tips, resources, stockists, and a glossary. The estimated word count is 20,000 words or 100 pages of type, plus images.

 

TOTAL:  $5,050

 

 

 

The Impact

 

The book will inspire people young and old to make a kite of their very own, rediscover a favorite kite flying spot from childhood, and share the joy of kite flying with others. It will help build community from the ground up as the passion for the craft spreads and people want to share their stories of kite flying with those around them. The book will also instill a sense of creativity and resourcefulness in readers, and engage them in ways they can use materials they have in their local vicinity to make kites, as traditional cultures have done for thousands of years.

 

 

How You Can Help

1) Donate!

2) Share the campaign on Facebook and Twitter!

4) Follow us on Instagram (@kitecollective)

story:
About Us:

Chutzpah is an art gallery and coffee shop that encourages people to look at art, coffee, and life in general from a different perspective. We are dedicated to promoting artists and other creative professionals who have a passion for their work, while educating the public about all forms of art, music and coffee culture.

Chutzpah is run by Ian Morris and K Mikael Schnyder. Ian has run Homemade Genius, a successful music and arts nonprofit organization in upstate South Carolina, for the last 8 years.  Homemade Genius will continue to operate alongside Chutzpah to bring progressive music and art to Charleston. Mikael is a Southeast Regional Barista competitor with 12 years of coffee management experience, 2 years of coffee roasting experience and 6 years of coffee retailer experience. Together, they are teaming up to bring Charleston a new and exciting place to view and create art and music while enjoying a delicious cup of coffee in an inviting, relaxing atmosphere.

We know there is a need in the Charleston art scene for something different. In our gallery we will work hard to create a space that incorporates street art, outsider art and modern contemporary art, alongside progressive realism. We want to establish a true community of artists and art lovers alike. In our gallery, we will show a variety of progressive, modern artwork, by both promising up-and-coming artists and established artists. By taking only a 25% commission on all sales, we want to truly encourage and support the artists. 

 

Mission Statement: Chutzpah is defined as shameless audacity and fearlessness. To be a creative professional in today’s world, one must possess these traits. At Chutzpah, we are committed to supporting and promoting the hard-working, passionate artists in Charleston and beyond. With our art gallery and coffee shop, we provide the community with a place to create, learn about and appreciate progressive art, coffee, music and more. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We've got the chutzpah to follow our dreams and the knowledge and experience to make it happen, but what we need now is funding. That's where you fine people come in.

We are aiming to raise $10,000, in order to help us secure a lease, build our coffee bar, purchase coffee shop and gallery equipment, and begin providing Charleston with a unique art gallery and cafe.

For your donation, you will get a variety of perks depending on the amount your donate.

Once we raise the funds necessary to open, Chutzpah Gallery and Cafe will host a private opening event for everyone who donates $50 or more to our campaign. The event will include an art show, several musical performance, free drinks and hors d'oeuvres, and a great time! You won't want to miss it!

For donating $15, you will get a free download of your choice of one of the two Chutzpah Compilation CDs. For donating $25, you will get a download of both CDs.

Volume 1 Chutzpah Compilation CD (rock and singer/songwriters):

  1. Carousel by The Winter Sounds
  2. Untouched and Burning by Besides Daniel
  3. Die Already by The Royal Tinfoil
  4. Hardly Wait by Cloudeater
  5. Robot by Sick/Sea
  6. Box-Type Love by Run Dan Run
  7. A Little Joke by Pocket Vinyl
  8. Empty Tank by Jungol
  9. Tell Us A Story From Before We Can Remember by An Era of Echoes
  10. The Horde by Wolf Lord
  11. Count Zackula by A Mile At Sea
  12. Lethe by Loather
  13. The Wagon by Spoken Nerd
  14. Farm Kid by Elim Bolt
  15. Black Heart by Fire Mountain
  16. With A Feeling by The Dubber
  17. Moonshine by The Hungry Monks
  18. Old Country Road by A Mad Affair
  19. Keep Your Head Up by Arthur Alligood

 

Volume 2 Chutzpah Compilation CD (electronic and hip-hop):

  1. Destination : Imagination by Njrrd
  2. Soul Eater by Maiki
  3. Clyde Drexler by Mad Axes
  4. Nexst by Trublklef feat. Dr. Horrible and DJ Emeighty
  5. Liveability by Supah Mario
  6. Regressing by We Roll Like Madmen
  7. 109 and Nancy by The SH.A.AW Brothers
  8. The Good Life by Sick Tyte Click
  9. Dynasty by Grand Royal
  10. FatRat by FatRat Da Czar
  11. Guilty Intentions by Quanstar
  12. All That by SOHI
  13. Until We Are Brave Again by Cedric Umoja and IMO
  14. Sleepy and Weepy by Sole Symphony
  15. Night Shift by Loa
  16. The Ultimate Creative by Ian Morris
  17. Dubai Departures by Saki Bomb
  18. Grind by Left
  19. Home by Sunday Morning

 

For all donations of $50 and above, you will receive this t-shirt, designed and printed by Charleston t-shirt company Artisan Tees (artisantees.com).

  

 

For your donation of $100, you will receive your choice of a matted and signed print from either Charleston artist Lara Neece (forestandfin.com) or Charleston artist Brian Cate (bdeangraphics.com). Lara Neece prints will be matted and signed by the artist, but will not come framed. You will have your choice of these three prints - Sea Turtles, Finches, or Whales.

 

Brian Cate prints will be matted and signed by the artist. You will have your choice of these three prints - Magnolia Plantation, Woman with Red Gloves, or 39 Montagu Street.

 

 

 

For your donation of $250, you will receive your choice of either an original sculpture created by Charleston artist Anna Godden, or an original painting by Charleston artist and Chutzpah co-founder Ian Morris. 

Cast aluminum indoor wall sculpture titled "Andy's Yard Art" by Anna Godden:

 Outdoor garden sculpture by Anna Godden:

24"x36" acrylic, spray paint and oil pastel painting titled "From Your Heart Closet" by Ian Morris. This painting also comes with a poem:

 

For your donation of $500, you will receive your choice of one of several large original pieces of art created by a talented artist.

38"x48" spray paint on wood painting titled "Owl Be Watching You" by Charleston artist Crosby Jack:

 

42"x42" acrylic and spray paint on canvas painting titled "Left" by Charleston artist Ross MacTaggart:

36"x80" mixed media on hollow core door painting titled "Escape From Neo Tokyo" by Columbia artist Cedric Umoja:

 

For your donation of $5,000, you will get a rare opportunity to rent out the Chutzpah building two times in 2013 for free! First, host your own private event in our space - host your birthday party, hold a group meeting, whatever you want! Second, you will get a private concert at the Chutzpah gallery featuring performances by Charleston singer/songwriter Lily Slay of The Royal Tinfoil, and Greenville singer/songwriter Sarah Schaffer. Details of both events, including dates, time, etc., will be worked out between the donor, Chutzpah staff, and the musicians.

Sarah Schaffer:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jUMo0fWFD5U

Lily Slay (The Royal Tinfoil):

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Trlg-YeAugc

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know not everyone has the money to donate, but you can still help us achieve our goal!

  • Help by spreading the word to your friends and family who may be able to donate.
  • If you're an artist, donate a piece of artwork we can auction off to help raise money.
  • Once we do raise the money to get Chutzpah up and running (because we're confident we will!), come get a cup of coffee and check out our awesome art gallery!

If you have any other questions about Chutzpah or our campaign, feel free to contact Ian Morris at homemadegenius@yahoo.com.

In our gallery, we will show a variety of progressive, modern artwork, by both promising up-and-coming artists and established artists. By taking only a 25% commission on all sales, we want to truly encourage and support the artists. 
 
Mission Statement: Chutzpah is defined as shameless audacity and fearlessness. To be a creative professional in today’s world, one must possess these traits. At Chutzpah, we are committed to supporting and promoting the hard-working, passionate artists in Charleston and beyond. With our art gallery and coffee shop, we provide the community with a place to create, learn about and appreciate progressive art, coffee, music and more. 
 

What We Need & What You Get
We've got the chutzpah to follow our dreams and the knowledge and experience to make it happen, but what we need now is funding. That's where you fine people come in.
We are aiming to raise $10,000, in order to help us secure a lease, build our coffee bar, purchase coffee shop and gallery equipment, and begin providing Charleston with a unique art gallery and cafe.
For your donation, you will get a variety of perks depending on the amount your donate.
Once we raise the funds necessary to open, Chutzpah Gallery and Cafe will host a private opening event for everyone who donates $50 or more to our campaign. The event will include an art show, several musical performance, free drinks and hors d'oeuvres, and a great time! You won't want to miss it!
For donating $15, you will get a free download of your choice of one of the two Chutzpah Compilation CDs. For donating $25, you will get a download of both CDs.

Volume 1 Chutzpah Compilation CD (rock and singer/songwriters):

Carousel by The Winter Sounds
Untouched and Burning by Besides Daniel
Die Already by The Royal Tinfoil
Hardly Wait by Cloudeater
Robot by Sick/Sea
Box-Type Love by Run Dan Run
A Little Joke by Pocket Vinyl
Empty Tank by Jungol
Tell Us A Story From Before We Can Remember by An Era of Echoes
The Horde by Wolf Lord
Count Zackula by A Mile At Sea
Lethe by Loather
The Wagon by Spoken Nerd
Farm Kid by Elim Bolt
Black Heart by Fire Mountain
With A Feeling by The Dubber
Moonshine by The Hungry Monks
Old Country Road by A Mad Affair
Keep Your Head Up by Arthur Alligood
 
Volume 2 Chutzpah Compilation CD (electronic and hip-hop):

Destination : Imagination by Njrrd
Soul Eater by Maiki
Clyde Drexler by Mad Axes
Nexst by Trublklef feat. Dr. Horrible and DJ Emeighty
Liveability by Supah Mario
Regressing by We Roll Like Madmen
109 and Nancy by The SH.A.AW Brothers
The Good Life by Sick Tyte Click
Dynasty by Grand Royal
FatRat by FatRat Da Czar
Guilty Intentions by Quanstar
All That by SOHI
Until We Are Brave Again by Cedric Umoja and IMO
Sleepy and Weepy by Sole Symphony
Night Shift by Loa
The Ultimate Creative by Ian Morris
Dubai Departures by Saki Bomb
Grind by Left
Home by Sunday Morning
 
For all donations of $50 and above, you will receive this t-shirt, designed and printed by Charleston t-shirt company Artisan Tees (artisantees.com).
  
 
For your donation of $100, you will receive your choice of a matted and signed print from either Charleston artist Lara Neece (forestandfin.com) or Charleston artist Brian Cate (bdeangraphics.com). Lara Neece prints will be matted and signed by the artist, but will not come framed. You will have your choice of these three prints - Sea Turtles, Finches, or Whales.

 
Brian Cate prints will be matted and signed by the artist. You will have your choice of these three prints - Magnolia Plantation, Woman with Red Gloves, or 39 Montagu Street.
 
 





 
For your donation of $250, you will receive your choice of either an original sculpture created by Charleston artist Anna Godden, or an original painting by Charleston artist and Chutzpah co-founder Ian Morris. 
Cast aluminum indoor wall sculpture titled "Andy's Yard Art" by Anna Godden:

 Outdoor garden sculpture by Anna Godden:

24"x36" acrylic, spray paint and oil pastel painting titled "From Your Heart Closet" by Ian Morris. This painting also comes with a poem:

 
For your donation of $500, you will receive your choice of one of several large original pieces of art created by a talented artist.
38"x48" spray paint on wood painting titled "Owl Be Watching You" by Charleston artist Crosby Jack:
 
42"x42" acrylic and spray paint on canvas painting titled "Left" by Charleston artist Ross MacTaggart:

36"x80" mixed media on hollow core door painting titled "Escape From Neo Tokyo" by Columbia artist Cedric Umoja:

 
For your donation of $5,000, you will get a rare opportunity to rent out the Chutzpah building two times in 2013 for free! First, host your own private event in our space - host your birthday party, hold a group meeting, whatever you want! Second, you will get a private concert at the Chutzpah gallery featuring performances by Charleston singer/songwriter Lily Slay of The Royal Tinfoil, and Greenville singer/songwriter Sarah Schaffer. Details of both events, including dates, time, etc., will be worked out between the donor, Chutzpah staff, and the musicians.
Sarah Schaffer:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jUMo0fWFD5U
Lily Slay (The Royal Tinfoil):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Trlg-YeAugc
 
Other Ways You Can Help
We know not everyone has the money to donate, but you can still help us achieve our goal!

Help by spreading the word to your friends and family who may be able to donate.
If you're an artist, donate a piece of artwork we can auction off to help raise money.
Once we do raise the money to get Chutzpah up and running (because we're confident we will!), come get a cup of coffee and check out our awesome art gallery!
If you have any other questions about Chutzpah or our campaign, feel free to contact Ian Morris at homemadegenius@yahoo.com.

story:
RAPID PULSE International Performance Art Festival presents a vast range of styles and forms of time-based work. Produced by Defibrillator Gallery in the Noble Square neighborhood of Chicago, Rapid Pulse will exhibit live performances by 24 international, national, and local artists who were invited by the curatorial committee or selected from an international call for proposals. Rapid Pulse also includes public interventions, a video series, social events, artist talks, and panel discussions. Spilling over to other venues in the neighborhood, the festival embraces the local and the global simultaneously. We aim to invigorate Chicago by bringing to the city artists of exceptional calibre from around the world. Dynamic programming, decidedly fearless and unique, aims to provoke thought and stimulate discourse surrounding performance art. 

Visit www.RAPIDPULSE.org for more information 

Your contributions will go toward housing and feeding 26 local, national, and international artists. Often visiting artists go to great expense in order to participate in a festival - paying for their own airfare and missing out on employment. The least we can do is make sure they are comfortable and well-fed while they are here. Your help is invaluable. 

RAPID PULSE 2014 ROSTER

ANTIBODY CORP (Chicago)  | JESSICA ELAINE BLINKHORN (US) | ANNA BROWN (Chicago) | DIANA daf COLLAZOS (Peru) | ALISON CROCETTA &PETER REESE (US) | DIAZ LEWIS: CARA MEGAN LEWIS & ALEJANDRO FIGUEREDO DIAZ-PERERA (Chicago/Cuba) | DISORIENTALISM: MARIANNE KIM & KATHERINE BEHAR (US) | ESPAND: HANNA M OWENS & SOHEILA AZADI (Chicago/Iran) | LINDA HESH (US) | LAI THI DIEU HA (Vietnam) | JASON LIM (Singapore) | ALASTAIR MACLENNAN (Ireland/Scotland) | CARLOS MARTIEL (Cuba) | MIKEY MCPARLANE (Chicago) | TEOMA NACCARATO (Canada) | KIRA O’REILLY (UK) | FREYA BJÖRG OLAFSON (Canada) | LA POCHA NOSTRA (US/Mexico) | MATTHEW PREST (Australia) | RAQUEL PUNTO (Mexico) | BORYANA ROSSA (Bulgaria) | MICHAL SAMAMA (Chicago/Israel) | SANDRINE SCHAEFER (US)  |  MANUEL VASON (UK/Italy)  | JULIE VULCAN (Australia) | 

RAPID PULSE curators are Julie Laffin, Steven Bridges, Giana Gambino, and Joseph Ravens.

Want to get involved with RAPID PULSE? Sign up HERE:  V O L U N T E E R !

Can you host a visiting artist? We're seeking people who have private rooms in their homes. Only have a sofa? That could be handy, too! If you're interested, please fill out our P14 HOST FORM.

or contact gianagambino@rapidpulse.org

RAPID PULSE is made possible with support from The British Council, Cliff Dwellers Arts Foundation, School of the Art Institute of Chicago, Society for Arts, Holiday Jones, and Nightingale. Defibrillator is partially supported by grants from the Gaylord and Dorothy Donnelley Foundation, The Illinois Arts Council Agency, and Chicago Department of Cultural Affairs and Special Events.

story:
The Firebird Festival is an annual celebration of arts and culture that is held in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. 

This year marks the 11th year of the festival, as it returns to Friendship Field on December 6th, 2014.

http://firebirdfestival.com

The Firebird Festival mission is to provide an annual celebration of the borough of Phoenixville's namesake - the Phoenix. Just as the Phoenix rose from its own ashes, the town of Phoenixville has risen, and continues to rebuild and improve the local community, after the loss of its principle industry in the early 1980's.

The festival is designed to foster a collaboration of local artistic and creative talent, and to enhance the overall cultural life of Phoenixville.

100+ performers, an expansive craft vendor area, and gourmet food trucks and vendors from the Philadelphia and the surrounding suburbs will be on site to welcome the thousands of participants who flock to Phoenixville for the festival. 

There will also be a parade from downtown Phoenixville, leading its way up to Friendship Field. The community is encouraged to join in the parade, which will feature paper lanterns, peace birds, puppets, dancers, drummers and more.

There will be continuous shuttle buses connecting downtown to the bird site at Friendship Field.


Progress

Our 2014 campaign reached 115% of our goal of $5,000, which will help the festival to grow and prosper!


How You Can Help

There are many elements that go into the festival, ranging from building the bird and providing a safe and comfortable festival experience for the community, to providing entertainment, obtaining insurance, and promoting the festival.

Below is a breakdown of annual expenses that we incur when putting on the festival:

  • Portable Restrooms - $2,100
  • Stage & Sound System for Musicians and Performers - $1,300
  • Compensation for Musicians and Performers - $1,500
  • Insurance for the Festival - $3,000
  • Posters, Flyers and Printing for Promotional Material and Programs - $1,000
  • Wood and Materials for Construction of the Phoenix - $1,000

We all have a part to play in this wonderful celebration, and we look to each of you, the community, friends and families who have enjoyed this wonderful celebration in the past, to help us achieve 100% of our fundraising goal.

We were very successful in raising funds last year, thanks in part to the support of people who gave gifts through our 2013 Indiegogo campaign.
Let's keep the fire burning and do it again!

Please join in support of the Firebird Festival by making a gift through this campaign, and by asking family and friends to join you in making a gift.

You can also help by using the social media tools on this page to share this campaign with your friends and family who embrace what the Firebird Festival is doing for the community.

All funds that are raised through this campaign will go to support the purchase of construction materials and goods and services listed above, in order to ensure a safe and exciting Firebird Festival for 2014!

Gift Recognitions and Perks

From smaller gifts to larger gifts, all are important.
Every donation to the campaign is greatly appreciated and put to use.

Please see the list of "perks" for donors along the right side of this page, for what we are able to offer to donors as "thank you" recognitions for continued support.

We are offering T-shirts, mugs, framed prints, canvas prints, and even 5 chances to be "torchbearers" and pass the torch into the Phoenix, lighting it on fire on December 6th, 2014!

With your help, the Phoenix will always rise from its ashes at the Firebird Festival!
