story:
As a student of the Toronto Art Therapy Institute, I have partnered with a Toronto Community Hospital to develop a unique pilot project; Project: Colourful Minds. This project aims to transform walls of an inpatient adult psychiatric unit into interactive and evolving mural spaces, where patients can create and connect using art in a safe space. This is a new concept in an effort to support treatment through art on a mental health unit.

About the Project

This project seeks to transform unit walls using a high-performance dry erase, odourless formula which transforms virtually any smooth surface into an erasable canvas. This environmentally responsible surface is LEED and CalGreen compliant, and is also UL GREENGUARD Gold Certified for indoor air quality. 

Patients will be invited to participate in specified directives in an effort to improve the physical environment of treatment, create opportunities for social connectedness, develop skills to enhance resilience and recovery, and promote community and social inclusion.  

How You Can Help

The campaign seeks to raise $5,000 that will go to the development and sustainability of this project. This will be used to purchase:

  • Primer and Dry Erase surface formula 
  • Wall cleaning supplies: Erasers, Cloths and Liquid Cleaning Formula
  • Artist Tools: Stencils, Safe Drawing Tools, Dry Erase Markers, Pencil Crayons and Crayons  

    The Impact

    Your support will bring us one step closer to building an empowered social community. By showing your generosity, you will be building a community space that encourages communication, collaboration, and resilience.   

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you are unable to support financially, it doesn't mean you can't help! 
      Please share this campaign with your friends, family and networks. 
      If you have any questions regarding this project please do not hesitate to contact me at:
      colourfulmindsproject@gmail.com

      THANK YOU!

story:
Hi, I’m Andy, an artist living in Edinburgh, Scotland. I loved painting from an early age and studied fine art and graphic design at Edinburgh College of Art. Now, as Kurt Schwitters said, I nail my pictures together! I use recycled scrap metal and experiment with other materials like concrete and plastic to create unique mounted assemblage pieces. My work has been accepted into major Scottish exhibitions by the SSA and RSA.

I’ve been invited to exhibit my work in a showcase in Taipei, Taiwan by the artist and gallery director, Yosifu. It will be my first major international exhibition, so it’s hugely important for my career. It will be the second time I have exhibited alongside Yosifu, whose work is celebrated in Taiwan. It will build on my collaboration with Queen Margaret University whose cultural management students (from Taiwan) have really opened up a dialogue about my art with an Asian audience for the first time. And, finally, it will complete the fantastic creative journey I have had with filmmaker Michal Korzonek who has spent many months filming the making of my work for a documentary.

'Munro' miniature

Like many men my age, I have a family and a mortgage, but luckily I have a small workshop and the support of my family and friends to express myself through art. I feel privileged to have this opportunity and don’t want to waste it. Besides the inspiration to make art, time and money are necessary components in making this dream to exhibit overseas a reality. I have poured sweat and tears into this project for many months and years – please help me find the money to show my work in Taipei and complete filming.

£3000 will cover the cost of travel, packing and transporting artwork, and completing filming. We have squeezed every possible penny out of our costs – I have secured a room in a hostel for artists whilst Michal will stay with a friend. We certainly won’t be flying first class or business – if it takes two days to get there, so it will be! Queen Margaret University have been incredibly supportive in providing equipment for filming and editing so we are asking only for what we absolutely need. Anything over and above our target will be spent on marketing the event in Taiwan.

  • Return flight costs for Andy and Michal: £2000
  • Packing and transportation (including freight and insurance): £1000

Here’s a taste of the perks available for supporting me: a postcard with an original sketch by me, an invitation to the documentary screening (if it’s half as much fun as my preview show, you will want to be there!); a Q & A Skype with Michal and I; a morning of filming with Michal and I (expect friendly banter and lots of laughs!), a tutorial at my workshop (it is a bit of a squeeze and safety goggles will be provided!); join me for a trip around my favourite galleries (a cuppa and cake are included!); and get your hands on some of my latest work (I think those miniatures will go fast!); plus many more perks as this crowd-funding journey unfolds.

Let’s fall in love with the things we find!
Let’s take a sculpture and put it on the wall!
Let’s go small when everyone else goes super-size!
Let’s get people connected in faraway places through art!
Let’s support young people and their creativity!
Let’s share my story through film!

And, hopefully, let’s sell some artwork!

I was overwhelmed by the response to a preview of the early body of work for Taiwan but somewhat despondent when I realised that the cost of transporting some of the bigger pieces was prohibitive. Thankfully, I have a new network of Taiwanese “fans” who urged me to try something smaller. So I went miniature! Downsizing was a massive challenge at first and a risk – what if no-one liked them – but the late nights have been worth it. I have never been more proud of my work and the reaction people are having to my miniatures is terrific. It’s not something I would have necessarily explored, had miniatures not been so popular in Taiwan.

I appreciate that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign... wherever you are. If I make it to Taiwan, who knows where I will go next! Your in-kind donations, suggestions, recommendations, ideas and inspiration will be much appreciated.

Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools! THANK YOU!!!!!

story:
Our Mission

Dispoze is a creative collaboration of Chicago’s newest and freshest artists. Our passionate staff aims to deliver a snapshot of urban lifestyle to our readers....and Dispoze is that lifestyle. 

Heavily focused on music, fashion and art, our quarterly magazine aims to be not only Chicago’s premier art & culture magazine, but also to be ranked nationally. Because Dispoze is our passion, our first focus will always remain on our invigorating brand and captivating content. 

We have a staff of almost 30 dedicated and passionate young artists. From writers to photographers to designers, we have every inch of our vision covered and we know exactly what we need to get there.

Some of our short-term (within this next year) goals include: 

  • Hosting events throughout the year, including our launch party, a quarterly weekend-long pop up shop, concerts, film festivals, local events, brand releases, and more.
  • Hitting an online circulation of 50,000 and a print circulation of 5,000 by the release of Issue 3.
  • Developing our merchandise line into products our generation will love, helping to spread our brand and vision.
  • Developing an online presence in the blogosphere, ranging from interview videos to event coverage.
  • Getting Dispoze on the shelves of local businesses we support, and developing partnerships with businesses - particularly clothing brands, record labels and event venues.

Some of our long-term goals include: 

  • Opening up our own office, with a creative environment and plenty of space to throw events.
  • Hitting an online circulation of 150,000 and a print circulation of 15,000 by the release of Issue 6. 
  • Seeing Dispoze on the shelves of major retailers.
  • Developing and cultivating a devoted fan base. 
  • Build upon our existing staff with the addition of new, creative artists -- and hopefully, paying them!
  • Opening up our own storefront in downtown Chicago, then branching out to other top markets.

We are already well on our way to achieve each and every one of these goals, and after just a few weeks, we've already managed to lock interviews with big names such as RCA Record's G-Eazy, who recently opened up for the Drake vs. Lil Wayne tour and hit #3 on Billboard charts with his summer album. His massive following will help fuel our e-zine sales and increase our circulation. We are networking more than ever before, and establishing personal relationships and connections with some of Chicago's finest. 


The Specifics

Print: A 9x12, 96 page magazine with 100# offset cover and 60# offset pages, done in full color and with perfect binding, plus gold foil accents for the cover. This gives the magazine a beautiful, "coffee table" look. 

E-Zine: Launched through Issuu.com, we will be able to provide the same content to thousands of readers around the world. Issuu.com tracks statistics and page views, so we'll be able to take the data to future advertisers.


Our Launch

We've already locked several performers, including Chicago's St. Millie along with Columbia College's own, Cae Jones. We've also locked a DJ. We'd like to blow up some of our photography and hang it, as well as sell our merchandise. We'd also like to be able to give away promotional items, such as stickers and lighters. The venue would be near downtown Chicago.
The official date for the launch party is December 4th, 2014.

What We Need

Our first issue publishes on December 1, 2014. Most of the funding for business expenses and printing costs is coming from advertisers, but we need your help for that final push to help make Dispoze everything we want it to be. We are asking for $8,500, and here's why:
  • Most advertising budgets are slim in the final quarter of the year, as they've already exhausted most of their funds. $8,500 will cover all of the costs to print, giving us a beautiful product to take to businesses at the start of the new calendar year. 
  • Although we are still actively searching for advertisers, and have secured a few, we want to market and focus on our brand identity, which involves developing and distributing merchandise before we even release our first issue.
  • Excess funds will go towards web hosting fees, new equipment, and our launch party.
  • We've already almost exhausted our personal funds -- and the first rule of business is that it takes money to make money!

Your Impact

Your contribution will ensure that Dispoze becomes a reality. Here are some of the spots in our budget that we'd love to spend more on:

  • Print quality.
  • Marketing - adding stickers, posters and advertisements in other medias.
  • Maintaining our website and adding more interaction between the site and the viewer.
  • External hard drives.
  • Staff - we've got almost 30 people working for free as of right now, and one of our ultimate goals is to make money doing what we love! 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about Dispoze!
    • Leave us a comment on our IndieGoGo and let us know what you think.
    • Share our campaign across social media, and check out our Twitter and Instagram!
    • Reach out to the most creative person you know and invite them to submit on our website.
    Thank you for taking time to learn about Dispoze, and hopefully, happy contributing!

Heavily focused on music, fashion and art, our quarterly magazine aims to be not only Chicago’s premier art & culture magazine, but also to be ranked nationally. Because Dispoze is our passion, our first focus will always remain on our invigorating brand and captivating content.

story:
HELP US BRING BACK THE ART!

idspace, a gallery in East Hawaii, was created as a place for artists to explore "what might be"; a space to experience the spirit and imagination of those whose processes and products mark our place and time.



As many of you know, after ten wonderful years of exhibitions, gatherings and performances, our beloved idspace outgrew its former rural rainforest home. Limited parking and county building code requirements have forced us to seek out a more suitable (and more costly) space. After months of searching, we've found a location in downtown Hilo, Hawaii that will allow us to continue to provide an alternative venue for local and international visual and performing artists. Through our free online publication, www.hiartmagazine.com, we will continue to share our events and exhibitions with readers around the world.



Collaboration and friendship are the foundation of idspace. Over the years, our community has been enriched by the bonds formed and opportunities presented to the artists and those in attendance. Faithful volunteers have lent their time and talents, from spackling and painting to gourmet catering for our events and  together we can continue to make our gallery grow. idspace was not designed to profit financially, but there are considerable costs associated with setting up a new gallery.

 

 


With your help we will be able to meet our current expenses:

renovation materials...$2000

labor........................donated

one year's rent...........$8280
_______________________

total needed............$10,280


In exchange for your generousity, we are offering some awesome gifts. 

 



We hope you'll join our idspace and HI Art family!
Visit idspace online at www.hiartmagazine.com.

story:
Who am I and what is this campaign all about?

My name is Gina Santi and I am a photographer, anthropologist, and educator. I am producing a 2014 wall calendar for CASA -the Center for Adolescents in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico- to be sold as a fundraiser for the organization. I am providing my images and design skills free of charge but am in need of contributions to cover printing costs.

CASA is a 30-year-old grassroots, youth-driven organization that proudly serves 80,000 people a year all over Mexico through its community and education advocacy efforts: maternity hospital and family clinic, professional midwifery school, day care programs, libraries, theater group, and violence prevention programs. I encourage you to see the attached video in its entirety to better visualize the scope of activities that your contribution will reach.

What do I need?

The cost of printing one calendar is US$18.00 and this campaign is based on 100 calendars. I need a total of US$1,800. They will be 12-month 2014 wall calendars, printed on heavy archival quality stock, individually signed by the artist, and in limited edition. The retail price of the calendar will be US$35.00 and it will be sold among CASA's constituency during other fundraising events in the Fall of 2013.

If this campaign is fully funded, CASA will receive US$3,500 that will go towards its many community programs :-)

100 calendars x US$35 = US$3,500

Any donation amount is greatly appreciated!! Of course, if we receive more of your generous donations we will be able to print more calendars and therefore more money will go toward's CASA programs.

Regardless of how much money is raised for this campaign, 100% of the donations will go to CASA. Gina Santi Photography is not keeping even one cent!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread out the word!! Post this campaign on your facebook wall, tell your family and friends, and please reach into your pockets and contribute to this worthy cause. You can help make the lives of those less fortunate a little easier.

 

THANKS IN ADVANCE FROM ALL OF US AT CASA!!!

story:
Empower Others Through Art

Picasso believed that we are all born artists, and 21inc's 21Leader Vanessa Paesani agrees.  She will be working with the clients (artists) of the Restigouche Hospital Centre in Campbellton in February 2013; clients will create art to make creative, client-generated hallways spaces.

This project arises from the belief that everyone is an artist and the process of making, and subsequently displaying, art is an empowering process.  Read more about 21inc's 21Leaders here: http://www.21inc.ca/2012-21leaders-nb.html.

 

How You Can Help & How I'd Like to Thank You

The funds required to deliver this project will be used for the creative supplies for the day.  We need:

  • Canvasses (x20) @ $20/piece = $400
  • Acrylic Paint = $300
  • Brushes = $100

Donating to this project will make the hallways of this centre more vibrant, while also empowering clients by displaying their art in the centre's hallways.  If you donate $25-$49, I will recognize your contribution to making this project possible on a recognition painting that will be displayed alongside the other art created that day.  If you donate $50 or more, I will recognize you in as an art aficionado in a separate recognition painting to be displayed alongside the others.

Photos from the day and the art created will be made available on my new blog: http://vanessapaesani.wordpress.com/

If we are unable to raise the total amount, the project will move forward, except that we will be able to provide less paint for the artists that day.  Please help me make this community-based project a success, and empower others to make art!

 

The Impact We'll Have

Creating and displaying art is empowering.  By believing that everyone is an artists, we will help the clients of the RHC see themselves as artists.  This art will be displayed to make the centre more vibrant and give artistic voice to the hallways.

 

If You Can't Donate Funds, I Can Still Use Your Help!

If you like this idea, but can't donate any funds, please help me accomplish my goal by sharing this project with others.  If you have any specific questions or feedback, please write me at: paesani.images@gmail.com.

Thank you.  Go be an artist.

story:
What is Newsprint Award? / ニュースプリントアワードとは？:

In 2013 bookdummypress, an independent bookstore & a publisher in New York and Reminders Photography Stronghold, a gallery in Tokyo joined forces to launch an international photography publication award to celebrate the newsprint’s contribution to the evolving creativity of self-publishing. 

Newsprint is not only an economical medium that allow a range of experimentation, but also has the potential of reaching a diverse audience wider and faster. Keeping this award open to photographers / artists without any entry fee, it is intended to stimulate to take a renew approach towards this format and to introduce photographers to a way to self-publish and self-distribute their work.

2013年にニューヨークで出版社とブックストアを運営するbookdummypressと、東京でギャラリーと写真総合施設を運営するReminders Photography Strongholdが設立した国際写真賞です。賞を設立した目的は、ニュースプリントによって個人出版物の可能性を高める事です。 

ニュースプリントは、実験的なことを試す事ができる経済的な媒体だけではなく、より広く、そしてより早く様々な人々に届ける事ができる可能性を持っています。  この賞は、写真家とアーティストたちへ開かれています。申し込み料金はかかりません。ニュースプリントというフォーマットへの新しいアプローチの方法、そして写真家達の作品の拡散を目的としています。


Why do we ask for your support? / なぜ私達はサポートが必要なのか？:

This is the second year of the Newsprint Award, we are striving to keep offering this award every year to individual photographers / artists. Your support will enable us to make the award sustainable and disseminate the winning project as wide as possible. The funds will cover the production of a newsprint publication, printed by Kyoto Shimbun, and a solo exhibition of this year's winner in Tokyo.

この賞は今年で二回目です。私達はこの賞を毎年写真家とアーティストに提供したいと思っています。あなたのサポートで、ニュースプリントアワードを毎年持続することを可能にし、受賞者のプロジェクトを世界中に広めることができます。  サポートで得られた資金は、京都新聞社で印刷する出版費、そして東京で行われる今年の受賞者の写真展をサポートします。


What do you get? / サポートの特典は？:

Depending on your level of support, our thank you gift will change. Check out the PERKS in the right sidebar for all the details.

① Pre-order for the Newsprint Award 2014 publication “The War Within” by Noi Satirat Damampai (includes shipping).

② A set of Newsprint Award 2013 & 2014 publications (includes shipping)

③ A set of Newsprint Award 2013 & 2014 publications + bdp original tote bag (includes shipping).


④ RPS Membership ISO 50. Workshop discount and free events. (worth $100)

⑤ Signed 25x14.2cm (10x6 inches) size print from Noi Satirat Damampai's "The War Within" + 2013 & 2014 publications (includes shipping). 

⑥ Set of five prints from Noi Satirat Damampai's "The War Within" + original box handmade by Noi's mother + 2013 & 2014 publications (includes shipping).


サポートの内容によって変わります。右のサイドバーの特典の詳細をご覧下さい。

① 2014年度受賞者Noi Satirat Damampai のニュースプリント ”The War Within”プレオーダー  （送料込み）

② 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品 （送料込み）

③ 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品 + bdpオリジナルトートバック （送料込み）

④ RPSメンバーシップISO50。ワークショップのディスカウントとイベント参加費が無料になります。（通常1万円）（送料込み）

⑤ Noi Satirat Damampai "The War Within" からサイン付き25x14.2cm (10x6 inches)のアーカイバルプリント1枚 + 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品（送料込み）　

⑥ ノイのお母さんお手製ボックス入りアーカイバルプリント5枚セット + 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品（送料込み）

2014 Winning Project / 2014年度受賞作品:

The 2014 winner, Noi Satirat Damampai (Thailand) portray the struggles of Karen ethnic group which is considered as the longest civil war in the world, in her award winning project “The War Within”. Unlike any other conflict the project is comprised of musing portraits and desolate landscape that show how intense but stale those lives have been through during the 60 years of fighting and fearing.

2014年度受賞者は、タイのフォトグラファーNoi Satirat Damampai。彼女は今回の受賞作”The War Within”で、世界で最も長く闘い続けるカレン族の姿を描写しています。他の内戦のプロジェクトと違い、この作品は瞑想的なポートレイトと荒涼とした風景写真で成り立っており、60年以上も続くこの争いがいかに過酷で生気がないものかを表している。


2014 Finalists:

“No Mans Land” by Norbert Goertz

“I’m Lost in the World” by Mito


Here are the names and comments of Juries that selected this year's winner and finalists:

Harvey Benge (Photographer)

It was a great pleasure to be involved as a judge in the 2014 Newsprint Award organized by Victor Sira and Shiori Kawasaki (bookdummypress) in New York and Yumi Goto and Masaru Goto (Reminders Photography Stronghold) in Tokyo. Overall I was impressed with the high level of work entered and it was difficult to arrive at a clear cut final decision. The stand-out winner, Thai photographer Noi Satirat Damampai exhibited a superb depth of 

understanding in the treatment her project. Called THE WAR WITHIN the project deals with the struggles of the Karen ethnic group. The work was sensitively realized in a manner that went beyond the usual presentation of documentary work and what's more the design of the book-work was in perfect harmony with the newsprint medium. Congratulations to Noi Satirat Damampai and all the participants.

Takayuki Kobayashi (flotsam books)

There were many interesting works, beautiful works and works that made me curious. I saw new talents from upcoming photographers. However, one question that came up in my mind is, how many of them actually thought about the final presentation format? Each work could be interesting and beautiful, or each image could be striking. But newsprint is the medium for this award. All the elements such as layout, image size and image quality would be very different from making a photobook. Simply you cannot rely on the print quality. When you apply to an award like this, it has to be more than taking pictures and uploading the files. You have to consider what kind of format you work with and try to output your idea accordingly. I feel like there were many potential applicants if they had been thought through and worked on it a bit further. 

John Stanley (CCNY Director)

Newsprint is not dead, but is more alive than ever, as evidenced by the astounding array of international entries to this year’s Newsprint Award that stretch the idea and scope of the medium. I was gladdened to see a wide variety to the approaches taken – from scholarly reportage of contemporary issues to quirky personal takes on small details of life. The winner, Noi Satirat Damampai, blends archetypal styles in the book “The War Within” to

show us more than the headline reports concerning the Karen ethnic group in Southeast Asia, working in a manner that offers a disorienting and personal take on a broad and long-lasting regional conflict. The two finalists hint at the diversity to the entries – Norbert Goertz’s “No Man’s Land” shows an urban fringe area in a deadpan but not humorless typological way, while Mito’s “I’m Lost in the World” offers us a personal fantasy world of shadowed figures trying to find their way through a romanticized pastoral land. These artists show that just as the overall volume of newsprint is shrinking in everyday industrial usage, the material is being destabilized and dynamically transformed into a contemporary individually-crafted artistic medium unique from its past connotations.


I hope you recognize the value of this award, and that you will want to support it and be part of it.

このアワードに対してより多くの方々の共感を得、ご支援頂ければ嬉しいです。

What is Newsprint Award? / ニュースプリントアワードとは？:

In 2013 bookdummypress, an independent bookstore & a publisher in New York and Reminders Photography Stronghold, a gallery in Tokyo joined forces to launch an international photography publication award to celebrate the newsprint’s contribution to the evolving creativity of self-publishing. Newsprint is not only an economical medium that allow a range of experimentation, but also has the potential of reaching a diverse audience wider and faster. Keeping this award open to photographers / artists without any entry fee, it is intended to stimulate to take a renew approach towards this format and to introduce photographers to a way to self-publish and self-distribute their work. 2013年にニューヨークで出版社とブックストアを運営するbookdummypressと、東京でギャラリーと写真総合施設を運営するReminders Photography Strongholdが設立した国際写真賞です。賞を設立した目的は、ニュースプリントによって個人出版物の可能性を高める事です。  ニュースプリントは、実験的なことを試す事ができる経済的な媒体だけではなく、より広く、そしてより早く様々な人々に届ける事ができる可能性を持っています。  この賞は、写真家とアーティストたちへ開かれています。申し込み料金はかかりません。ニュースプリントというフォーマットへの新しいアプローチの方法、そして写真家達の作品の拡散を目的としています。Why do we ask for your support? / なぜ私達はサポートが必要なのか？:

This is the second year of the Newsprint Award, we are striving to keep offering this award every year to individual photographers / artists. Your support will enable us to make the award sustainable and disseminate the winning project as wide as possible. The funds will cover the production of a newsprint publication, printed by Kyoto Shimbun, and a solo exhibition of this year's winner in Tokyo.この賞は今年で二回目です。私達はこの賞を毎年写真家とアーティストに提供したいと思っています。あなたのサポートで、ニュースプリントアワードを毎年持続することを可能にし、受賞者のプロジェクトを世界中に広めることができます。  サポートで得られた資金は、京都新聞社で印刷する出版費、そして東京で行われる今年の受賞者の写真展をサポートします。What do you get? / サポートの特典は？:
Depending on your level of support, our thank you gift will change. 
Check out the PERKS in the right sidebar for all the details.
① Pre-order for the Newsprint Award 2014 publication “The War Within” by Noi Satirat Damampai (includes shipping).
 ② A set of Newsprint Award 2013 & 2014 publications (includes shipping) ③ A set of Newsprint Award 2013 & 2014 publications + bdp original tote bag (includes shipping).④ RPS Membership ISO 50. Workshop discount and free events. (worth $100)
⑤ Signed  25x14.2cm (10x6 inches) size print from Noi Satirat Damampai's "The War Within" + 2013 & 2014 publications (includes shipping).   ⑥ Set of five prints from Noi Satirat Damampai's "The War Within" + original box handmade by Noi's mother + 2013 & 2014 publications (includes shipping).サポートの内容によって変わります。右のサイドバーの特典の詳細をご覧下さい。① 2014年度受賞者Noi Satirat Damampai のニュースプリント ”The War Within”プレオーダー  （送料込み） ② 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品 （送料込み） ③ 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品 + bdpオリジナルトートバック （送料込み） ④ RPSメンバーシップISO50。ワークショップのディスカウントとイベント参加費が無料になります。（通常1万円）（送料込み）⑤ Noi Satirat Damampai "The War Within" からサイン付き25x14.2cm (10x6 inches)のアーカイバルプリント1枚 + 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品（送料込み）　⑥ ノイのお母さんお手製ボックス入りアーカイバルプリント5枚セット + 2013年と2014年度のニュースプリント受賞作品（送料込み）
2014 Winning Project / 2014年度受賞作品:
The 2014 winner, Noi Satirat Damampai (Thailand) portray the struggles of Karen ethnic group which is considered as the longest civil war in the world, in her award winning project “The War Within”. Unlike any other conflict the project is comprised of musing portraits and desolate landscape that show how intense but stale those lives have been through during the 60 years of fighting and fearing.
2014年度受賞者は、タイのフォトグラファーNoi Satirat Damampai。彼女は今回の受賞作”The War Within”で、世界で最も長く闘い続けるカレン族の姿を描写しています。他の内戦のプロジェクトと違い、この作品は瞑想的なポートレイトと荒涼とした風景写真で成り立っており、60年以上も続くこの争いがいかに過酷で生気がないものかを表している。 2014 Finalists:
“No Mans Land” by Norbert Goertz
“I’m Lost in the World” by Mito
Here are the names and comments of Juries that selected this year's winner and finalists:
Harvey Benge (Photographer)
It was a great pleasure to be involved as a judge in the 2014 Newsprint Award organized by Victor Sira and Shiori Kawasaki (bookdummypress) in New York and Yumi Goto and Masaru Goto (Reminders Photography Stronghold) in Tokyo. Overall I was impressed with the high level of work entered and it was difficult to arrive at a clear cut final decision. The stand-out winner, Thai photographer Noi Satirat Damampai exhibited a superb depth of 
understanding in the treatment her project. Called THE WAR WITHIN the project deals with the struggles of the Karen ethnic group. The work was sensitively realized in a manner that went beyond the usual presentation of documentary work and what's more the design of the book-work was in perfect harmony with the newsprint medium. Congratulations to Noi Satirat Damampai and all the participants.
Takayuki Kobayashi (flotsam books)
There were many interesting works, beautiful works and works that made me curious. I saw new talents from upcoming photographers. However, one question that came up in my mind is, how many of them actually thought about the final presentation format? Each work could be interesting and beautiful, or each image could be striking. But newsprint is the medium for this award. All the elements such as layout, image size and image quality would be very different from making a photobook. Simply you cannot rely on the print quality. When you apply to an award like this, it has to be more than taking pictures and uploading the files. You have to consider what kind of format you work with and try to output your idea accordingly. I feel like there were many potential applicants if they had been thought through and worked on it a bit further. 
John Stanley (CCNY Director)
Newsprint is not dead, but is more alive than ever, as evidenced by the astounding array of international entries to this year’s Newsprint Award that stretch the idea and scope of the medium. I was gladdened to see a wide variety to the approaches taken – from scholarly reportage of contemporary issues to quirky personal takes on small details of life. The winner, Noi Satirat Damampai, blends archetypal styles in the book “The War Within” to
show us more than the headline reports concerning the Karen ethnic group in Southeast Asia, working in a manner that offers a disorienting and personal take on a broad and long-lasting regional conflict. The two finalists hint at the diversity to the entries – Norbert Goertz’s “No Man’s Land” shows an urban fringe area in a deadpan but not humorless typological way, while Mito’s “I’m Lost in the World” offers us a personal fantasy world of shadowed figures trying to find their way through a romanticized pastoral land. These artists show that just as the overall volume of newsprint is shrinking in everyday industrial usage, the material is being destabilized and dynamically transformed into a contemporary individually-crafted artistic medium unique from its past connotations.I hope you recognize the value of this award, and that you will want to support it and be part of it.このアワードに対してより多くの方々の共感を得、ご支援頂ければ嬉しいです。

story:
Hey Im Todd Glass, and I want more money.

Im Todd Glass and one thing you should know about me is that i'm really into money. But I do good things with it. Please give me some of you're money so I have a lot of it.

story:
Short Summary

I am an experimental sculptor asking questions about our environment and revealing the beauty of natural phenomena through my work. I blend art and science to create unique multi-media works and I have been awarded a year-long artist's residency in Iceland to explore the landscape and to make new work.The research trip of a lifetime.

During my artistic expedition I will be researching the fluid dynamics of lava flows, the cracking and popping of glaciers and turning the spectacular Aurora Borealis into sound.

Above: a selection of some of the macro photography c-type ice prints available. Take a look at the gallery for the prints on offer: ice prints

My work focuses on patterns in nature and natural processes, challenging the way we look at materials and the world around us. As team leader, I'm going to be exploring natural processes in geology, which will be feeding into my recent 'experiments' exploring magnetism, fluid dynamics, harmony and sound waves. Through scientific experimentation both out in the field and in my ‘lab’ I will reveal the processes of natural phenomena using light, sound and movement.


Above: One of my experiments exploring magnetism.

I studied at Central Saint Martins School of Art and Design and Camberwell College of Art, graduating with a ceramics degree in 2003. I have worked on some wildly varying projects, from making dresses out of bread for Jean Paul Gaultier to sculptural commissions for Radiohead to architectural model-making for Norman Foster and directing large-scale video projections for Gwyneth Herbert's Sea Cabinet. It is safe to say that I enjoy exploring new materials and approaches.

I collaborate with specialists from all walks of life, from tailors and architects to musicians and theoretical physicists.

Above: This is a test for a kinetic sculpture which will be made from porcelain and magnets.

I regularly respond to a site as a starting point for my sculpture and there couldn't be an environment more suited to my work.

Having a full year to dedicate to focused research, experimentation and making will not only take my practice to the next level and provide an explosion of ideas but it will also give me the chance to share with you the awe-inspiring processes and phenomena of the natural world. I look forward to sharing my findings with you.

What I Need & What You Get

I have most of the basics of the expedition sorted but need your support to be able to buy the necessary materials and equipment to do my observational skills justice and take my 'lab' into the field. A scientist and intrepid explorer is nothing without the tools of their trade to prove their theories.

I will be exploring light, sound and movement in the natural world which will require things such as prisms, motors, mirrors, light sensors and of course some recording equipment (both audio and visual). I work in both digital and more traditional media so things such as photographic paper (for pinhole photography) also need accounting for.

Above - The beautiful refractory patterns coming from the solid crystal, commemorative, Fire and Ice Expedition 'Ice Cube' which can be yours when you become my Quarter Master.

All my work has been leading up to this artistic expedition so it seems fitting that I should offer some of my research in exchange for your support. So for instance, I offer you a signed limited edition print of one of my 'magnetic' drawings in exchange for the pledge of £45 and the privileged title of 'Lava Dodger'. If you just can't settle for anything less than an original drawing then a £200 pledge will get that in the bag as my 'Nordic Navigator'.

Above - Work in progress of one of the large scale 'Magnetic Landscape' drawings on offer when you sign up for the 'Prince of Whales' perk.

Take a look at the drawings available on either the gallery section of the campaign or on my flickr page here. Drawings on flickr New drawings are being added regularly so do keep your eyes peeled and when making a pledge make sure to specify the drawing you're after.

Metal incarnation of one of my drawings from the 'magnetic' series, yours when you sign up to be my 'Top Geyser'.

Magnetic Drawings

Become a 'Quarter Master' and carry out your own experiments on light as we do in the field. A crystal 'Ice Cube' is yours for the taking...


I also have limited edition porcelain and glass 'Ice Cubes', black and white C-type ice photography, studio visits and sacred geometry lessons, not forgetting abook of drawings to peruse at your leisure.

C-type 'Ice' print.

Limited Edition Porcelain and Glass 'Ice Cube'

There are perks for everyone, from a postcard or Polaroid thank you, all the way up to a unique sculpture depicting the atomic structure of ice using porcelain and glass.

'Ice' sculpture depicting the atomic structure of ice in porcelain and glass.

The initial three months of my time in Iceland will be focused on exploring the landscape and researching possible sculptures, installations and artworks. So even if I'm unable to raise all of the funds necessary to execute all of the expansive ideas I have bubbling away, the money raised will at least help me to get to the stage of having the initial research to allow me to put together more detailed proposals and funding applications to organisations, institutions, galleries and funding bodies. This is the first step towards increasing the sustainability of my practice, allowing it to grow.

The Impact

Your contribution to my expedition will allow me to share the awe inspiring natural phenomena the world has to offer. My practice blends art and science and it is my intention to make scientific notions more accessible to the general public. I will be collaborating with specialists in their field and through workshops, exhibitions and events I will not only teach but inspire people to ask questions, explore and encourage cross disciplinary collaboration.

Above: Visuals from Gwyneth Herbert's Sea Cabinet

In a recent project I made the move into time based, interactive work as a result of working with singer, composer, writer and producer Gwyneth Herbert. This irrevocably developed my work in ways I could never have imagined. It is this search into the unknown which I not only find spectacularly exciting but essential for progress in both art and science.

Other Ways That You Can Help

If you aren't able to make a donation never fear, you can still help. I ask you to share this project with as many people as possible. The more people who join the expedition the more discoveries we can make together. So please use the indiegogo share tools so we can make this expedition one to be proud of.

story:
A LITTLE ABOUT ME.

Hello everyone! My name is Josh, I am a full-time undergraduate transfer student at the Fashion Institute of Technology (FIT) in New York City, majoring in Illustration. I am seeking your help with funding for art supplies required during my next semester of study as well as those necessary for future independent projects. As I'm sure many can imagine, it's tough being a young New Yorker providing for myself without financial support from parents, all while attending school and working part-time.

Unfortunately with my current job I only make just enough to be able to pay key bills, afford meals, and a weekly Metrocard (I can't even imagine what the fare hike will do to my wallet)! This is why I need your help! I love school, being able to create art, and being able to properly finish art assignments and projects! Art supplies are so expensive and required supplies are used frequently in my classes; supplies run out and expenses add up so quickly!

To last me through May, I am asking for help securing $1,500 to manage these expenses; it will be a huge lifesaver!

 

What I Need & What You Get

 Thankfully due to the Pell Grant and other scholarships, financial aid is enough to cover tuition but of course not to purchase crucial supplies. 

The goal is set at $1,500 to afford all the art supplies I will need for upcoming independent projects (art shows and exhibits) as well as my Spring semester classes. 

The classes I will be taking are as follows:

ART HISTORY WESTERN ART/ RENNAISANCE

PRINCIPLE OF ILLUSTRATION 2

INTRODUCTION TO ADOBE PHOTOSHOP/ILLUSTRATOR

APPLYING COLOR TO ILLUSTRATE

PERSPECTIVE DRAWING, COMPOSITION AND CONCEPT

ANATOMY LIFE DRAWING ILLUSTRATION 2

GENERAL ILLUSTRATION DRAWING 2

 

Here is a non-exhaustive list of the supplies I need:

Text books (6)

canvas

acrylic & oil paints

paint extender

studio easel and accessories 

paint Brushes

colored pastel

markers

18x24 All purpose drawing pad (4)

black india ink

graphite pencils

charcoal pencils

kneaded eraser

masonite drawing board

 

 To extend my gratitude toward contributors, I will be beyond delighted to email attachments of my original photography and digital illustrations which will serve wonderfully as wallpapers or poster prints!

 

The Impact

Your contributions to this campaign and with it the fulfillment of my goal, will allow me to get through this upcoming semester without suffering the same financial constraints that I experienced this Fall. My schoolwork will benefit greatly from the absence this stress (and of course the presence of adequate supplies) and there will be no way I can thank you all enough!

If I don't however, reach my goal, all contributions will go toward purchasing new art supplies and will be gladly appreciated!!

If I surpass my goal of $1,500, all excess funds will be allocated towards a study abroad trip studying (what will you be studying? art history?) to Florence, Italy in May 2013!!!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I totally understand that not all are in positions to donate! However, to help you can share this campaign with everyone you know who may be interested in contributing (every dollar counts!). Please also feel free to share my work if you enjoy it, to friends and associates whom you know appreciate art! LETS INSPIRE THE WORLD!

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE!!!

story:
We are called Sixty Inches From Center (SIFC) because we document, archive and support art that exists outside the central iconic art institutions in Chicago. With video, audio, photography, writing, projects, and community engagement, SIFC captures and contributes to the most innovative aspects of our city’s peripheral visual culture.
_
All documentation collected is cataloged on the Sixty Inches From Center Archive and used as an educational and promotional support tool. The Sixty Inches From Center Collective Project focuses on creating new ways to engage the Chicago community with the vanguard visual arts. These efforts combined make Sixty Inches From Center an essential portal to the contemporary art periphery in Chicago and act as a testament to this work’s deserved place at the global art table.
_
From audience-curated programming to micro funding and sponsorships, the look and success of SIFC and our endeavors depends on the support and engagement of the creative community in and around Chicago.
_
We at Sixty Inches From Center are not trying to reinvent the wheel. We are looking for ways to strengthen the arts programs, artist collaboratives and creative practices or spaces that already exist and bring together the many different underground organizations, artists and collectives that are doing amazing things. Our goal is to create new bridges and act as facilitators of collaboration in Chicago’s art scene.

Making things transparent for our supporters: www.SIFCChicago.wordpress.com
_
The Money Situation: The truth of the matter is that if we want SIFC to function and be up and running in the best possible way, we need about $10,000. We are asking for $3,600 because it is the minimal amount that it will take to launch SIFC. Therefore, any way you can help would be very beneficial!
_
Our Team: Our current team consists of 15 art historians, artists, writers, editors, filmmakers, web designers and graphic designers all working and living in the Chicagoland area. Our advisory board was chosen based on a combination of their investment in the Chicago art community, their own areas of art expertise and their unwavering support of our vision. They are educators, artists, directors of non-profit organizations, writers, art historians and filmmakers in new media.
_
Why We Do What We Do and Why We Need You: Our archiving project and launch campaign are our primary focuses when approaching IndieGoGo for funds. While IndieGoGo offers an answer to the questions of where funds will come from to make these innovative projects happen, Sixty Inches From Center asks, “What happens to these events, artists and projects when they’re done?” Many of the vanguard art practices happening locally, nationally and internationally are lost due to lack of proper documentation. Many of the artists and movements missing from the top-used textbooks are absent from the art historical dialogue because that information wasn’t properly recorded. Once the archive compiles a substantial amount of content, it will be serve as an educational tool locally and nationally, able to be studied and referenced.
_
Carrying Out Our Mission: With proper documentation also comes the need for the most cutting-edge and efficient technology. Our team needs top-quality equipment that can easily tag along as we go to art events and artist studios, and then be uploaded to the website in a timely manner. We don’t want our presence to be a big production at these events, or to overshadow the event or art itself. Therefore, we need things such as Sanyo VPC-CG20 Dual HD 10MP Camcorders, DSLR NEX-5 cameras and Olympus WS 400S 1 GB Digital voice recorders for our team. In order for these items to function correctly, we need other things such as memory cards, external hard drives and memory card readers. This will also allow each person on the team to cover video, audio and photography with only two very small and compact tools.
_
To address our concern with community engagement we are also raising funds for two other initiatives: the SIFC truck and SIFC traveling photo booth.
_
SIFC will purchase a vehicle to travel around Chicago creating temporary and explosive art events throughout the city. The idea behind this is to 1) be a constant promotional tool for SIFC, 2) travel throughout the city and engage as many different communities as possible, and 3) offer constant collaborative art experiences with Chicago’s communities. Instead of trying to get people to come to us, we will come to them in addition to partnering with art spaces around the city. Also, artists will be encouraged to propose ideas around this mobile curatorial tool.
_
The SIFC Photo Booth will also be a traveling initiative. This hand-crafted booth will travel along with us and be set up at different locations in an attempt to capture the faces behind Chicago’s art community. This too will become a trademark, promotional tool for SIFC.
story_txt:
We are called Sixty Inches From Center (SIFC) because we document, archive and support art that exists outside the central iconic art institutions in Chicago. With video, audio, photography, writing, projects, and community engagement, SIFC captures and contributes to the most innovative aspects of our city’s peripheral visual culture.
_
All documentation collected is cataloged on the Sixty Inches From Center Archive and used as an educational and promotional support tool. The Sixty Inches From Center Collective Project focuses on creating new ways to engage the Chicago community with the vanguard visual arts. These efforts combined make Sixty Inches From Center an essential portal to the contemporary art periphery in Chicago and act as a testament to this work’s deserved place at the global art table. 
_
From audience-curated programming to micro funding and sponsorships, the look and success of SIFC and our endeavors depends on the support and engagement of the creative community in and around Chicago.
_
We at Sixty Inches From Center are not trying to reinvent the wheel. We are looking for ways to strengthen the arts programs, artist collaboratives and creative practices or spaces that already exist and bring together the many different underground organizations, artists and collectives that are doing amazing things.  Our goal is to create new bridges and act as facilitators of collaboration in Chicago’s art scene.
Making things transparent for our supporters: www.SIFCChicago.wordpress.com 
_
The Money Situation:  The truth of the matter is that if we want SIFC to function and be up and running in the best possible way, we need about $10,000.  We are asking for $3,600 because it is the minimal amount that it will take to launch SIFC.  Therefore, any way you can help would be very beneficial!
_
Our Team:  Our current team consists of 15 art historians, artists, writers, editors, filmmakers, web designers and graphic designers all working and living in the Chicagoland area. Our advisory board was chosen based on a combination of their investment in the Chicago art community, their own areas of art expertise and their unwavering support of our vision. They are educators, artists, directors of non-profit organizations, writers, art historians and filmmakers in new media.  
_
Why We Do What We Do and Why We Need You:  Our archiving project and launch campaign are our primary focuses when approaching IndieGoGo for funds.  While IndieGoGo offers an answer to the questions of where funds will come from to make these innovative projects happen, Sixty Inches From Center asks, “What happens to these events, artists and projects when they’re done?”  Many of the vanguard art practices happening locally, nationally and internationally are lost due to lack of proper documentation.   Many of the artists and movements missing from the top-used textbooks are absent from the art historical dialogue because that information wasn’t properly recorded.  Once the archive compiles a substantial amount of content, it will be serve as an educational tool locally and nationally, able to be studied and referenced.
_
Carrying Out Our Mission: With proper documentation also comes the need for the most cutting-edge and efficient technology.  Our team needs top-quality equipment that can easily tag along as we go to art events and artist studios, and then be uploaded to the website in a timely manner.  We don’t want our presence to be a big production at these events, or to overshadow the event or art itself.  Therefore, we need things such as Sanyo VPC-CG20 Dual HD 10MP Camcorders, DSLR NEX-5 cameras and Olympus WS 400S 1 GB Digital voice recorders for our team.  In order for these items to function correctly, we need other things such as memory cards, external hard drives and memory card readers. This will also allow each person on the team to cover video, audio and photography with only two very small and compact tools. 
_
To address our concern with community engagement we are also raising funds for two other initiatives: the SIFC truck and SIFC traveling photo booth. 
_SIFC will purchase a vehicle to travel around Chicago creating temporary and explosive art events throughout the city.  The idea behind this is to 1) be a constant promotional tool for SIFC, 2) travel throughout the city and engage as many different communities as possible, and 3) offer constant collaborative art experiences with Chicago’s communities.  Instead of trying to get people to come to us, we will come to them in addition to partnering with art spaces around the city.  Also, artists will be encouraged to propose ideas around this mobile curatorial tool.
_
The SIFC Photo Booth will also be a traveling initiative.  This hand-crafted booth will  travel along with us and be set up at different locations in an attempt to capture the faces behind Chicago’s art community.  This too will become a trademark, promotional tool for SIFC.

story:
What is it all about?

TIFF 2012 is the second edition of a new photography festival in Poland created by young people with energy and passion for photography. TIFF is meant to change it's formula every year in order to discover new possibilities of presenting photography. In 2012 edition invited artists will create an exhibition by working together in one place and at one time. This event will be transmitted online via our website and it's results will be shown during the festival's main weekend on November 8th to 11th. 

We created our program basing on what we believe is lacking in other similar events which is diversity and creativity. This festival is not only directed to people with extensive knowledge in photography, but also to people who had never participated in such events and who share a desire to see more and know more.

We are aware that organizing TIFF 2012 with it's complex and eventful program is not an easy task but we believe that with your help we can do it. Contributing to this campaign you will not only help us make our dream come true, but you will also support young emerging artists who wait for a chance to present their work to the wider audience. Be a part of TIFF!

 

Who Are We?

"BLIK" Foundation is a young non goverment organization, focused on visual education, that realises its purposes trough photography. Few of our projects were officially selected for the program of European Capital of Culture 2016 in Wroclaw. TIFF International Photography Festival is one of them. 

 

More about TIFF International Photography Festival

An idea of a TIFF has arrived with a dynamic growth of Wroclaw's culture. It seems like there is still not enough attention for the art of photography. In 2011, during the pilot edition of TIFF, this extremely daring desire to renew the influence of Wroclaw's artistic circles on Polish photography arose inside of us. With the birth of this festival we try to connect with a traditional photography output of Wroclaw which towards years affected the whole country, as well as neighbouring countries. We would like to resume this trend and become the catalyst for evolution of photography through various innovatory, fresh, and inspiring activities around photography and related arts, offered to local, artistic and academical circles.

Two major ways of 2012 edition are cooperation of Visegrad Group countries and "Process in construction". First subject is a trial of a battle with a lack of thought exchange between Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and Hungary, which we have noticed lately. "Process in construction" is an idea inspired by the dynamic of modern world. We have decided that this years form is going to be focused on construction, bottom-up actions, establishing new standards and ownerships. Moreover, in a response to the modern issue of existence between the virtual and real world, we would like to report the wide part of festival actions in the real time, simultaneously on the Internet. That way we could give tools for active participation in these actions to the virtual receiver.

 

This year TIFF consists of three major section: Main Program, where invited guests would work on common exhibition searching for new ways in artistic photography; Theoretical Section, based on media-lab form, by which theoretics from different countries would exchange directions of searching and development of theoretical thought around photography; Section of Publications, which would sum up and spread bottom-up actions, showing primary need of creation and express not only through the work, but also through the form of presentation. Additionally, under the TIFF wings we are planning to organize the review of the artistic Schools of Photography, Debut’s Presentation, and also Accompanying Exhibitions. All of it in November 2012.

 

What Do We Need?

 

The total budget of TIFF Festival is 83 000$. In this sum are:

cost of artist fees - 12 000$

costs of travel and accommodation 21 000$

production of exhibitions and preparing festival’s space 23 000$

promotion and publications 17 000$

translations 6 000$

cost of administration 4 000$

 

We hope to raise the campaign up to 50,000$. Revenues from tickets and gadgets are expected in a sum around 15 000$. We are still looking for private sponsors in Poland for another part of the amount. Please, partake in helping us! Even if you don't have money, you can help. Please share the link to this campaign on your Facebook or Twitter account or inform your friends in other ways :)

 

The Impact

The attendance of the 1st Polish-German edition that approached 4000 viewers has proved a demand for a photo festival in Wroclaw. The program comprised 35h of workshops, 11 artist slide shows, 11 exhibitions, 2 concerts,3 debates, festival cinema: 4 film screenings and an all-Polish debut open call with 5 winners. All took place in 5 galleries in Wroclaw such as WrocÅ‚aw Contemporary Museum.

The festival was under 10 official media auspices and appeared in all accessible media including dozens of articles, 3 TV broadcasts and 5 radio broadcasts. We have been granted a sponsorship by Goethe Institute and Council of Lower Silesia's Governor office.

TIFF is the 1st photography festival in Wroclaw and a rarity in Poland.  A month-long festival (Oct, 26th- Nov, 30th) will constitute 39 events, 1,000 publications, gather 70 artists from 7 countries and thousands of viewers. We are going to promote young, talented photographers, and give them opportunity to meet professional, hot name, photographers. We are propagating the idea of photography as an important way of contact with art. Due to this fact, we offer the festival to a very wide range of audience and the ticket are believed to cost approximately 7,25$ and will include entrance to all of the events, workshops and lectures.  

We have many positive opinions from experts and potential viewers and that is why we are very excited about this year program. Here are some of them:


„[...]The level of photography and its presentation was very high and all exhibition openings were noticeable events in cultural calendar of Wroclaw. Each of three exhibitions had different curator’s idea which made the formula of it more interesting and also as a series of events gave an image of what are young photographers looking for in modern art (...). Having in mind great cooperation with creators of TIFF, and appreciating their work for reviving the photographic circles in Wroclaw (...), we would like to cooperate with festival during the next edition in november 2012 (...).”

Dorota Monkiewicz, Director of WrocÅ‚aw Contemporary Museum (from the official support letter)

 

„To be one of five winners of TIFF competition for young photographers „Debuts 2011” and the possibility to present my work to the wide audience, was my personal success. Being part of the festival gave me the possibility to promote my artistic work, but also to meet with public what was a big development for me and was very inspiring. Giving the opportunity to the young, active and talented, but still not promoted artists is a very good idea. I hope that thanks to such and other activities of TIFF Festival, work of less known photographers will be noticed and appreciated for the people not connected with photographic circles, and will help young artists in their careers in Poland and abroad.”

Joanna Ziajka, photographer (from the official support letter)

 

„BLIK is a dynamic and active foundation from Wroclaw, which we started to work with during the application for the European Capital of Culture. From the beginning we met with big engagement from their site, which was proved by applying with many ambitious cultural projects, and also by active work on promoting wroclaw’s candidature.”

 

Institution of Culture Wroclaw 2016, 26.05.2012

 

What do you get?

We prepared for you different perks. From the simple "thank you" e- mail, trough tickets, postcards, festival's gadgets, catalogues, up to limited prints and special invitation. You can be sure that none of our supporterts will be left with out our gratitude.

Please notice that all of the printed materials will be sent to you during festival or in one week after so that the artists can sign them for you. 

 

About the Campaign

Check out our profile for more updates, video and pictures and latest news about our work on this project. 

Wait for promotional video and more info on our campaign. Soon our website will be released in english.

story:
if you missed this funding deadline please feel free to send any donations our way through paypal with a short note including your address and tshirt size. when prompted for recipient use the following address: coralshort@gmail.com

 

we will send the perks your way by the end of the summer. 

 

THANK YOU!!!!

 

We need your financial help to take the Hole-y Army Puppet Parade to the Streets! Dyke marches everywhere get ready!!! A fantastically luscious carnival of colourful textile puppets is coming your way! Click HERE to see them!

 

Hi I am Coral Short from Montreal/ NYC.  I am working with Ariel Speedwagon from Brooklyn to bring some stellar community art and trans activism to this year's dyke marches. I have created 100 large vaginas/ hole puppets out of textiles to walk in the dyke march. March with us! We would love to have you join our radical love army! Ariel Speedwagon is our drill sargent extrodinaire. 

 

The dyke march is by nature a feminist protest march. 

  

We welcome all bodies who have ever IDed as a dyke past, present or future to join our Hole-y Army.  Self identification is integral to the new generation of queers.  We are all more than the sum of our body parts. We believe in self-determination over our own bodies  March with us for inclusion of all dyke bodies! Genderqueers welcome! 

 

Trans women are our friends, our lovers, our co-workers and our neighbors. Trans women are not strangers to our communities. Trans women have been a part of queer, lesbian, and dyke communities since the beginning. Trans women have been marching alongside otherwomen since day one, and still are today! 

 

We at the hole-y army celebrate holes of all shapes and colors and sizes on whatever gendered or genderless body they may inhabit, as hairy or shaved as they may be.  

 

Let's create positive change together through art!  Community change and evolution keeps us real and relevant to the new generation.  We are ALL gorgeous, sexy, and brave, not just some of us.  Support our community art activism cause through making a donation.  Your money will contribute to queer art activism today.

 

New York! Toronto! Montreal!

COME MARCH WITH US and choose your favorite hole puppet to march with.  

 

NYC DYKE MARCH June 23rd

$1,000 needed for:  shipping/ van rental/ gas/ travel expenses to get to new york/ per diems*

 

TORONTO DYKE MARCH June 30th

$1,000 for: shipping/ van rental/ gas, travel (airfare for ariel!) expenses to get to toronto/ per diems*

 

MONTREAL FIRST EVER DYKE MARCH August 18th

$300 for food and water for our 100 performers, gas/ per diems*. 


* both performances will have snacks and water before and after the marches to show appreciation to our 300 puppet performers who are putting in hours of their lives to execute this gay art miracle!

 

Check out our fabulous perks!  Your item(s) will be shipped to you in August when all the dyke marches are over :) Make sure to tell us your t-shirt size and give us your address:  hole.y.army@gmail.com

 

There are all many levels of participation in the Hole-y Army:  FUNDING us, MAKING your own hole and bringing it with you, CARRYING a hole during the march or REPOSTING this project to your friend networks!  like us on facebook here

We thank you from the bottom of our holes for your support.

We couldn't do this without you.

sisters in solidarity,

xx coral and ariel

 

-------------------------------------------------------------------

 

This project is supported by Allied Productions, Tennis Court, Materials for the Arts in New York City and Toronto Dyke March.

This work has evolved due to fantastic and thought provoking  discussion and dialogue with my trans community:  Nicki Green, Emma Deboncouer, Francesca Di Nascosto, Aaron Blaise, Tuesday Smillie, Pilar Gallego, Lucas Crawford and André Azevedo.

Contributing hole maker so far: André Azevedo, Ask Nicely, Jenn Dickman, Nicki Green, Gaël Krajzman Johns, Kestryl and Sassafras Lowrey, Felix Namasté, Ariel Speedwagon, and Christine Chateau. Please feel free to make your own hole on a stick!

If you interested in the Hole-y Army performing this puppet theatre at your Dyke March or Pride contact us! hole.y.army@gmail.com

Contributing hole maker so far: André Azevedo, Ask Nicely, Jenn Dickman, Nicki Green, Gaël Krajzman Johns, Kestryl and Sassafras Lowrey, Felix Namasté, Ariel Speedwagon, and Christine Chateau. Please feel free to make your own hole on a stick!

story:
$100,000 seems like a lot but either way you get your Perk.  Boston will open with or without the success of this campaign, even still we already have a functioning shop!

Thank you for coming to our campaign page. 

If this is your first time here, or would like to learn more about what we are trying to accomplish and why, please scroll down and read on. 

If you are already familiar with our campaign and have already decided to contribute, please direct your attention to the column on your right. 

___________________________________________________________________

 

Our Existing Business is Great - but we want more and this is what we are going to do about it....

Boston Body Art Studio & Gallery

A Hybrid Body Art Modification Studio & Commission-Free Art Gallery for the City's Art Students' in the Center of Boston. 

The Body Art Studio will employ only the best in their craft offering tattoos, body piercing and eventually permanent makeup.  The Gallery will gather it's artwork from local art students & artists looking to get into, or advancing in, the Art Community.  The space is so large, we couldn't not put one in and will still have room for retail.  Unlike other galleries though we will already have a fully functioning business to cover the overhead, so 100% of the money from art sales will go directly into the (student) Artist's pocket.  We feel it will be the perfect hybrid, continually drawing inspiration from one another.   

     But our Campaign's success is dependent on the community, who will decide if this is something they want for their community.  No matter if this Campaign is successful or not the shop will still open, but we are hoping this works (hint, hint.....)

 ___________________________________________________________________

You're Probably Asking Yourself-

"Why The Hell Would They Give Away Free Time on Tattoos?"

Well that's simple.  Sure we can (and may still have to, LOL) go to a bank and pay a ton of interest to a bunch of faceless suits (no offense to any bankers who may be reading this) and open like every other business does.....  or we can try something different.

We would rather give away some serious discounts, for a limited time, and "Pay it Forward" to Our Clients, Rather than a Bank. 
The people we wouldn't already have had a business for the past four years without..... and will now hopefully earn some new Clients along the way.

  ___________________________________________________________________

Why We Need Funds-

This space has been sitting vacant for a very long time and requires a complete gut and renovation.  Which means it will be absolutely pristine when we are finished but getting to that point is going to cost some serious cash and a little bit of time and labor.  Also- Licensing, Permitting, Materials, Advertising, Employees, Taxes, Merchandise, Furniture, Body Art Equipment & Supplies, Insurance, Gallery Set Up.... It all adds up very quickly.  
     We decided to let everyone get involved and thank them generously in return.  We've come up with some great Perks and hope you wont miss your chance to take advantage of them while they last, because once this campaign is over there will never be pricing like this again at either shop.

 

Get Perks!  Perks!  Perks!  Perks!  Perks!  Perks!  Perks!  Perks!

If you are generous enough to contribute pick from any of these Perks below.  Prices are suggestions but you can contribute any amount you want for any Perk as long as you meet the minimum requirement. 

___________________________________________________________________

  

$1+ for an eShout Out 

Every little bit counts.  If you would like to help us reach our goal please keep in mind every dollar counts.  If enough people get together and each do a small thing, combined it becomes a great big thing.  We realize that & will appreciate every contribution towards making our dream a reality.  If you choose this perk you can contribute any amount from $1 to $10,000 or more (lol, we wish).  Even if it’s only a few dollars, we still want to express our gratitude, and will do so by giving you a shout out on our website.  Every Funder will be listed here unless they want to remain anonymous.

$10 for a Decal

Want a wicked badass sticker of your very own?  Slap it on your laptop, fridge, bumper, the annoying roommate asleep in the next room, wherever.  The only way to get one of these badass decal stickers is to become a Funder on this Campaign so don't miss your chance.  We will ship it anywhere in the Continental US.
And get your name on our website's Thank You List.

___________________________________________________________________                       

 

$20+ for the Great Wall of Funder

Help out our cause and you will be forever in our hearts, on our website, and on our walls too.  Each Funder of $20 or more will get their name etched onto a little metal Funder Plate that we will mount permanently onto a wall in the studio for all to see.  Once we are open for business, stop by for a picture with your plate, then post it online so everyone knows what a wonderful and generous person you are, as if they don't know already.  And get your name on our website's Thank You List.

___________________________________________________________________

 

$30 for the Shirt Off Our Back- Mens

OK, not literally but it will get you a new Tshirt made just for this campaign.  Pick up one of these stylish limited edition Men's Tshirts with the studio's logo on one side and "I Support Ink & Art" on the other.  Shipping included anywhere in the Continental US.  You help us get our doors open in the process, get a Funder Plate in the studio and get your name on our website's Thank You List.

story_txt:
$100,000 seems like a lot but either way you get your Perk.  Boston will open with or without the success of this campaign, even still we already have a functioning shop!
Thank you for coming to our campaign page. 
If this is your first time here, or would like to learn more about what we are trying to accomplish and why, please scroll down and read on.  
If you are already familiar with our campaign and have already decided to contribute, please direct your attention to the column on your right.  
___________________________________________________________________
 
Our Existing Business is Great - but we want more and this is what we are going to do about it....
Boston Body Art Studio & Gallery
A Hybrid Body Art Modification Studio & Commission-Free Art Gallery for the City's Art Students' in the Center of Boston.  
The Body Art Studio will employ only the best in their craft offering tattoos, body piercing and eventually permanent makeup.  The Gallery will gather it's artwork from local art students & artists looking to get into, or advancing in, the Art Community.  The space is so large, we couldn't not put one in and will still have room for retail.  Unlike other galleries though we will already have a fully functioning business to cover the overhead, so 100% of the money from art sales will go directly into the (student) Artist's pocket.  We feel it will be the perfect hybrid, continually drawing inspiration from one another.    
     But our Campaign's success is dependent on the community, who will decide if this is something they want for their community.  No matter if this Campaign is successful or not the shop will still open, but we are hoping this works (hint, hint.....)
 ___________________________________________________________________

 You're Probably Asking Yourself-
"Why The Hell Would They Give Away Free Time on Tattoos?"
Well that's simple.  Sure we can (and may still have to, LOL) go to a bank and pay a ton of interest to a bunch of faceless suits (no offense to any bankers who may be reading this) and open like every other business does.....  or we can try something different.
We would rather give away some serious discounts, for a limited time, and "Pay it Forward" to Our Clients, Rather than a Bank.  The people we wouldn't already have had a business for the past four years without..... and will now hopefully earn some new Clients along the way.
  ___________________________________________________________________


Why We Need Funds-
This space has been sitting vacant for a very long time and requires a complete gut and renovation.  Which means it will be absolutely pristine when we are finished but getting to that point is going to cost some serious cash and a little bit of time and labor.  Also- Licensing, Permitting, Materials, Advertising, Employees, Taxes, Merchandise, Furniture, Body Art Equipment & Supplies, Insurance, Gallery Set Up.... It all adds up very quickly.       We decided to let everyone get involved and thank them generously in return.  We've come up with some great Perks and hope you wont miss your chance to take advantage of them while they last, because once this campaign is over there will never be pricing like this again at either shop.

story:
The Question of the Animal, The Question of Being

 It is through the work of art—where we recognize being and are able to see into the world of other beings—we may also find the means to construct a new concept of being; a concept that suspends anthropocentricism and is inclusive of more than the being that is human.  The question of the animal becomes the question of being; a question which begs consideration of Upper Midwest North American Indigenous philosophy which has been ignored—for the most part in traditional Western philosophy. Indigenous wisdom is not centered on anthropocentric constructs and offers insight into the question of being and into the human-animal relationship and our relationship to the Earth.  Maurice Merleau-Ponty’s notion of flesh of the world reflects the wisdom of Indigenous philosophy and creates a space for such philosophy to enter the discourse of man’s non-hierarchical relationship with the natural world.

Breakdown of my campaign funding:

I am campaigning to raise $1300 and the breakdown is as follows:

  • Airfare From Bemidji, MN to Sarasota, FL= $850
  • Three nights lodging =$360
  • Meals @ $30 per day = $90
  • I am campaigning for Fixed Funding, if I do not reach my goal, all contributions will be returned and I will not be able to attend the conference.

Why and how will your contribution make a difference? 

  • Each contribution, no matter the amount will bring me closer to my goal.
  • My paper to be presented is an important contribution to the NEXUS panel, to the conference and to all people interested in art, philosophy, and humans relationship to animals and the earth.
  • It is important to share my scholarly work with other peers and professionals in my field and to give this significant conversation a public platform where the discussion will begin and hopefully continue long beyond the place and time of the conference itself.

Challenges:

  • Beyond the obvious financial challenges, this--being my first invitation to present at a prestigious conference is a bit intimidating but I have complete confidence in my work and know that I will present it in such a way that others will be thinking of it long after the conference ends.

Other ways you can help:

  • I realize that some people cannot contribute financially but you can still help by asking others to spread the word, share my Indiegogo link on social networking systems and use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
I am doing this

Many times in my life I have given up and I know what that feels like. I know the slow death of the spirit that happens when we do not answer our calling. Everyone in this world is going for their dreams and working at it. I am raising funds for these programs so that I can continue to be one of the people that answers their calling, that takes the steps and surrenders to the journey.I value my time as I value others. It begins with the self.

Raising funds for tuition to attend two programs here in NYC

The first program focuses on the entertainment industry and has 3 separate levels. The first level that I was just admitted to costs 375.00.

The second program is an acting program that is 6 months long. This program costs 1650.00.

The funds donated will all go directly to the programs. Wether I reach my goal or not, because I am attending. 

When I become better my students and fellow co creators become better

Other Ways You Can Help

I know some of my friends or fellow dream makers will not be able to donate money. 

Please know that even a share helps. Talk about it with someone you think maybe interested in the perks being offered. Share the indiegogo campaign. 

I am so thankful for this space. 

Thank you so much from the bottom of my heart

Cause when the music drops  youuuuuu #youbustamove

story:
You Are Here: A Multi Media Event

Every spring, the Multi-Media Event Class at the Maryland Institute College of Art (MICA) produces, directs, and creates a show featuring lines of each student's work. In order for our show, You Are Here, to happen this year, we need your help!

In the past this event has been known as the Experimental Fashion Show, but this year we came to the decision to call it a Multi Media Event, seeing that it is really so much more than fashion. Our lines include fashion, but also performances, puppetry, sculpture, and more. We have been busy putting our collections together since August, and can't wait to show them to you.

We’ve booked our venue at our very own BBOX on MICA's campus. On April 26th and 27th 2019, You Are Here will be bringing the Multi Media Event back home to MICA. 

We couldn't possibly run this show on our own, however.  We are working alongside stage managers, stage hands, photographers, videographers, graphic designers, technicians, models, and many other volunteers to create the best event possible. We need your support to help all of us come together and collaborate for You Are Here. 

Your contributions will help feed and support our technicians, artists and collaborators. Most of our goal will go towards feeding or volunteers at the shows, but the more we can earn, the more we are able to compensate people for all the time and work they have given us.

Whether you donate or not, it would help us out a lot if you shared this campaign!

Designers: Mark Fleuridor, Maddy Lavosky, Ellie MacInnes, Andrea Barnes, Wen-Yu Chang, Macy Peterman, Sarina Angell, Sukalp Bhatija, Regan Dunleavy, Zhirong Kang, Skip Chipps, and Bokeum Jeon

Follow our Instagram to see some of our work and get updates!
