story:
The Exhibition: Opening July 10 2015, The Studio on Chiltern Street, London

Without my Camera; Drawing Contemporary London is a project that will allow me to exhibit publicly for the first time in the UK. I will be presenting a body of work that I have created while living in London for the past two years. This project responds to an invitation from The Studio on Chiltern Street, to present a solo exhibition in central London, through the Studio's donated use of this beautiful gallery space.

My Art Practice:

Originally from Australia, my studio practice has been primarily concerned with drawing while being based in Hackney, East London.

With a particular interest in examining social activity and relationships, I create intimate portraits of people, places and their communities. I work from memory to capture these discrete moments in time, creating images through everyday observations. Using contemporary fashion as a starting point my work explores how we move and perform in public spaces.

Since 2008 I have shared these drawings online via my blog, www.leogreenfield.com. I consider this website as an ongoing artwork that has grown into an archive of impressions through the genre of street and fashion culture.

This art project has led me to draw from a diversity of settings and cultures, from the streets of small communities in rural Australia to major cities in Japan and Europe.

Without My Camera will present 60 of these drawings created since my arrival in the City in December 2013, that capture both the breadth of my studio practice and reflect my observational research in social drawing.

The Outcome:

The substantial donation of gallery space by The Studio on Chiltern Street has given me the opportunity to present my work in an international context. This solo exhibition will see my drawing practice brought to life and displayed in the very setting where it was inspired, the dynamic City of London.

My base while working in London has been a studio in Netil House, Hackney where I have applied my daily drawing practice. My artwork has appeared online via social media and in many printed publications but this exhibition will see these efforts realised in a physical format and viewed by a live audience.

The exhibition will provide a new opportunity for audiences to interact with this material beyond the virtual and will consolidate this two years of work at Netil House and also present my research into drawing as a fine art practise. As a working artist this exhibition will increase my exposure significantly and provide a platform for further creative opportunities.

Your donation;

Now that the artwork has been created and the perfect location to exhibit discovered I am seeking your help to fund Without my Camera; Drawing Contemporary London. All donations will receive perks as notions of gratitude; including posters, original art work and tours of East London. 

The target figure of £1500.00 for this campaign will be used to fund the fabrication, promotion and costs associated with hosting this unique event. 

These include;

·  The installation fabrication for the sculptural display of the art work. With the help of engineer Aran Dasan we have designed structures that will allow us to display a large collection of drawings. Please see the 3D designs of the exhibition set-up attached.

·  Insurance for the duration of the event to cover those involved and visitors to the exhibition.

·  Transport of materials and artworks for installation to and from the event.

·  Professional photography of the exhibition so the work can be documented and shared on social media.

·  Funding for the Press and a private viewing, including catering, staff and set-up costs.

·  Poster and catalogue production to document the event.

·  Enable this body of work to tour as an exhibition and to be shown in Melbourne in December 2015.


The Exhibition Team:

In addition to the donation of the space for this exhibition, I have been lucky enough to have the support of a fantastic collaborative team. These people have generously donated their skills to see this project become a reality.

I would therefore like to introduce;

Kim Blake, who has facilitated the donation of the space and is managing the PR for the event.

Aran Dasan who is designing and constructing the installation for the exhibition which is allowing me to explore experimental ways to displaying drawings as sculptural objects in-space.

Aimee Kepa and Mairi McPhee who have come on-board as producers and mentors for the exhibition.

I am also very grateful to Leon Bowers who has worked on graphic design for the project.


Your Support:

Your cash donation will help this exhibition to be realised and this unique opportunity in London used to its full potential but non-cash support is also most welcomed, such as the sensational in-kind support I have already received. My team and I would be incredibly grateful if you could spread the word to others that may help so please do so via Face Book, Tweets and email to share this upcoming exhibition with your friends and colleagues.

Thank you very much for being involved,



Leo


www.leogreenfield.com

story:
About Tortuga Gallery

Tortuga provides space for art, music, dance, poetry readings, film classes, and community meetings. In the process of applying for non-profit status, Tortuga has brought an enriching cultural experience to an under-served neighborhood adjacent to Albuquerque's struggling city center.

The building that houses Tortuga was built sometime in the 1880s when the railroad came through Albuquerque.  Its original purpose was a General store for the neighborhood and it has had many functions since then.  According to our neighbors, it has been a cabinet shop, laundromat, a food distribution center and a YMCA.
Proceeds from events held at Tortuga have been donated to many organizations including "Save the Bosque" sponsored by the Sierra Club, "Works in Progress" hosted by UNM's Blue Mesa Review, Peace One Day Awareness, Sickle Cell Warriors and Women Iraqi War Veterans.

Raise the Roof

The need for a new roof is urgent! To continue showing the great art work of the many creative emerging talents thriving in Albuquerque, this accessible, friendly venue needs community support.  It will cost $15,000 to replace the roof on this approximately 2,000 square foot building. 

Pax Garcia and Jill Logan
Pax and Jill, the owners and directors of the gallery, are the beating heart of Tortuga. Pax is an artist, musician and curates the shows at Tortuga. His amazing energy and skilled hands have transformed Tortuga from a derelict shell with no heat, electricity, or running water to the viable enterprise it is today.  Jill, an educator by training, provides the organizational and computer skills needed to keep things flowing smoothly. Together they provide a space for musicians, visual artists, dancers, poets and community organizations to meet and express their creativity in a single unique venue with amazing energy. 

About Our Mystery Artist

One morning Pax and Jill woke up to a large gift of art from the sister of an artist named Kaui who passed away awhile ago.  The sister had seen what looked like a silhouette for her sister in one of the online photos taken at Tortuga and felt led to ask Tortuga to exhibit her sisters work and consider as a donation to keep the gallery going. "The Buddha Dreams the Tree" will be raffled along with "Angels and Demons" by Pax Garcia as well as the one of Denise Weaver Ross' "House of Cards" series.  See the online gallery to view this images.  More information on the raffle will  be available at tortugagallery.org.

About Our Branding Artist

Lesley Long created the great brand image on for this campaign, found on the publicity, and the many perks. Lesley has been an artist and taking part in shows and working with galleries since the 1990's. She relocated to New Mexico from Bellingham, WA in 2007. She works mostly in oil paints but also has quite a collection of drawings. Her animal image paintings and drawings can be described as highly imaginative and sometimes dreamlike. She also has done quite a few ceramic works including a series of ceramic cat masks. To see more of her work visit etsy.com/shops/animalparty and on FaceBook at lesleylonganimalparty. Enjoy the animals!

story:
Who are we?

We are four Industrial Design Engineering students of The Hague University of Applied Science, passionately working on a project focussed on developing a shoe concept that takes the advantage of 3D printing and 3D scanning technologies. The aim of our project is to use and test these technologies and to find the best possible bridge between orthopedic shoes and fashionable, but uncomfortable shoes. A combination of a 3D printed "inner-shoe" and a traditionally manufactured "outer-shoe" is the result of 5 months of hard work, but now it is time to take it to the next level,  the production. With the right funds, we can complete the prototyping and testing process and fully develop the best ways to implement these technologies in the shoe market. The step towards full utilization of 3D printing technologies for the shoe industry can only be realized with the right prototypes and this requires funding. That is why we ask you to support us in reaching our goal of producing final prototypes of both the inner and the outer shoe. 

Konzept:

Despite the natural biomechanics of the feet, ready-to-wear shoes nowadays are still standardized, contributing to potential feet disease and injuries. Konzept is designed for young people, who need to prevent such cases. This piece introduce a long-term solution that aims to offer the market one of the most individual pair of shoes, fully customizable, combining 3D printing technology with traditional manufacturing processes. Using 3D scanning technology to complete a scan of each individual foot, allows a 3D printer to build a flexible but sturdy "sock-like" inner shoe, delivering a unique fit for the user. This inner shoe is made of flexible material and is very durable, but most importantly can be used in several outer shoes to fit different contexts. This way, comfort can be taken anywhere you want.As shown, the shoe exists out of two parts. The inner part is a 3D-printed sock-like wearable, printed to fit the exact shape of your feet. 3D scanning technology is used to create a model of the negative of one's individual feet. Experts convert this negative to create a model around it and add further corrections, which will help the user to gain a high level of comfort. Together with the expertise of official Orthopedic shoe-makers, we will adjust the support of the shoe according to personal needs. Using flexible filament (Ninjaflex/Filaflex) on an FDM printer, the inner shoe is then printed. 

The outer part of the shoe is traditionally manufactured and can be customized to personal preferences. For the start up of this project, we will focus on one basic model, a shoe that would fit casual occasions such as several types of work environments, study surroundings and recreational ones. The range of models will be further expanded in the future, as we proceed working on the development of Konzept. 
Why two parts? During our research, we realized that current 3D printed shoes are often too extreme and artistic for the users. By using two parts, it is not only possible to transport comfort into several shoes, it also allows the user to keep within acceptable looks for a 3D printed product. It is basically bridging the gap between extreme artistic shoes and the normal shoes we know. Also, by having two parts, we can continue developing different models for the outer shoe, possibly exploring more specific fields. 

The thought behind the Konzept shoe is based on the unmet need for having ultimate and long-lasting comfort while being able to walk around in style. The current shoe market aims at mass production, surpassing the need for personal attention. Basic shoe models cause problems for those who have slightly different feet, such as blisters, injury and possible back problems. The thought of getting a pair of custom orthopedic shoes is still often associated with unpleasantly looking, often large shoes, and if there are no significant problems yet, then why bother? 
3D printing and scanning technologies are opening up new possibilities for a future of widely implementing customized products. The possibilities are there, but we are not that accessible yet to the average user. Konzept uses the opportunities to adres not only prevention of  health related problems, it also allows the user to optimally benefit from the value it delivers. Our solution is personal and innovative, so perfect for those who face problems with standard sizes of shoes and happen to have an interest for design and technology! 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to development a proper production plan, we need to test the functioning of the inner and outer shoe, and their behavior together. We will make real-sized prototypes, in order to test comfort, fit and behavior in different climates.  The university don't own the correctly sized printers we need, so we have to involve an outside company to support us with printing the shoe models. This is more expensive but necessary for proper results that we can use to conduct tests. Costs per shoe: 150€. 

The outer shoe will be produced in collaboration with an orthopedic shoe company in The Hague, but the expenses are for us. We plan to make 2 pairs of shoes to test size, behavior and different materials in combination with the inner shoe. Total costs: 300€.

If we don't reach our goal of 1000€, we will still use the money for our prototypes but we will be limited in the amount of prototypes and testing we can do. 

By funding our project, you will become a part of the actualization of this step into the future! 


Risks & Challenges

Final implementation of this project needs a lot of development because of the costs involved. We might have to invest in our own printer in order to start production at a bigger scale. 

Entering in a new market is always risky, as there are likely obstacles that we are not fully aware of. However, our research led us to believe that we can take this risk, and we are confident that we can pass these obstacles.

story:
Heed me, fellow Brojans! BROSTOCK is coming up fast on Sept. 1st (aaaa) and you know what? We're gonna raise $500 and get THREE port-a-pots! AND a handwashing station with water and paper towels!! BECAUSE WE LOVE OURSELVES AND WE DESERVE IT!!!

Suggested donation is $5 person, but pay what you can. Thanks very much everyone.

And don't forget to check the event description for important details like how to respect the grounds, what to expect, where to sign up for things, etc.: https://www.facebook.com/events/177377312936969/

PHOTO CREDIT: Peggy Peterson Photography 

https://www.facebook.com/peggypetersonphoto/

story:
Good News!

Thanks to your support we're now fully funded, which means I can afford to add additional tiers. Check the Updates tab for more information on the new nightingale cards and how you can bring them home.

Card Front

Shadows will be eliminated during the final print

Card Back

The Skinny

  • One independent artist kicking off a career
  • Symbolically resonant greeting cards
  • A striking, elegant style and a passion for nature

What You'll Get

All backers receive the following:

  • A card with a meaningful message for your loved ones
  • Free shipping
  • The satisfaction of helping a developing artist spread his wings

At $20 you'll also receive a 30% discount on all future cards (which, with your support and a bit of luck, will be many and varied).

Finally, in addition to those other perks at $65 I'll draw a custom poster for you featuring an animal that you find personally meaningful in the style of the image below. ($20 value unsubtly included.)

Obstacles

With the image already created, nothing short of Santa crashing through the local print shop's roof can stop this campaign after it's funded.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not a holiday season sort of person but still want to support me?

  • Publish my campaign on your social media
  • 'Like' my page on Facebook here and drag your friends along
  • Contact me to commission a custom piece (or even a print line) more to your tastes
  • Send hugs. This is my first time putting myself out there in the crowdfunding world, and boy, it's not as easy as it looks.

Thank you all once again, and best of luck in your own lives through the new year.
